PARA.TAB: With regard to the assertion made by the member for Watson, I think he was out of the chamber when I read out those really pertinent comments of Mr W. Pollard, the chief executive officer designate of Airservices Australia, made on 29 September 1995. Subsequent to that, I understand, someone tried to heavy him to get him to change his view. But he put it well and truly onto the record and I think it is worth putting on the record again. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout the world, and in my past experience, there are many airports that have intercepting runways and they are used quite safely. In fact, many airports do not have parallel runways but usually have one north-south and one east-west, and many times they are intercepting and it is done safely.

I have a lot more comments along those lines and which I have used already in the course of this debate. My colleague the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) recently held up a map showing just how the airport currently operates. You can see that traffic is concentrated in an unfair way over citizens who are suffering badly.

PARA.TAB: These are the flight patterns that have been put in place after the minister's so-called noise abatement program in November 1994. This is a map of how the noise pattern used to be distributed when the east-west runway was operating. I think it is significant to remember that for 40 years Sydney airport—

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you table it?
—Yes, indeed. I seek leave to table the map, Mr Deputy Speaker.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—Is leave granted?
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am amazed it took him so long. They always say no. They do not want anything to be on the record; they certainly do not want it in Hansard where ordinary folks can read it. The point I was making is that this has been a deliberate political ploy to make the lives of some folk in Sydney unbearable—and unbearable is what it has become. They know that the only chance they have is to see this government turfed out. They know that they cannot believe a word any of the ministers have to say on this matter or, indeed, on any other matter.

PARA.TAB: They remember that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) told them before the last election that they were going to get tax cuts and that they were going to be put into l-a-w, law. They remember that Bob Carr, the Labor Party Premier in New South Wales, said he was going to take the tolls off roadways. He won the election and not only have the tolls stayed but the Carr government is going to build some more toll roads. They remember the excuse that the Prime Minister gave for not giving the tax cuts was that somewhere down the line he was going to give them something else. They are not quite sure what it was. All they know is that they were not told the truth. They are not going to believe anything the government has to say about having any care or concern for the plight these people find themselves in.

The member for Watson in his contribution has tried to confuse and abuse the issue. He tried to say that it is unsafe to reopen that runway when in Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth, as we speak, those cross-runways are in operation. The minister somehow considers that the people of Sydney are not quite as smart as those in Melbourne, Adelaide or Perth and, therefore, cannot run cross-runways; he somehow considers safety to be an issue for Sydney but not for the people of Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth. That is a nonsense argument.

The minister has the power to accept these amendments today and to allow the bill to have its passage. We have already heard him say that he will not accept our amendments. I did allow the bill to pass through the second reading stage. We agreed to the passage of the bill through the second reading stage in the hope that the minister may change his mind and accept these amendments in the consideration in detail stage. We will see when the vote is taken. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PUNCH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —Attempting to blame the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) for noise resulting from the third runway is commensurate with trying to blame Bill Clinton for the Gulf War. It is blaming not only the wrong side but also the wrong administration. There are certainly a number of people around the place who can bear responsibility for the third runway and the decision to go ahead with it, but the minister at the table is certainly not one of them. He was with me shoulder to shoulder in the 1980s—and even before me, given his age—in fighting this thing to a standstill.

PARA.TAB: If there is one person who sits in this place who can take a good deal of the blame for this it is the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). When I was the Minister for Aviation Support, day after day he and his colleagues accused me of holding up the economic progress of this country in opposing the third runway and holding the nation's economy to ransom—all, supposedly, to save my seat. But what was his view on this? Let us go back to the condemnation of himself by his own words on Tuesday, 21 March 1989 in an interview with Mike Carlton on Radio 2GB. He says in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Their refusal to build the third runway over the last six and a half years has been based on their assessment of the politics of it. Their right wing numbers men openly boast that they are not going to be so stupid as to build a third runway and lose all those seats in Sydney. I have always regarded that argument, incidentally, as nonsense. I grew up under the flight paths in the St George area of Sydney and know something about the politics of the area and I have always regarded the issue as being grossly exaggerated in terms of the impact on local residents. There are a limited number of people who are severely affected by aircraft noise. The great bulk of the rest of them are only mildly affected and in any event bought their houses knowing full well that they were under flight paths. In any event—
listen to this one; this is a beauty—

there are many sections of my electorate, in areas like Lane Cove and Hunters Hill, that have just as much aircraft noise and are as frequently under flight paths as people living near the airport and I think that—
CARLTON: They may in fact get less if the third runway is built? People around Lane Cove?
JOHN HOWARD: Many people will because you will have the north-south pattern. I think the case for it on general interest grounds is absolutely overwhelming.

Condemned out of his own mouth—`the north-south pattern'. He predicted that his people would have less aircraft noise and he got it wrong. I go back to Hansard of 8 March 1989 when he was running this debate that supposedly I was holding up the progress of the entire nation to save my political seat, despite the 20 years of history of opposition to this runway before that. I drew his attention to the Hunters Hill mayor, Sheila Swain. I quoted:
Hunters Hill mayor Sheila Swain said today that her council was opposed to the plan.

PARA.TAB: She said the second international airport at Badgerys Creek should be given the top priority.
"At the western end of the municipality we already have quite a bit of noise from aircraft", Mrs Swain said.

SPEECH.PARA: She also said that it would become even greater with the third runway. Of course, I also drew to his attention in the debate on that day the comments of the then mayor of Lane Cove, Sydney Friedlander, on the issue. John Howard was warned. John Howard sold out his own electorate on this issue. He was warned. He made a major fundamental error and now he is attempting to blame people who actually opposed this runway right from the start.

PARA.TAB: Do we remember full well when the opposition in this place used to cry that this runway would meet the airport needs of Sydney until 2010 and that my proposal for Badgerys Creek was a gross waste of money and that we would not need Badgerys Creek until 2010? No. We have forgotten it. It vindicates my position on this all along. When those opposite were saying that I was selling out my electorate because the east-west runway would close, I said they never had any intention of bearing with that position and today proves that right. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, the member for Barton (Mr Punch), has entered the debate because he has been heavily involved in the airport politics of Sydney for a long time. He was a person people who so strongly believed in his opinion that he was forced to stand against his government.

PARA.TAB: I am sorry that he is leaving the chamber because what he has just demonstrated by his argument is that, if he knew all the time that Sydney was going to operate only on a north-south configuration and that the east-west runway was going to close, he was stupid to resign. If he knew that, he was stupid to resign. If he knew that the ultimate result was going to be what he claims is happening now, why did he resign? That is the stupidest thing he has ever done.

He cannot convince me that he thought it was going to operate solely north-south because all that he stood for then would have been in vain. If he knew it was going to operate on a north-south configuration only, he knew at that point that people were going to be free of aircraft noise. He knew that he would have achieved his goal of what he stood for. He could have said at that time, `It is bad now, but I will ensure that the government changes the configuration,' and he didn't do it. He resigned instead. If he knew those things, why did he resign?

He wasted his political life for something he said he believed in. If he had known at that time, as he now claims he did—as the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) maintains that he knew, as the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) claims he knew—that was the dumbest political thing a person has ever done from the New South Wales Right of the Australian Labor Party because you guys do not operate in that way. You operate on the basis of certainty alone.

I do not believe you thought for one moment that that east-west runway would close. Now that it has you claim, with the benefit of hindsight, that you knew all the time it was going to close. The simple question is: why did you resign? That was the silliest thing to do, to give up a ministry, if you were in there batting for your people. If you were convinced that you had won the arguments in the cabinet and the result was going to be the closure of the east-west runway, you could have argued that around the stumps and held your ministry.

You could have maintained the government's position because you would not have needed to vary with the government. If the government's goal was to close the east-west runway and you knew it, why did you not stick with government policy? It would have advantaged your people. There was no need to have resigned. I do not believe you are that sort of person.

I believe you honestly stood for what the people of your area wanted. They did want that runway to be modified. You said, `I cannot cop it. I cannot cop the continuation of this process. I am going to differ with my government, with my Prime Minister, and I am going to resign.' I believe you do hold those views very strongly, but I do not believe you knew at that time the east-west runway was going to close or you would not have resigned because your electorate has been advantaged by the closure.

The critical point in all of this is November 1994. We have a pattern here that shows the use of all three runways in November 1994. The statement by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) that was read out by the minister was based purely on the fact that if there were full use of Mascot there would have been a sharing of noise. I do not know if all people in the House at the moment can see it, but what this shows is that with a balanced spread of aircraft using three runways the noise is shared.

The minister has not promoted that sharing process whereby the people of Bennelong were suffering the same noise level as those in the flight path of the east-west runway. What he has done is changed that and provided a configuration such as this where only the people in the Bennelong area suffer, not the people in other parts of Sydney who previously suffered noise—sharing in the process. To achieve this goal, aircraft are flying 52 kilometres over residential areas at great danger to the residents of Sydney. (Time expired).

TALKER.NAME: Mr PUNCH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously my old friend the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) did not hear my concluding remarks. Let me expand on them for a moment. The quotations I used showed, without any semblance of fear of argument against it, that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) knew exactly what pattern he was advocating and what the result would be.

PARA.TAB: In my concluding remarks a few moments ago, I made the point that I believed, despite all the argument that was coming from that side, which you have just repeated six years later, my electorate was going to be better off, as it currently is, because of a supposed downgrading or closure of the east-west runway.

As I said at the time, and I will say it here again, I have never believed, and until the day I die I will never believe, that a Liberal Party government, the airlines, although I note their current position, or the aviation bureaucracy—one or all of them—will not at some stage, in their obsessive hunt to jam more and more aircraft into Sydney, because of their vested interests in the whole issue, come along and demand and campaign for the reopening of the east-west runway. That is what we have got now. You did not even take 10 years to revert to that position—to somersault on some position about closing the east-west runway.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has always been our position.

—You say now that it has always been your position to close the east-west runway. Howard is campaigning right now for the reopening of the east-west runway. He was always going to do that when he discovered that there was more noise on the people in his electorate. He made a mistake and now he is trying to get out of that mistake by reneging on his position of 1989 that the east-west runway would remain closed if the coalition built a third runway. So you have come the full circle on this.

PARA.TAB: What it all means is that, irrespective of whether you are in government or we are in government, for the residents of Sydney the third runway will become a game of Russian roulette: who is in government and who is going to put what aircraft and how many over whose houses? On current traffic figures, your proposal to reopen the east-west runway would see some 16 to 20 per cent more aircraft over the east-west runway than before immediately. It would also see a gross diminution in safety because of that mad Simops proposal that operated for some years. That is why you have painted yourselves and your constituents into a corner by supporting the reopening of the east-west runway.

The people under the east-west runway were happy to live with the amount of noise they had previously so long as they could see a diminution in it in the immediate term by the construction of Badgerys Creek. But you said Badgerys Creek was not needed until 2010—and you were wrong about that too. The one salient constant in all of this is that the opposition has not got one thing right about the third runway—ever. We have got a couple of things wrong about it, sure. But you ain't got one thing about it right.

That political roulette game is now alive and well. Despite the safety factors and the diminution in capacity which in 1989 was to you people the be all and end all—and I was the worst in the world for daring to say that perhaps we should put capacity somewhere other than KSA—we now have this Russian roulette game, inspired by your leader's fear of losing his seat, to reopen the east-west runway.

I always knew the Leader of the Opposition was going to do that, and so did the member for Watson. We always knew that, despite all the promises in 1989 that the east-west runway was going to be closed or diminished, someone would be back—and it would be your side of politics—to reopen it. Forget the promises made. Forget all the nuances. Forget all the winding up of the talkback radio commentators that those documents from the former state government have now revealed. You were always going to somersault on that and never keep the promises you were making to the people under the east-west flight path.

I resigned because I reckoned that decision was wrong. Hawke did a back flip and I am silly enough to believe that, if you make a promise, you ought to do your damnedest to keep it. I resigned to fight this thing the whole way. But it is in there now; it is a fait accompli and up and operating. What we have to do is what this man, the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton), is doing: try to lessen the impact on as many people in Sydney as possible—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a very passionate contribution from the member for Barton (Mr Punch), who resigned because he thought he would lose his seat. A picture speaks more than a thousand words. Here is the pre-November 1994 flight path pattern. Here is the post-1994 flight path pattern.
—You should table them.

—I have tried that already. My colleague reminds me that we should table them. But, of course, the government does not want those pictures in the record because they do speak more than a thousand words. I asked to have them tabled. I wanted them printed in the Hansard so that other folk could see them.
—You cannot print them.
—Indeed you can.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! Any decision as to whether or not these are able to be tabled is not a matter for debate between the member for Mackellar and the member for Watson.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point is that the government has not acceded to their tabling. I revert to the point I was making. A picture speaks more than a thousand words. The bottom line is this: it is a political decision, taken by the minister in November 1994, to ensure that the most pain is inflicted upon the people who live at the end of the Bennelong tunnel. It is a deliberate political decision. Of course, the good member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) and the good minister think it is very amusing for these people. They laugh away the plight of other Australians. They laugh at the fact that people are losing the value of their homes.
—We are laughing at your reference to a tunnel.

—There is no light for those people at the end of the Bennelong tunnel. When you are defeated as a government, then there will be hope for the people at the end of the Bennelong tunnel; yes, indeed. John Howard does offer that hope. John Howard does offer that light for those people, and they know it. They know very well that unless you lot are defeated—thrown out, as you were in New South Wales—there is no light at the end of the tunnel.

PARA.TAB: The minister may well have the pleasure of playing a similar role for his leader in this next election as he played for Barrie Unsworth. He was a major figure in bringing down the Unsworth government, which, of course, was the inheritor of the Wran government. Mr Brereton was known as the pariah of the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —The pariah of Palm Beach.

—He is the pariah of paradise when he comes into my electorate, I can tell you that. As I said, a picture speaks more than a thousand words. The illustration shows where the flight paths now go, making life hell for people who live under those flight paths. It also shows where those planes did not fly, in the same numbers, before—areas where the people's homes have lost value and where people have had health repercussions because of the intensity of what has been inflicted upon them by the decision of the minister.

PARA.TAB: Much of this debate today has been quite entertaining. We have heard history regurgitated by people on the Labor Party side, who have put their slant on it. The bottom line is that it is the minister's decision of November 1994 that has destroyed the lives of thousands of people in Sydney. I have said to the minister again and again: it is within your power to accept these amendments, to allow the privatisation to go ahead and to enable a fair and equitable distribution of the noise factor by reopening the east-west runway. There is sufficient evidence on the record to show beyond doubt that it is perfectly safe and, indeed, advantageous to reopen it. The final piece of logic that can be said is that, when there was discussion about a third runway, it was always two runways plus a new runway equals three runways. They should be run together, and successfully together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening patiently to the debate on the airport bills. It has taken me back to my entry to the parliament at the beginning of 1994. At that time the member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) was challenging the then Leader of the Opposition, John Hewson, for the leadership of the Liberal Party. Reflecting on that leads me to think how the mighty have fallen since the beginning of 1994.

PARA.TAB: The member for Mackellar wants to berate the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) on a few issues. She has got plenty of front, plenty of hide, to do that when, over the last 18 months, no-one in this place has more comprehensively failed on policy questions than the member for Mackellar. In health, she has failed on issue after issue after issue. In her attacks on the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence), there has been failure after failure after failure.

Just yesterday, it was embarrassment after embarrassment when the member for Mackellar, in a speech which the media reported this morning, said that governments have no responsibility, taxpayers have no responsibility, for the outcomes of family breakdown. Who has responsibility? Is it the street cleaner? Is it the people who clean up those who have to sleep on the streets? The member for Mackellar, in her tirade of abuse, really has shown more hide than anyone could ever imagine.

The truth of the matter is that airport administration is not an easy public policy task. Who are they going to call on the opposition side to undertake the task? The honourable member for Mackellar. What did she come up with? These total inconsistencies. It makes for some very interesting points in the debate because members on this side of the House from east Sydney—the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), the member for Kingsford-Smith and the member for Barton (Mr Punch)—and members from west Sydney—myself and the member for Chifley (Mr Price)—have spoken with one voice. It gives a total lie to the assertion by the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) earlier on that there is some division. For as long as I can remember, the five people I am talking about have all had one position—that is, the construction of the third runway was inadvisable. It was not going to be good policy. It was going to have consequences that would be unacceptable in terms of urban planning and urban environment. The best course of action would have been the construction of Badgerys Creek airport in the first instance.

My only regret in this matter is that the Minister for Transport was not in that position five or 10 years ago, because had he been we would have had Badgerys Creek up and running as Sydney's second international airport and there would have been no third runway. There is no doubt that the member for Mackellar and the member for Mitchell were supporting John Howard throughout the 1980s saying that the third runway was an essential micro-economic reform for Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sure is.

—The member for Mitchell has just confirmed that: it is absolutely essential. From the very first day they had the strongest possible support, along with Nick Greiner's government in New South Wales, for the third runway, and all the noise consequences that holds for people in the inner city. Those who are arguing against that position have been here today arguing the same position years later—the member for Watson, the member for Kingsford-Smith and the member for Barton, joined by myself and the member for Chifley. We have stated what we believe to be the correct position. We want to make sure that Badgerys Creek airport can be successful for the tens of thousands of jobs it offers in western Sydney, a real catalyst for tourism and manufacturing growth, and to do it in a fashion which is consistent with good urban and environmental planning in the greater west.

PARA.TAB: What we have seen from the opposition is these propositions: campaigning in east Sydney saying that they want to reopen the east-west and holding up this legislation until that is done; saying in east Sydney and the electorates of Lowe and Bennelong that they want to fast-track Badgerys Creek airport; and assertions being made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) that somehow it would be possible to transfer all the international flights to Badgerys Creek.

What the member for Mackellar has argued throughout the debate on this amendment is that it is possible to fast-track Badgerys Creek without finance, or at least not to specify where the money would be coming from. That is a shameful position for a senior member of the opposition to take. The member for Mackellar and her copilot, the Leader of the Opposition, when they campaign in the south-west of Sydney and the seat of Macarthur, say they want a comprehensive EIS at Badgerys Creek which would involve a two- or three-year delay. Her interpretation of fast tracking is to build a two- to three-year delay into the process. This really is low grade stuff. This is low level flying in every sense. In the consistency and in the substance of this debate I would have thought it would be clear to anyone listening to the discussion or reading the Hansard at a subsequent date that Labor has been consistent on this matter and the Opposition has been a shameful, inconsistent fraud.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to conclude my remarks in this debate by saying something about Badgerys Creek. The fact is that Badgerys Creek airport will go ahead and it will be a significant economic generator. It took effort from everybody—local government, state government and federal government representatives—to convince the minister at the table and the FAC that the runway should be at least capable of handling jumbo jets. That was not the government's original intention and the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) knows that. It still is not adequate. In the process of financing and generating activity, the government has decided to use taxpayers' funds through the FAC. It has been the preferred position of local governments, elected members of the Labor Party and the Liberal Party from western Sydney to use a mixture of private funds and government funds, perhaps drawing in elements of local government and representatives of the community to construct a truly local international airport.

PARA.TAB: John Howard has not endorsed the use of Badgerys Creek as Sydney's international airport. You cannot keep misrepresenting him in that way. That is not a fact. As to the progress at Badgerys Creek, I put the minister on notice that western Sydney residents are becoming very concerned about the lack of action and communication by your government. In the last month there has been an effort by some of your members and you to restore that situation. You need to do a whole heap more than you are doing. There are pockets of resistance rising up because people do not know what the flight paths are going to be. They cannot understand what the ultimate resolution of this problem will be. It is time for you to get out there—

TALK.START.PARA: —An international airport. John Howard promised it.

—The minister can say what he likes but I have here a time flow chart, and none of this is yet under way. Yet you are putting out statements around western Sydney that the tractors will roll at the beginning of March. The EIS is not supposed to be finished until the end of July next year. Are you going to start construction before the EIS is finished? Are you saying that the EIS you are doing is just a facade and an update of what has already been done? Of course you are.

PARA.TAB: You intend to have, through the community consultations, the negotiations, the EIS and the whole construction of the infrastructure, token consultation. You are not going to do a real job on this; you are going to push ahead because you have a problem down at Mascot. You are not going to treat the people of the west any better than you did when you were in the state government. Your view of Sydney, from those salubrious buildings bordering Sydney Harbour, stretched as far as Drummoyne, as being the western suburbs. I think it is time that you communicated effectively with people.

The Olympic Games are coming up. The pressure from the people of western Sydney is to have this airport finished by the year 2000. Your parliamentary secretary says it will be finished late in 1999. Every expert says that that is an impossibility, that you are not going to hit that target. That is a gross overstatement. Don't you think the unions will screw you when they know you're on such a short timetable? Do you think you will satisfy the needs of Sydney and the Olympic Games by not connecting rail to it? Are you going to force people onto more road transport? What do you, as Minister for Transport, really stand for? You have got no environmental aspects in all of this. This was going to be the environmental Olympic Games, yet you ask people to depend on road transport for their communications. Where is the planning that you are espousing for Badgerys Creek?

This legislation needs to be held up until you make a decision to open the east-west runway. In so doing, I hope you will clarify your lack of commitment, lack of planning, lack of consultation with the people of western Sydney, so that they understand what you are doing, they are properly consulted, environmental studies are done and footprints are generated. In that way, people will know how they are going to be affected, where they are going to be affected and whether any measures need to be undertaken by you—and this bill gives you that power—to soundproof, insulate or buy property which is severely affected by noise pollution. This is a great amendment and I believe, minister, that you should support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham Mr M.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —That intervention by the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) raises the key point about this amendment from a western Sydney perspective. It goes, of course, to the press release issued by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) on 26 September. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition believes leasing of KSA should be deferred until the following occur: first, the east-west runway is re-opened; second—
and I hope the member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) is listening—
a genuine environmental impact statement on Badgerys Creek is completed.

Of course, in the terms of her amendment, that second condition is missing. It raises the question for hundreds of thousands of people in greater western Sydney: what is the current policy position and intention of the federal opposition regarding Badgerys Creek airport?

PARA.TAB: Is it fast-tracking, which is what the opposition have said, in the east of Sydney? If it is fast-tracking, how will they pay for it if they are not going to use the funds available from the private leasing of Kingsford Smith airport? If it is not fast-tracking, is it the environmental impact statement and therefore a two- to three-year delay in the construction of Badgerys Creek airport?

This is a key issue. Let me repeat the question for the member for Mackellar, whom I invite to give an answer which is so important to the people I represent: do you want Badgerys Creek fast-tracked and, if so, how will you pay for it, or do you want a new EIS, which will delay the process for two to three years? That is a key question fundamental to the coming election campaign and the policy positions that both parties will be taking throughout greater western Sydney and all the key seats in the region. I invite the member for Mackellar to give a straightforward answer to a straightforward and vital question.
Question put:
That the amendments (Mrs Bishop's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Bill agreed to.
Motion (by Mr Brereton)—by leave—put:
That the bill be now read a third time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.
Consideration resumed.
Bill (on motion by Mr Brereton) read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Mrs B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move opposition amendments Nos. 1 to 5:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 5, page 3, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Act not to apply to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) and Sydney West Airports until satisfactory equitable arrangements approved

SPEECH.PARA: "5. For the avoidance of doubt, it is expressly declared to be the intention of the Parliament that the provisions of this Act shall not apply to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and Sydney West Airport until a proposal that satisfactory arrangements are in place to share more equitably the aircraft noise burden over Sydney, in particular, the resumption of full operation of the East-West runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, has been approved as specified in paragraph 19(g).".
(2)Clause 19, page 9, lines 7 and 8, omit paragraphs (a) and (b).
(3)Clause 19, page 9, after paragraph (e) insert the following paragraph:
"(ea) Adelaide Airport;".
(4)Clause 19, page 9, line 12, omit "an airport", substitute "subject to paragraph (g), an airport".
(5)Clause 19, page 9, add at the end of the clause:

"(g)Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and Sydney West Airport must not be specified in the regulations unless a proposal that satisfactory arrangements are in place to share more equitably the aircraft noise burden over Sydney, in particular, the resumption of full operation of the East-West runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, has been laid before the Senate and the House of Representatives and approved by resolution of each House.".

These amendments are in line with the amendments I moved earlier to the Airports Bill to excise Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport. I now propose, similarly, to excise the references to Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport from the Airports (Transitional) Bill so as to effect the postponement of the privatisation until such time as the noise burden over Sydney is dealt with in a more equitable manner—in particular, until the resumption of the full operation of the east-west runway at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport has been approved.

PARA.TAB: It is also proposed in this set of amendments that the Adelaide airport be added to the list in clause 19 of the Airports (Transitional) Bill so that the provisions of that bill will apply to Adelaide airport forthwith. The reason for that amendment is to give effect to our belief that Adelaide airport ought to be treated like the other mainland capital city state airport and be in the first phase of sales of the Federal Airports Corporation. The current legislation unfairly discriminates against Adelaide airport by leaving it until the second tranche. We believe that it is only fair that it be included in that first list, and the amendment has been proposed accordingly.

We also propose, as we did with the previous bill, an amendment to prevent the government restoring Kingsford Smith airport to the list under the Airports (Transitional) Bill and the Airports Bill, including it in the first tranche of sales. Our reason, which we argued strongly with the first bill, is exactly the same with this bill—the unfair distribution of noise concentrated over certain areas of Sydney.

The government has argued that it cannot reopen the east-west runway because it believes that it is unsafe. That has been shown to be clearly fallacious. It is not unsafe. There is a list of experts, including the newly designated head of the government's own body oversighting air safety, who say that it is perfectly safe to conduct such an operation with intersecting runways.

In the debate on the previous bill, I used diagrams which showed pre-November 1994, when the minister made his decision which resulted in the inflicting of unfair noise and which has resulted in the depreciation of land values under these new flight paths and in health problems for people who are being subjected to this unfair battery of noise.

We simply say that you cannot sweep the question of noise under the carpet, allow the privatisation to proceed and believe that somehow it will magically be fixed. It will not. The responsibility is the minister's. He can address that problem now and allow the legislation to go through if he is serious about the privatisation.

As I said on the question of Adelaide, we have moved to bring it into the first tranche because we believe there is no reason whatsoever to discriminate against Adelaide and leave it out, and at some disadvantage. Accordingly, we are adding it in. I do hope the minister sees reason and accedes to the amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BRERETON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be acceding to these amendments for very good reason. Firstly, in respect of Adelaide airport I say: Adelaide airport needs to be extended and it needs to be extended prior to being leased. That is the priority of the South Australian government and it is the priority of our government. The proceeds for that extension, an extension due to commence in March of next year, come from the leasing of Sydney airport. That is where the funds are coming from. Of course, the opposition are proposing that the whole of the leasing process be wrecked by Sydney's being eliminated from the leasing process.

PARA.TAB: So in point of fact, the only people who are discriminating against Adelaide are the opposition, by persisting with these amendments and threatening to use their numbers in the Senate to block this legislation. They are the only people who can wreck the very carefully negotiated plans between our government and the government in South Australia to see the South Australian airport extended, and extended now.Certainly, privatising it in the first tranche is the last thing anyone has recommended. Every bit of financial advice has said: lease the major assets first but extend Adelaide first, before it is leased. Only the opposition would in effect discriminate against Adelaide airport.

In relation to this furphy that has been repeated by the opposition today about reopening the east-west runway, the opposition have always known that inherent in their plan to develop Kingsford Smith airport with parallel runways was the elimination of traffic on the east-west runway. They have known it for as long as this proposal has been around.

Some of them knew it even before they were here in this chamber. The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) knew it in 1975. In the New South Wales parliament, when across the chamber from me, he said that the proposal he was speaking in favour of then—that is, the parallel runway—would cater for an expansion of the traffic. An acceptance of the solution would mean that cross runways would not have to be used. You knew it in 1975. You have known it at every point.

John Howard knew it in 1989 when he was castigating this government for not proceeding with the expansion of Kingsford Smith. The whole of the opposition knew it when they were attacking the then minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, the member for Barton (Mr Punch), at the time he was saying Badgerys Creek should be built. John Howard knew it as Leader of the Opposition, knew it the day he turned up on the Mike Carlton program and knew it in every one of his public utterances.

It does the opposition no good at all to be claiming that Mr Bill Pollard, the new head of Airservices Australia, has said anything that supports their contention. In point of fact, Mr Pollard has said the opposite. What he said is, `Sure, you can run intersecting operations and they are run around the world.' But he also said, `You cannot run them at the capacity Sydney airport needs to run at to operate effectively, efficiently and to service the demand that is upon it.' And it is a very considerable demand.

The one thing the opposition have never been able to establish is how you could reopen the east-west runway, as they say they will, for full jet operations using intersecting runways and maintain the capacity. Airservices Australia says that that destroys the capacity. It could be as low as 55, as opposed to the 85 it is designed for and the government is committed to.

That wrecks the value of the airport, wrecks its ability to service the needs of Sydney. All of this is inherent in the proposal that is being put forward so ineptly by the shadow minister sitting opposite. It is a proposal that would destroy the value of the airports, that would destroy the ability of Badgerys Creek to be built, completed in time for the year 2000 Olympics, that would destroy our ability to proceed with the extension of Adelaide airport with the development of the new runway and would give us arrangements at Sydney airport, not only wrecking its value but destroying its capacity in rendering it less safe. This is, I repeat, the dumbest thing I have ever seen in 25 years of politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the opportunity to comment on some of the statements the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) made earlier in the debate when he concluded the second reading stage of this bill and also some of the other Labor MPs' comments. I think I should start by commenting on some of the amusing compliments that some of the Labor MPs seem to have given this unfortunate minister. The member for Chifley (Mr Price) complimented the minister by saying that, regardless of how shocking everybody says the minister is and what people say about the minister, he could not condemn the minister. He would not condemn the minister, even though other people say such shocking things about him. What a backhanded compliment.

PARA.TAB: That was followed by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Punch) complimenting the minister on the fantastic job he has done through the 1970s and 1980s. Given his age, of course, he goes back to the early 1970s—another backhanded slap in the face for the minister. Some friends the ALP members are to each other in this debate!

In the minister's comments he said some things about the federal government having done so much for South Australia. He commented on the road changes in Mount Barker, which is in my electorate, and he also commented on the runway extension. Still, even though the government has done so much for South Australia, why is South Australia a second-class citizen when it comes to the sale of the Adelaide airport, the premier airport in South Australia? Why is it that the Adelaide airport cannot be in the first tranche with the other airports being sold around the country? The reason is that South Australians are second-class citizens as far as this government is concerned and have always been treated that way.

The minister likes to hand out ugly threats about the coalition's position on this bill. He likes to say that the extension of the runway will be finished first before the sale of the airport, before the lease of the airport. If the extension is not done first, if we do not behave, if the coalition does not do what he wants us to do, then the suggestion hangs in the air that the runway extension might not go ahead.

He also suggests that the South Australian government in some way supports the Labor Party's position on the sale of the Adelaide airport. Nothing could be further from the truth. On Tuesday of last week the shadow cabinet in Adelaide announced that they would bring forward the sale of Adelaide airport by two years and put it in the first tranche of sales. This was welcomed by the Premier of South Australia, Dean Brown, who supports the coalition's position and who told me personally that I should do my best to push for that in Canberra for South Australia and for the Adelaide airport. So the government cannot try to clothe itself in the popularity of the South Australian Liberal government on this issue of the Adelaide airport.

The minister claimed that the coalition had stabbed South Australia in the back by not supporting the government's position. I do not know how he could ever suggest such a thing when the ALP has stabbed South Australia in the back not only over the airport but also over the wine tax which was in the budget two years ago and was introduced last year—the wine tax which so damages my state—

TALK.START.PARA: —I should let the member for Chifley (Mr Price) know that my comments about his contribution to the debate earlier were not about the substance of what he said in reference to the Airports Bill but in reference to the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) when he said that, regardless of what other people say about the minister—implying regardless of how shocking the minister is and what other people say about him—you could not condemn him and he was his friend. PARA.TAB: I would like to talk in this contribution about how important Adelaide airport is to South Australia, why it is that we want to bring forward the sale of the airport by two years and why the coalition announced that last Tuesday. Adelaide airport is vital to South Australia not because the length of the runway precludes its maximum use in bringing tourists to South Australia but, primarily, because the length of the runway precludes trade opportunities, exports to South-East Asia and imports from other countries.

South-East Asia is a market for fresh food produce, which is produced in abundance in South Australia. One of the great problems in trying to get that produce to places like Singapore and Hong Kong is that the size of the planes that take off from Adelaide airport is not sufficient to make it worth while for corporations in that region to use Adelaide airport. Therefore, a market that is waiting for South Australian companies to fill with fresh food produce, amongst many other goods and services, is not being used because of the runway extension not having gone ahead under the state Labor government, although it was promised many times. So the airport is very important to South Australia and the extension of the runway is very important.

Privatisation would be of assistance to Adelaide airport. There are people in South Australia and in Australia who are prepared to develop it into the premier airport that it should be and make it a proper and proud gateway to South Australia. Privatisation would also enhance its export potential. The South Australian government's position on privatisation, particularly on the runway extension, has been clear all along, and it has committed funds to upgrade it.

The minister is holding up an article. I was there last Tuesday when the announcement was made that the coalition would bring forward the sale of the Adelaide airport by two years, which was welcomed by the state government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without the extension.

PARA.TAB: The South Australian government is supportive of the coalition position to bring forward the sale of the Adelaide airport. TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) really does make it up as he goes along. No wonder nobody ever believes a word that passes his lips. PARA.TAB: How dare you come into this place and say you stitched up a deal with the man who was Leader of the Opposition, whose name nobody can remember. How dare you come in here and tell us you bypassed the proper Westminster and parliamentary processes so that you can do deals on the sly with your mates. What an affront you are to this parliament. You are saying that Punch is a dill for resigning because he should have known there was going to be a change in the configuration. That is what you are saying. It is illogical, Minister. Nobody knew that. The three runways were going to be used in conjunction.

PARA.TAB: That has always been the position of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the Fraser government and successive members of the Liberal Party. We were quite clear as to how Sydney airport was to be used. You interfered politically. You interfered in November 1994. You thought influencing seats was a smart thing to do to win the New South Wales election. You could not believe your success when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) endorsed that process.

Laurie Oakes, in an article in the Bulletin, had it exactly right when he described what happened. It is no use you denying that. This is exactly what occurred: the Prime Minister and cabinet came in and said that we were going to do it this way, we were going to close the east-west. The Prime Minister has a record of closing runways. He closed one at Bankstown because it aligned with his house when he lived there. That is the fact of the matter: he closed a runway at Bankstown. He has a record of closing runways if they do not suit his personal convenience. That is the way in which this whole thing has operated: it is a matter of personal convenience.

In relation to the minister's description of the deals done in Adelaide, it is not a process of inclusive politics. It is a process of doing deals. Minister, you described it that way. You do not stand for the whole community. You represent the Labor Party here. You do not represent your fellow Australians. Nothing could be clearer in the way in which you are now trying to blackmail the Australian community into agreeing with you because it is a Labor Party policy.

Let me refer to the precision of these amendments and what the bill proposes. Your proposition, Minister, is that if we prevent the leasing of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) all of your works programs will stop. The budget does not say that. The budget is not predicated on any sales. I have here your transport budget, which you signed off. Here it is—your budget for 1995-96 for the transport portfolio. It is all your stuff. It has pretty pictures in it. There is not a thing in it about the sale of airports being essential for you to complete your program. You do not say that in your budget. Is your budget wrong?

Let me have a look at the works proposed at Badgerys Creek which you say cannot proceed unless you get this legislation. The EIS was supposed to have started in July. It has not yet started, so there has been no loss of money. Even though much of the work has not started, the works program for Badgerys Creek until the end of this year, 1995, was supposed to have been community consultation, negotiation and funding of lease, environmental assessment, design and documentation, infrastructure design, flight path and airspace management, EIS on Elizabeth Drive, west Sydney orbital stage 1 EIS, the west Sydney orbital stage 2 EIS and the negotiation of contractual arrangements—none of this requiring a single dollar. It is all paper and telephones.

Until the end of this year you do not need a cent for Sydney airport; you do not need a cent for Badgerys Creek. You do not need a cent until well into next year. But you are now saying that not selling Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport is going to stop the construction of Badgerys Creek and cause havoc in South Australia. Nobody will believe that. We just need to get that lorry of lies running around the suburbs telling the people what the real truth is, because you are certainly not telling them the real truth.

The coalition's decision that you need to open the east-west runway is a logical and carefully thought through decision. It is not going to create disruption to anybody or anything. The fact of the matter is that you could give our proposition the tick here in the House, it could go through the Senate and it would be all done. Overnight you would achieve your results. But, no, you prefer to blame others and say that it is going to cause havoc. It will cause havoc only if you choose to let it. (Time expired)

—I will do my best to follow your ruling, Mr Deputy Speaker.

—The minister said earlier in the debate that he linked the sale of the Kingsford Smith airport to the extension of the Adelaide runway. Nothing could be further from the truth. Six months ago or more, when the Adelaide airport extension was announced, the government made no mention of this being linked in any way to the sale of Kingsford Smith airport. The reality is that this government is trying to yet again adopt the thuggery tactics that it has adopted for 13 years as a government in Australia.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that this government stands bereft of any principle with respect to this matter and so many other issues, as I have observed in my short experience as the member for Sturt. TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that the residents of the North Shore—whom the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) has today tagged `a lousy handful of votes'—will be very pleased to know that that is the way in which they are regarded by this minister. As I said earlier, if you really want to remember the lengths to which this lot will go, take a look every day at Peter Baldwin's face: bashed and meant to be dead.

We have come to the stage in this debate where ordinary mums and dads—who are suffering at the hands of this minister's political decision to inflict noise pain on them—are becoming unhealthy; where psychiatrists are being involved; and, as I have said before, where property values are dropping. And all of this does not even register with the minister because he calls them `a handful of lousy votes'. As for your interjections about `shooting in the foot', you have not got any feet left. You have done it so often that you stand there on stumps at the end of your legs. It just is not an acceptable Australian way.

We will go forward to this election remembering many of the words that you have used in this debate to describe your contempt, your utter contempt, for individual Australians who are merely trying to get on with the business of running a family, of keeping a household together, of having some quality of life—and you have termed them `a handful of lousy votes'. As far as I am concerned, Minister, every individual Australian has the right to be considered. It does not matter if they belong to the same political party or not. We have forms of government and governance in this country which have to be observed.

Along with a lot of other people, I have read the texts of Mates and other books which show how you and your mates operate. As we go into the next century, we are going in there to have a clean government. We are going in there to have one that governs for all Australians—not just for their sectional interests and their mates.

This debate is about fairness and equity—concepts which I am afraid this government lost touch with a long time ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) is a very important bill. I am pleased that I am able to complete my speech, which was interrupted by the adjournment debate two nights ago. Clearly there is already a lack of responsiveness in the system and the `clever country' rationale for expansion is not being realised.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I would like to comment on the government's failure to foster an economy which is able to absorb the young people being educated in our universities. When the Dawkins revolution was sold to the Australian public in 1988, a major argument for the changes was that Australia's young needed to be educated to fill the highly skilled positions that were to be generated under a Labor government. Parents and young people accepted this story and invested money, energy and hope in the acquisition of a university education. Too many have found that the government's sales pitch was a gross distortion of reality.

While graduate unemployment is lower than unemployment for young people without degrees, there is overwhelming evidence to suggest that graduates have simply shifted into positions formerly held by non-graduates, rather than into the highly skilled positions promised them by the Labor government. Not only is this a tragedy for the non-graduates who are pushed into unemployment by the influx of graduates into positions previously held by non-graduates; it is also a tragedy for the young graduates who worked so hard towards a dream which they are now finding to be empty.

When reading about the 1995 Australian/Vogel Literary Award last month, I was struck by the sense of betrayal expressed by the 27-year-old winner of the award, Richard King. Richard was quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: My generation was brought up being promised so much . . . we found it wasn't there.
This is a damning indictment of the Labor government that has been in power for the last 13 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham Mr M.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) in saying this is a very important piece of legislation. The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 is the sort of bill that goes to the heart of the social justice debate in which the parliament has been engaging in recent months. On that, in my experience, working people in Australia are concerned not so much with ownership issues as with skills and opportunities, and the active role of government in enhancing the economic and social capability of those genuinely in need.

PARA.TAB: Australia's education system is at the heart of this task. I had two reminders of this recently, both of them relevant to the higher education sector. The first of them was the comments made by Rupert Murdoch, expressing concern about the development of an underclass and the high level of youth unemployment in some parts of Australia. I thought people on the coalition side had a hide in making some of their comments on social justice issues, but for someone who sponsored the Thatcherite revolution in Britain and actively supported Reaganomics in the United States to be complaining about the development of an underclass is, indeed, exceptionally rich.

The second reminder on these issues arose on Monday. I noticed in the Sydney Morning Herald that the average TER—the equivalent these days of what had been known as the HSC—mark was twice as high in the north shore and eastern suburbs of Sydney than in western Sydney and south-western Sydney. The interesting thing about those figures—of course, they are in relation to school education—is that once people from western and south-western Sydney gain entry to university they do as well as people from any other part of Sydney.

This reinforces the importance of the link between higher education and school education and, in both sectors, the importance of the home learning environment. It is very important to broaden our concept of education beyond formal institutions, be they school education or higher education, to include the home learning environment where issues of advantage and disadvantage are so important.

I outline four principles that I believe are significant in the parliament's consideration of higher education in Australia. The first of those principles, of course, is the need for quality outcomes. What we have found, with the internationalisation of the Australian economy, is that all factors of production have now become mobile, except human skills.

In many respects, the quality of human skills determines a nation's wealth. The new growth theorists, who are becoming very popular in economic debates and forums, have emphasised the importance of a culture of innovation in a country in order to have successful trading and economic arrangements. A culture of entrepreneurship is very important for a nation's economic success. Higher education in Australia should be at the absolute vanguard of the shift in culture.

Also, I think, on the issue of social values and leadership our universities need to play a more prominent role in the public debate. I was recently part of the parliament's delegation to the European parliament. As part of that, we listened to Chancellor Kohl, the German Chancellor, at the Council of Europe. He explained how all Western societies have an opportunity, in the 1990s and beyond, to define our societies by combining `the humanism of antiquity with the rationalism of our times'. That is a beautiful phrase and a beautiful set of ideals and values that are all about excellence, quality, compassion and a more enlightened society. Our universities should be at the absolute vanguard of defining such values and actively promoting their worth throughout all parts of Australian society.

The second principle I would define for the higher education sector is in terms of responsiveness to economic change and responsiveness to the internationalisation of the Australian economy. I have used this example in the parliament previously but I think it is worth repeating. Alcatel is a telecommunications company just to the north of my electorate. Its training cycle, its education cycle, is of just six months duration. Because of rapid technological change in that industry the company cannot sensibly plan ahead for the training needs of its staff for any more than six months.

This emphasises the problem for those in school or higher education who want to focus excessively on fixed content. I notice that Bob Carr, the Premier of New South Wales, is trying to focus on content. Content, of course, is always changing as technology and our economy change in response to international pressures. In many respects, with regard to fixed content in the curriculum of schools or universities, once people leave those institutions they remember very little of the content they picked up at school or university. The way of learning is all important and that is really where our universities should be placing more emphasis.

Are our universities in Australia responsive to these influences? Are they responsive to the sorts of economic and social changes that Australia has gone through over the last 10 to 15 years? I have some reservations about institutions that are based on guaranteed income, institutions that are based on tenure—that is, guaranteed employment for staff no matter the quality of their outcomes. I have reservations about outdated management methods in the university sector in Australia. Our universities, essentially, are based on 19th century small `l' liberal values embracing diversity at any cost, a belief in learning for the sake of learning and a feudal protection of tenure and academic freedom.

It is my very strong belief that our nation, with the challenges it faces over coming decades, needs much more than learning for learning's sake. We need learning and skills that are relevant to our economic position and our social requirements. This is where universities have such an important role to play. They must be relevant to the economy and, of course, provide social leadership in terms of promoting more enlightened social values.

The third principle I will address is this issue of a lifetime commitment to education. I think it is a peculiar thing in Australia—indeed, it is an unusual thing—when we look at some of our trading competitors. In Australia, education is seen as something that people undertake until their early 20s and it is somewhat of a task. What we need in Australia is an ethos of continuous, lifelong education throughout all parts of the population. There must be continuous updating of the skills and knowledge required for people to be successful in internationalised economic arrangements, successful in a post-industrial society.

This issue of continuous education, a lifetime commitment, and the promotion of a government framework for lifetime education basically requires a revolution in our thinking about education, including the higher education sector and the systems of service delivery that we have inherited over the decades.

The fourth question I will raise—and I mentioned this earlier on—is equity, the problem of intergenerational disadvantage in our post-industrial society. We really do need to tackle the fact that, while our schools can have a disadvantaged schools program and while we can have equity funding for universities, we need to link those initiatives to the home learning environment. That is the root cause of educational disadvantage in Australia in the 1990s. New forms of information technology are the great opportunity for linking the home and the formal learning environment.

Some of these methods may be intensive in their case management. Some of these methods may be expensive in their case management and their administration for government, but it is an expense that is well worth meeting if we are to meet the challenge of a more inclusive society. If we are to find the sorts of remedies that Rupert Murdoch would press upon us in his pious complaints then we should realise that ever smaller government is not the answer. Some of these remedies have a fiscal cost. Those who want to argue the case for social justice and a more inclusive society should be willing to meet the cost. It is important to recognise those realities. Smaller government is not an answer when it comes to building a more inclusive, a more socially just Australia.

I would suggest also that universities should be more active in addressing these issues of educational inequity and educational disadvantage. I was quite inspired to read a comment from a speech by the late Mr Peter Wilenski, one of the great educational administrators and reformers in Australia's history. He made the speech in my part of Sydney at the University of Western Sydney, in its formative days, on 10 October 1987. I think it is a very good statement to provide to the parliament. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Issues of equity of access should not be afterthoughts forced on a university by reformist governments. They go to the heart of what a university is about. The socioeconomic maldistribution in our university student population, the fact that children of poor parents are many more times unlikely to go to university than children of equal ability from wealthy families, represents not only a major social injustice and enormous waste of talent for society, but also a deviation from the pursuit of excellence by universities who as a result have less than the best students. It is little wonder that the half of the community which is less advantaged has not come to the defence of the universities when the universities appear to have so little relevance to their lives or those of their children. Of course, the fault lies to a large extent with the pre-university education system but universities can have a major role in influencing that system.

There are big challenges for higher education in Australia in meeting each of these four principles. I was delighted to learn that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) has appointed a higher education management review team which is due to report in December. I also noticed with some degree of interest that the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and some of the other authorities in higher education were very concerned about the fact that there would be an external review of their relevance to our economic arrangements and to the training and skill requirements in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I think it is a good sign that the universities are apprehensive about the external review. They should not be immune from the review process—the sort of reform, the sort of initiative that has affected all sections of our society, the school education system, TAFE, and all forms of learning. Universities should not be sheltered away, hiding behind walls of academic tenure and attempts to secure academic freedom at any cost.

The legislation before the House is interesting and very important because it addresses some of these key issues of equity in the distribution of resources between states and the distribution of resources by the federal government between universities. The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) makes amendments to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 to adjust funding levels as a result of the allocation of new places, additional research funds, carry forward of quality funds and the inclusion of funding for 1997 and 1998.

Funding will be provided to close to 6,000 new higher education places, plus those in the pipeline, in the years 1996 to 1998 to states with strong population growth and currently low participation rates. Queensland will be a major beneficiary of these places, as will New South Wales and Western Australia. They will also be receiving additional places. I am delighted—I note that my colleague the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) is at the table—that the University of Western Sydney has been a major beneficiary of the additional growth allocation in New South Wales.

I congratulate the minister, Mr Simon Crean, on his initiative. He is a minister who is prepared to take on the difficult public policy task of redistributing much needed university resources to areas of rapid population growth like the west and south-west of Sydney to areas like our region which has low participation rates for tertiary education. Good on Simon Crean for doing these things. I look forward to the formalisation of this type of funding formula, to build into the institutions this sense of redistribution. We have a changing economy, changing growth in population and changing social needs. A region such as greater western Sydney should never be overlooked as part of that process.

The package provides the consideration given to faster growing regions with low rates of tertiary participation. The challenge now is to institutionalise these transfers in the higher education funding formulas. The model adopted in 1990 by the government served as an aggregate historical cost system adjusted through teaching and research related cost components. Added to this base level is approved funding for growth. Once growth has been allocated it becomes part of the base for the following year of the rolling triennium: that is, each university's funding generally equals last year's base, adjusted for changes in the teaching profile and research requirement, plus a growth component.

Under these arrangements, the arrangements that the minister has now altered, it was very difficult to move resources between institutions. The tendency was to entrench the funding position of larger, older universities and aggravate the financial challenge facing newer universities in regions of rapid population growth. Only the redistribution of public resources can ensure that the rate of population growth in outer metropolitan areas such as my seat in the south-west of Sydney is matched by the growth in government services. Politically this is never a simple task. Entrenched interest will fight hard, even academics will fight hard, to preserve existing facilities and benefits compared to regions which have gone without and are struggling to secure new services. Nowhere are vested interests more entrenched than in Australia's universities. The mystique of research and administrative autonomy has produced a feeling that somehow universities should be treated differently from other areas of public policy.

The time is long overdue to bring higher education into the mainstream of political principles, and a number of reforms stand out. The first of those is to institutionalise, to build into funding formulas, the redistribution of funds to universities on the basis of high population growth and low tertiary participation—it is a basic equity principle.

The second initiative is to make sure that population growth in outer metropolitan areas is accommodated by growth in outer metropolitan universities, not inner city institutions. I noted that the joint DEET-Higher Education Council working party at the end of last year expressed a remarkable view. This is what the discussion paper had to say:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not considered that all, or even most, of the resources made available to a State should automatically be allocated to regional institutions in areas of high population growth or low participation in higher education. In the major capital cities in particular, a number of universities will be in commuting distance for most students. There is no reason to exclude institutions in inner city areas, for example, from access to additional resources simply because of their location . . .

What the discussion paper is effectively saying is that location is not relevant. Try telling that to a university aspirant living in my electorate in Campbelltown, where in driving time people are closer to Goulburn than they are to Sydney University or the University of New South Wales. Try telling that to the thousands of students in that region of the 1970s and 1980s—I was one of them—who did not have a university in their part of Sydney and had to commute for 1 1/2 hours one way, three hours each day, to Camperdown for Sydney University or to Kensington for the University of New South Wales. The travelling time and the expense were a great disadvantage, a great hardship to the students of Sydney's west and south-west.

PARA.TAB: It is my very strong belief, as it is within the government, that resources for regions of fast population growth need to be allocated to the universities which directly service those regions. I reject this spurious argument that somehow inner city institutions can equitably and fairly service the needs of university students on the urban fringe. The DEET-HEC approach would impose large costs in travel time and expenses on students from outer metropolitan areas. It does not sit well with policies to provide equality of higher education opportunity. The 1994 ALP national conference resolved to develop a series of social justice benchmarks on access and equity issues. Higher education funding should set basic standards for the availability of university places and reducing the time and expenses faced by student commuters, particularly those at the urban fringe.

My third initiative would be to develop funding formulas on the basis of regional rather than state needs. The DEET-HEC discussion paper used state boundaries as its unit of locational analysis. This contradicts the government's general support for regionalism and funding arrangements that support regional equity. Real geographic distinctions in Australia are regional, not between the states. State boundaries—lines drawn in at Whitehall last century—have shown themselves to be an irrelevant guide to locational inequality. For instance, while the New South Wales population is projected to fall, some parts of the state, such as the north coast and also the south-west of Sydney, face some of the highest rates of population growth in all of Australia.

My fourth initiative—and I trust the minister is keen on this idea—is to build socioeconomic indicators and notions of regionality into the higher education funding formulas. The Kelty report on regional development in 1993 recommended the government should take into account the regional services provided by higher education institutions when assessing their eligibility for funding.

The availability of skilled labour is now arguably the single most important determinant of regional competitiveness. Educational agendas can be tuned to regional agendas while also addressing international competitiveness, thus becoming important instruments for economic development. Funding allocations to support these objectives can be tied to specific projects or linked to broader notions of socioeconomic advantage and disadvantage at a regional level.

The development of these indicators for higher education funding would present few difficulties. The ABS has done significant work on the measurement of socioeconomic conditions by geographic areas. The major challenge in applying these indices lies in the relationship of a higher education institution to its student catchment area. There would be little purpose in providing growth funds to an institution to increase regional participation if the bulk of students came from outside the region. It would first be necessary to establish the proportion of students of each institution which is drawn from the regional catchment. Big challenges, a good bill and good work on the part of the minister. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to listen to the argument from the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham). I thought some of his initiatives were commendable and some of his argument was quite good. But I was interested to listen to his contribution to the debate because he started talking about the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 about 12 minutes into his speech. He spoke basically about the varying levels of grants funding for certain higher education institutions that are part of this particular amendment. He did not speak much about the HECS debt contribution scheme. He did not speak much at all on the voluntary threshold for repayment of the HECS debt, setting new income thresholds at which people become liable to repay their HECS debts, introducing a mandatory up-front payment for HECS for certain New Zealanders and non-citizens, and removing the HECS exemption scholarships for the professional development of teachers.

PARA.TAB: I am going to address some of those issues today, because it is an abomination—the Labor government's great HECS hoax. Far too often, for far too long, we have heard a tirade of Labor government rhetoric, reaction and, in some ways, rhubarb. All too often, we have heard the slick promises couched in terms of equity, fairness and across-the-board change when the reality is that the Labor government is set on one course and one course alone. That is the money course: the yellow brick road to revenue collection. The government has a bag full of revenue raising tricks, all underhanded, all covert and all designed to rob—yes, rob—ordinary Australians of a few dollars here and a few dollars there, in the same fashion as that of a sneakthief or a crafty cat burglar who comes stealing in the night.

Today's HECS debate is but one example of the way the government operates. It is yet another example of appearing to do the right thing but, in reality, stifling the opportunity of some Australian—some Mr or Mrs Average. In this case, it is the student who is the target. Fortunately, I am not aligned to the government's way of thinking, and I suspect their current practices are less than honest. I speak in facts, not rhetoric.

Let me give a few examples of the government's hidden attack on the people of Australia and some of its covert activities.
