This was John Howard on national radio assuring listeners that the second wave was not as bad as it was first put up to be because the most obnoxious elements had been taken away. He said that this had all been fixed up. He said:
. . . the two things the unions objected to most, have been taken out—
including—
. . . things relating to what happened if a union went into the Federal jurisdiction . . .

The truth is that the provisions cancelling the registration of state unions seeking federal coverage have not been removed—they are still in the legislation—nor has the provision giving Mr Kierath power to award coverage to whoever he chooses—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the federal jurisdiction.
—to whichever union Graham Kierath wants to assign those employees to.
—With an appeal provision.
—The member for O'Connor! Put a sock in it.

—This is not the only occasion that the Leader of the Opposition federally has been caught out in respect of the second wave. Yesterday the opposition was outraged by a one-day blockade of Western Australia, caused by the second wave. The opposition was outraged to the point where the Leader of the Opposition said workers should be sued. Yet the Leader of the Opposition seems to think that there is some sort of communications blockade with Western Australia every day of the week. How else can it be that he thinks he can say something in Perth, Western Australia—that the Western Australian model is his model—and then come into the parliament and say he denies it, and expect anyone to believe him?

PARA.TAB: The truth is that he is aiming to achieve the third of the great IR lies. The first one was Jeff Kennett on the eve of his election saying, `Your awards are safe. No worker will be worse off, believe me.' We all remember it. The second of the great lies was Richard Court's lie when he said, `I'm no Jeff Kennett'—remember that one, on the eve of his election?—`You'll be right with me.' The third lie was John Howard saying, `I didn't say Western Australia was our model.' Of course it is his model. It is his model of industrial conflict and of slashing conditions. The only difference is that under John Howard it would be a nationwide model. For the final word on that, let me point out what Chris Richardson—

TALK.START.PARA: —You're just going on and on.

—Chris Richardson is a very interesting fella, that's why. He is a director of Access Economics. That is virtually a Liberal Party think-tank. You have been quoting Access Economics in this parliament for years. Mr Richardson said to Australian business today:

ANSWER.PARA: There's no denying that for the first 12 to 18 months of a coalition government you might have to plan on more industrial tension than you've had for quite some time.
What he is saying is that Western Australia is just a skirmish. If John Howard gets his way, you ain't seen nothing yet.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon three Victoria Cross winners: Sir Roden Cutler, Mr Ted Kenna and Mr Keith Payne. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to our visitors.

TAB.EMPHASIS: Whereupon honourable members rose in their places and applauded—

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Minister, do you consider expenditure by the Governor-General to be excessive and, if so, why didn't you take steps to alter the guidelines and rein it in? If not, why are your cabinet colleagues engaging in unsourced and cowardly attacks on the Governor-General over the issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a product of some banter, is it? The honourable member is an expert in banter. I have already answered this question once publicly today, which is fair enough. I will go through it again here, which is fair enough too. The position with the Governor-General's finances is that the office is responsible, like any other government department or agency, for its own administration within the framework of guidelines by the Department of Finance. As far as we are concerned, there are no problems with the administration within the framework of the guidelines that are laid down by them. The finance department does not administer the departments of the Commonwealth. It is obviously ridiculous to assume that it does. All the restrictions that apply via those guidelines apply to the Governor-General's Office. For example, they are subject to the efficiency dividend in their running costs, as are the other departments which are responsible in observing Department of Finance guidelines.

PARA.TAB: I have had a chance to look at the article in the newspapers today. The answers to the story go reasonably as follows: firstly, there was obviously no account taken by the journalist concerned of the ordinary increases in expenditure that flow from wage increases and general increases in the cost of living. They have the same deflator that applies to most of the other departments. A substantial amount of the additional expenditure can be explained by that process.

Secondly, a substantial proportion of the differences between the period of time that Mr Hayden has been in office and that of his predecessors goes to renovations of Government House. Those renovations are determined from time to time as required by an Official Establishments Trust which works out how to keep our old public buildings in decent operation. They are not a benefit to the Governor-General. They are not renovations of his private property; they are renovations of the property of the Australian people. Obviously, those renovations of old places like the Governor-General's residence and establishment are from time to time likely to be substantial and do explain most of the expenditure additional to that.

There are one or two other items. I am advised that the Governor-General no longer utilises as personal aides members of the defence forces, so a slight increase in the civilian establishment has been associated with that. Other expenditures that were drawn to our attention by the article go to the utilisation of a 707 for a recent trip to the 80th anniversary of the Gallipoli landings. That was an entirely appropriate occasion for the Governor-General to attend. That trip was accompanied by a swing through Indo-China, where he was, of course, representing Australian interests and concerns. Clearly, it was convenient for him, in those circumstances where it is difficult to travel in that region, to operate with an Australian government jet. The notion that he is, in some way or another, personally advantaged by taking a 707 as opposed to sitting in the front of a Qantas jet again draws a long bow. All of us here have been in the government 707s from time to time.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members—No!

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, you have. I remember flying the whole darned lot of you out during the air disputes a couple of years ago, so don't go around the place pretending that you haven't flown in them before. I am a personal witness to your trooping aboard the 707s. You can't escape that. I will swear on a stack of Bibles that I saw you all. The fact is that nobody could conceivably say that the front end of a Qantas jet is not better than travelling in the 707s. I only make the point in passing. It was an appropriate use of that aircraft by the Governor-General. When you take all those factors into consideration, the additional costs being experienced by Government House are pretty well explicable.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Yesterday, an organisation representing young Australians outlined to the minister a number of proposals and issues regarding youth unemployment. Can the minister indicate to the House whether it is the intention of the government to take into account their views and those of others in the community in developing further responses to that significant problem? Also, did the youth forum raise any concerns regarding alternative strategies for addressing youth unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Yes, I did meet yesterday with the group that came from his electorate. It is the third time that I have met with them, because I have visited his electorate to meet with them on two previous occasions. Yesterday's meeting was a very constructive one. I must say that I am impressed by the quality of the contribution that is coming forward from the young people in this country.We have already announced some important changes that will benefit youth, in particular the school to job guarantee pathway which was announced in the electorate of Bonython some weeks ago. Tomorrow I will be announcing changes to the Working Nation program, which will also see further benefits to young people. Following the extensive consultations of which this was part, we will be announcing further initiatives later in the year.

PARA.TAB: In the discussions that I had with the youth group, a number of issues came up. Of major concern to the group that visited yesterday was the question of what would happen to youth wages. Under us, they do not have a problem because we are committed to no cuts to youth wages. We do have a training wage, but it is award and competency based and it must lead to an accredited outcome. If training is not undertaken, then the appropriate award needs to apply, and this government is well known for its support of wage increases. Their concern, however, is with what they think the coalition stands for. Yesterday they made the following demand of the coalition:

ANSWER.PARA: We demand that the Opposition immediately release its plans and policies for Youth Employment, Industrial Relations, Education and Youth Wages.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you write it for them?

—No, I did not write it, and that is an insult to them. I will make sure that the member for O'Connor is known as suggesting that they are not being genuine, and there would be others on the other side of the House who would probably share his views. But it was not only the youth I spoke to yesterday that have echoed this concern. Father David Cappo from the Australian Catholic—
—Ah!
—They do not like this. These are people who have to observe the problem and speak the truth, but they do not like it when it is directed against them. He said on 12 October:

ANSWER.PARA: People are very concerned that . . . that through the coalition's industrial relations program, that wages are going to be cut. Now, that . . . that is a concern out there in the community, it's got to be addressed.

This was issued the day before the Leader of the Opposition attended the ACOSS conference. He had the opportunity to set the record straight, but he did not. He squibbed it. It is true that what he did was to rule out a $3 per hour minimum rate, which was such a disastrous policy for you at the last election. But what we do know is that the Leader of the Opposition and his shadow spokesman are committed to reintroducing Jobsback. The Leader of the Opposition said in November last year:

Like all policies, the Jobsback! industrial relations document is being reviewed in the wake of the 1993 election defeat. Its essential thrust will not change. Its main principles are timeless. If anything, they are even more relevant to contemporary economic challenges.

So the substance of Jobsback is still the coalition policy. Let me just remind the House of what the substance of Jobsback means for wages. They are committed to reintroducing Austrain. Austrain is something the shadow spokesman has spoken with praise about. But what does Austrain involve? If people have been out of work for six months, their wages will be cut by 10 per cent. If they have been out of work for 12 months, they will be cut by 20 per cent. If they have been out of work for 18 months, they will be cut by 25 per cent. Apart from cutting the rate, which is what Austrain would do, there is no requirement under Austrain to actually train the person or to give accreditation and recognition to training already undertaken.

PARA.TAB: The opposition's position in relation to youth wages is shameless. They think that they have covered themselves because they have ruled out the $3 per hour minimum rate. But they have not ruled out $3.10 an hour or $3.20 an hour and they have not ruled out Austrain, which will see wages for youth cut. It is not what the opposition have said; it is what they will not say. The simple truth is that under John Howard youth wages will be cut.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask the minister to table the documents that he was reading from and the other documents in his hand, including, I presume, the joint press statement which I issued with Father Cappo on 16 October which entirely contradicts his representations in his answer.
—The minister has indicated he was speaking from notes.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer the minister to his answer to the previous question. I ask the minister: if you are so concerned with the problem of youth unemployment, why have you ceased publication of the regional youth unemployment statistics? Is it because you are embarrassed by the fact that the last figures to be published showed that teenage unemployment was 36 per cent in inner Sydney, 42 per cent in the Wide Bay-Burnett area of Queensland, 45 per cent in southern Adelaide and 65 per cent in north-western Melbourne? Will you now direct the resumption of the publication of these statistics, or is it not a fact that after 12 years in government you believe that the best way to deal with youth unemployment is to treat the issue politically and simply censor the statistics?

—The first question about employment that the shadow spokesman has asked of me in I think three months has come when we have seen for the first time a slight hiccup in the employment figures. The shadow spokesman absolutely salivates when there is bad news on the employment front. You can see him—Dr Glee. It really takes over. It is not true that the figures in relation to youth unemployment will not be available.
—`Regional'.

—On a regional basis. Of course they are available, because they are collected by the Bureau of Statistics. If you are not smart enough to wander over there to get the figures, there is something clearly wrong with you.It is not just this side of the House that has recognised the volatility of these regional figures and the fact that they are not a reliable guide. I recall the leader of the government in the Australian Capital Territory made a similar statement two days ago, saying that the figures cannot be treated seriously because they have shown that youth unemployment went over I think 40 per cent when the numbers actually fell.

PARA.TAB: I think what we have to understand in this is that there is a problem associated with the way the figures currently are reported. This has been acknowledged by a number of commentators in the gallery—Mr David McKenzie and Mr Don Greenlees, to name two. I refer members of the House to articles that they have written—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. My point of order relates to relevance. A question was asked about the publication of regional unemployment statistics. The minister is referring to statistics collected by the ABS which are not published.
—There is no point of order. The minister is being directly relevant to the question that was put to him.
—There is no point publishing something that does not give an accurate guide, but that is not to say the figures cannot be obtained. I have not stopped them. It is not my decision.

PARA.TAB: I think it is important to put on record the position in relation to youth unemployment. The number of teenagers looking for full-time work is at its lowest level since April 1990. In September it fell by almost 3,000 to 88,500. Over the year to September the number of teenagers looking for full-time work fell by 6,500.

The full-time unemployment rate for teenagers fell from 28 per cent in August to 26.7 per cent in September. As a proportion of the total—note that: total—15- to 19-year-old population, teenage unemployment fell from 7.2 per cent to seven per cent. As acknowledged over the last few days by a number of commentators, rates of youth unemployment are confusing and misleading as to the state of the youth labour market. They are therefore inappropriate as the basis for a target.

Clearly our aim is to reduce the number of 88,500 teenagers looking for full-time work, and we are clearly making headway. When we came back to power in 1983, do you know how many teenagers were out of work when John Howard left them? There were 158,000. Today it is 88,000—44 per cent lower. So don't give us this hypocrisy on your side of the House about doing something for the youth unemployed; it is nonsense.

The reality is that, even though we have dropped the number by 44 per cent, the unemployment rate itself, as measured by the statistician, has remained pretty much the same. The reason for that is that the number of teenagers available for work has declined dramatically. We have seen many more stay on to complete year 12 and many more go into TAFE or into universities—all because this government has funded the capacity for them to do so and all because we recognise that the jobs that used to employ people in the 1970s and early 1980s, the unskilled jobs, do not exist anymore. If you do not recognise that, then you are not following where the labour market is going. As we progress further towards the Finn targets, we will see—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 145. The minister was quite clearly asked why the publication of the regional youth unemployment statistics was ceased and will he now direct the resumption. While he is answering that, he may well tell this House why his department is now insisting on freedom of information applications to get information that is freely available.
—The minister was asked a question about youth unemployment. He is answering that question and so he is relevant.

—This is a trend that will continue as we progress down the path of the Finn targets. This government is committed to growth in TAFE, it is committed to growth in higher education and there will be fewer people available for the labour market. The issue in terms of youth unemployment is not the publication of figures; it is having policies in place that will address the problem and it is recognising that a person's employability is enhanced by the fact that they are trained and they are skilled.

PARA.TAB: Our policies are ensuring that they get that necessary training and skilling. That is the reason why the youth groups that have met with me are more interested in developing the way forward with us than they are with you. Getting that information is not an issue of freedom of information. You can roll on over to the Bureau of Statistics, get the information and make of it what you want. But the simple fact of the matter is that it would be far better for the opposition to propose some constructive policy rather than to distort and misrepresent figures. I would urge them to get on that bandwagon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The minister has been quoting extensively from a document and claiming that it is readily available. I ask him to table that document so we can see whether the figures are bogus.
—I do not think the minister said he was quoting from a document that was available. He is quoting from notes.
—You're not prepared to make them available?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—You would not understand them if we made them available. The final point I make is that this is a government committed to a target of getting unemployment down. We have set our sails for getting five per cent unemployment by the year 2000 and ensuring, by the programs we have in place, that youth get their fair share. It is the opposition that has given up on a target. It is the Leader of the Opposition who last week said that five per cent was not achievable. That is the message he is giving to the young people in this country: `We've given up on you. And for those who are looking for jobs, we'll cut your wages at the same time.' That is the difference between us and you and that is why they will support us.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. Is the minister aware of proposals to change the level of inequality in Australian society, and what would the effects of those proposals be?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable members would be well aware, we have heard a great deal of bleating from the opposition recently expressing concern about inequality and poverty. The level of hypocrisy is quite phenomenal. I guess the most extreme example I have seen in recent days is that press release from the opposition spokesman on social security, where he says:

ANSWER.PARA: Equality is important. Inequality is morally intolerable and dysfunctional to society as a whole in that inequality leads to envy and malice . . .

Anybody would think from that that in the wasteland speech on social policy the other day from the Leader of the Opposition we might have actually seen some semblance or some scintilla of a policy that might lead to reduced inequality. Of course, we saw no such thing. The only substantive policy proposals we saw there were the usual ones about flexibility in the labour market—which, as we know, is code for wage cuts.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition on that occasion took the opportunity to try to reassure people on low incomes and to try to reassure the welfare sector that a coalition government would not mean bad things for people on low incomes. But of course he keeps getting blown away by his own colleagues. We singularly fail to see from the Leader of the Opposition any specific policies whatever in this area. We get a constant stream from members of his backbench—and, in particular, from the well known Lyons Forum of conservative coalition MPs in their document Empowering families. They say:

ANSWER.PARA: Encouragement of less preferable families situations is a foible of the social welfare system.
Mr Howard says that he will protect the sole parent pension, but we get this sort of rhetoric coming from that quarter. Then the member for Mackellar the other day in a statement said:
It is not the taxpayers' responsibility to pick up the remnants of a family when it breaks up.

What an extraordinary statement that is. Is she seriously suggesting that the government has no responsibility to attend to the needs of children in families that have broken up and make sure that there is an adequate level of income support? Is that what is being said? This is the background that you have to bear in mind when you see the Leader of the Opposition trying to make reassuring noises. All you see is the black heart of the opposition coming out in these sorts of statements emanating from the backbench.

PARA.TAB: We know, from the experience of Western Australia and Victoria, that what the Liberals before an election say they will do after an election bears no relationship to what they will actually do after an election. All the prejudices coming from that side of politics are to cut the social safety net and to adopt punitive policies in all of these areas. It is based on prejudice, Mr Speaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wages are up in Western Australia, unemployment is down.
—If you look at the utterances of the Lyons Forum and others, they take great stock—

PARA.TAB: Mr Tuckey interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister might just wait for a moment. The member for O'Connor does not have to comment on every sentence or point. In fact, you do not have to comment—do me a favour!

—Of course, many people who are advocating the cutting of the sole parent pension draw a completely false analogy with the United States that fails to take account of all the active measures we have taken to ensure or to maximise the chances of sole parents getting back into the work force. The fact is that the teenage pregnancy rate has halved in this country since sole parent support was introduced in the 1970s, unlike in the United States where the rate of teenage pregnancy has increased quite substantially. So the suggestion that the existence of some sort of income support structure leads to a proliferation of teenage pregnancy is a demonstrably false proposition. Of course, the government has done a range of other things that the member for Mackellar and others have failed to acknowledge. One such thing is the introduction of the child support scheme as a result of which many more custodial parents, following family break-up, are now receiving some sort of support from the non-custodial parents.

PARA.TAB: The Lyons Forum has things to say in the area of taxation policy where, again, you see an almost total vacuum of specific proposals from the coalition. They actually seem to favour a family unit taxation of the kind seen in France. This is held up as something that is seen to be fairly reasonable. Of course, the French taxation system includes a 20 per cent GST—and we have seen the GST rear its ugly head again amongst members of the opposition.

Importantly, the sort of tax system that you see in France has no redistributive impact at all when looked at in contrast to the tax transfer system in this country, which is highly redistributive. According to some commentators and analysts, our tax system is radically redistributive. When we see this talk about inequality, we should just bear in mind—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker: I presume that the minister is starting to wind up, but I do draw your attention to the clock. This is the sixth question we have had and we have been going for 40 minutes. At this pace, question time today will exceed an hour and a half simply because there is absolutely no discipline and no requirement for ministers to at least make some attempt to provide a brief and succinct answer. Mr Speaker, I invite you to use your discretion.
—The honourable member for Flinders has again made a reasonable point. Might I suggest that ministers try to shorten their responses. I call the minister, in conclusion.

—In conclusion, the policy prescriptions of the coalition, in so far as we can make any sense of them, are such as to increase inequality unambiguously. In the countries that have followed their prescriptions—the US and the UK—earnings are far more unequal than in this country. In the US, inequality in earnings is 2 1/2 times the rate in Australia, and in the UK it is about 1 1/2 times our rate. I refer those honourable members on both sides of the House who want to see that confirmed to the recent EPAC paper on inequality.

—I refer the Minister for Social Security to the Economist table, which proves him totally wrong on that point. My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister and relates to income inequality. I refer the Deputy Prime Minister to the recent lavish salary increases for executives of AIDC Ltd, who can hardly be described as battlers. Does the government approve of such pay increases which saw the remuneration of executives earning more than $100,000 increase from $5.2 million to $13.6 million, an increase of over 160 per cent despite a 40 per cent drop in profit? If not, will the government take action as the majority shareholder to prevent the payment of $17 million in so-called `golden handcuffs' to senior management of AIDC on top of their salaries, especially since the justification for these payments—the sale of the government's remaining 80 per cent stake in AIDC—has been shelved and the government will in fact buy out the minority shareholders?
—The revelation of the dimensions of that pay increase was a matter which I must say I found of concern.
—Who is the shareholder?
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition did not ask the question.

—The boards of these operations are conducted at arms length from government and make their own determinations on what the payments ought to be. The board of course did suggest to the government that it would be necessary to provide encouragement to staff, because there is enormous competition in the financial sector for quality people in the merchant banking arena, and that in a period of change via the privatisation process—where, basically, the intellectual capital of the organisation counts more than just about anything else—there is a requirement to have incentives put in place to ensure that those quality people stay. The amount and dimension of those incentives were a product, I am advised, of consultations the board had with a number of private advisers elsewhere in the financial sector who were on equivalent salary structures.

PARA.TAB: If the AIDC is going to continue in the financial sector, it would be sensible for its board to pay levels of salary, emoluments and all the rest of it that are equivalent to what is received in the financial sector. That being the case, the evidence from all of that provides that salaries in the financial sector are salaries which are clearly enviable and, compared with salaries in the rest of Australia, are probably too much.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Has the minister's attention been drawn to an article in today's Melbourne Age regarding the conferral of life gold passes to the three surviving Australian holders of the Victoria Cross? Could the minister explain to the House the rationale behind the provision of such a privilege to these very special Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and I thank members on all sides of the House for giving that very warm welcome to those who are, I think no-one will dispute, three great Australian heroes.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Only 106 Australians have been awarded the Victoria Cross since its inception in 1856 by Queen Victoria. Unfortunately, only three now remain. They are Sir Roden Cutler, Mr Edward Kenna and Mr Keith Payne.

PARA.TAB: Sir Roden Cutler VC was awarded the Victoria Cross for conspicuous and sustained gallantry during the Syrian campaign, and for outstanding bravery during bitter fighting at Merdjayoun. At Damour, a few weeks later, a machine-gun injury led to a leg being amputated.

Edward Kenna VC was awarded the Victoria Cross for his actions against the Japanese in May 1945 near Wewak, New Guinea. Private Kenna exposed himself to direct enemy fire while disabling machine-gun posts with a rifle. His magnificent courage and complete disregard for his own safety resulted in a successful attack on a Japanese bunker and avoided many casualties.

Keith Payne VC saw active service in Korea and served in Malaya before going to Vietnam in 1969. In that conflict, Warrant Officer Keith Payne was awarded the Victoria Cross for outstanding bravery. Directly exposing himself to the enemy, he was injured in the hands and arms but continued to cover the withdrawal of his troops. After nightfall, he located 40 lost and wounded soldiers beyond the perimeters whom he led to safety through the enemy lines. His sustained and heroic personal efforts saved the lives of a large number of his indigenous soldiers and several of his fellow advisers.

The three surviving holders of the Victoria Cross are frequently requested to attend functions and commemorations all over Australia, as is befitting Australians who have achieved as they have. The life gold pass will provide up to a maximum of 25 first-class return trips per annum on scheduled commercial and commuter air services, main line rail services and other government services, or by motor coach or other vehicles operating as regular carriers, to the VC holders and their wives. The government has taken this step to alleviate the personal expense that these Australian heroes incur in performing what is ostensibly a civic duty. We often revere our sporting heroes but I am very sure that my parliamentary colleagues on all sides of the House will say that these are three truly authentic Australian heroes.

Can I also say—I am sure they will not mind me saying it—that today also happens to be the 50th anniversary reunion of HMAS Cowra. Many of the veterans from there are in the gallery and I am sure the House welcomes them as well.
Honourable members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I finish by simply saying again that I thank the House for giving these three people in particular the thanks that they deserve from this country.
—I indicate, on behalf of the coalition, that we strongly support and endorse the comments made by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and we salute three outstanding Australians.

—Mr Speaker, my question is to the Deputy Prime Minister and I ask: as the government that claimed before the last election that it would not increase taxes, deliver two rounds of tax cuts, not increase the Medicare levy, take pensioners out of the tax system by 1995, build a national museum, spend $100 million on buying private hospital beds for public patients, and not increase the pension age for women, why have you failed to devote at least one chapter of your Shaping the nation document to the one characteristic that, more than any other, is the mark of your government, and that is shaping the truth to fit your own political purposes?

—I am glad that you are paying such attention to that excellent document because what that document reveals is that we are the government that has produced two million jobs in this country—670,000 of them since the last election.
—Order! I have remarked before in this place on unparliamentary language. I have turned something of a deaf ear this afternoon to one or two interjections. I will not from here on.

—This is the government that, in terms of the social safety net, has improved benefits to families for their young children, depending on the age of the children over the time, by between 70 and 130 per cent. This is the government that has improved the age pension by 12 per cent in real terms. Both those economic statistics were on the decline when you happened to be in office.

PARA.TAB: This is the government that has put in place a social safety net of which, evidently, you are proud at the moment, as you wish to try to associate yourselves with it. This is the government that has put in place—when there were two million Australians without any form of medical cover at all after about six depredations of the Medibank system when you were in office—a Medicare system which after years and years you now decide that you want to sign up to.

This is the government that has provided seven different tranches of tax cuts for the Australian people, and in the last set of undertakings in the election provided the first tranche of tax cuts early and provided the second tranche of tax cuts in the form of enhanced savings through superannuation. This is the government that is putting in place via the superannuation process a savings policy that addresses the decline in private savings in this country and guarantees a decent retirement for all Australians, particularly for our current young Australians.

If this government is not re-elected and those superannuation promises are therefore overturned, which you have already indicated you will do, a 25-year-old in the work force now would have their retirement benefit cut by about two-thirds over what this government proposes, and of course there would be substantial reductions for everybody in the higher age brackets. So this is a government with a great deal to be proud of, and I am glad we are able to celebrate it with a book today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker, under standing order 145 relating to relevance. The Deputy Prime Minister has addressed a number of issues, with one exception. He did not address any of those promises before the election.
—Order! I think the Deputy Prime Minister responded in full.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Will he advise the House of the reasons for the government's intervention in the industrial dispute between the AMIEU and Australian Meat Holdings?

—Following a meeting on Monday evening between the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations, me and a very representative group of government backbenchers, the government announced that we will ask the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to take a number of urgent measures to address the dispute between the meat workers union and Australian Meat Holdings. To this end the government has indicated that we will intervene in these proceedings. The member for Capricornia and each of her government colleagues raised a number of serious concerns about AMH's approach to enterprise bargaining. For our part, the government will ask the commission to investigate the allegations of duress by AMH during the bargaining process, and claims that meat workers' pay is being reduced under arrangements pursued by AMH. These are very serious allegations and must be properly and fully investigated.

PARA.TAB: Today I have written to the commission president asking that the hearings scheduled for 31 October and 1 November be brought forward. Urgent resolution of the dispute is required as many workers at Beaudesert have been locked out. Facilitation of enterprise bargaining at all of AMH's plants is urgently required. Contrary to the views of ill-informed critics—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you do that at Mount Isa?
—including the member for Flinders who has interjected, enterprise bargaining in the meat industry is progressing successfully at a number of other works. You only need to look to Victoria.
—And Wally Curran?
—I pay tribute to the efforts of Wally Curran.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the results. In that state 17 enterprise agreements have been completed.

PARA.TAB: Mr Anderson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If the Deputy Leader of the National Party wants to be here for his MPI, he should just sit back.

—Castricum Brothers—completed. R.J. Gilbertson—completed. Hardwicks—completed. D. and S. Hamilton Meats—completed. M.C. Herd—completed. G. and K. O'Connor—completed. The list goes on. I compliment each of those parties, and I again compliment Mr Curran for the effort that has gone into making those bargains.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, the allegations of AMH workers not receiving correct award entitlements will now be investigated by the Commonwealth. Our officers will conduct inspections of AMH time records. The Queensland government, I am pleased to say, following an approach to Minister Matt Foley, will also investigate allegations that a number of workers have lost substantial sums of long service leave resulting from this dispute.

I conclude by saying that the meat industry is vital to our economy. The government intends to take every step to ensure that there is a fair bargaining process—one that delivers results, both to workers and to companies, and delivers them through increased productivity and delivers them in an atmosphere of stable industrial relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's statement on radio 3LO on 5 October of this year that `the housing affordability index . . . is very good now.' Is it not a fact that the Real Estate Institute of Australia and the Commonwealth Bank-HIA indices of home loan affordability both show a massive decline in home loan affordability under your government? Is it not a fact that, according to the REIA index, home loan affordability is now 36 per cent lower than in March 1983, when Labor came to office? Is it not also a fact that, since September 1984, home loan affordability has reached the levels of the previous coalition government in only one quarter of the intervening 11 years? How can the government assert that housing affordability is very good when its record is so abysmal?

—The situation when we came to office, which the honourable member refers to, was that home loan interest rates were touching 14 per cent. But that 14 per cent was not the half of it. What you had to do was cocktail it to get to anything like a situation where your deposit was likely to meet the amount that you had to borrow. In cocktailing those loans, you were taking your interest rates well over 14 per cent.

PARA.TAB: In the course of this last term of parliament, interest rates for home loans in this country have never gone above what was the lowest figure under John Howard's tutelage as the Treasurer of this nation. Home loan affordability in the sclerotic system they had was knocked to pieces by the fact that it was almost impossible to lay your hands on any money in that highly regulated environment, unless you were prepared to put yourself way above what were the advertised and allegedly fixed rates. In comparing our position here with your position when you were in office, the situation of borrowers for home loans now is vastly better.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Is the minister aware of reports of a document concerning the government's record on training and alternative strategies in this area? Can the minister advise the House whether claims in the document are accurate? If not, why not?

—I thank the honourable member for Lyons for his question. I am aware of such a document. It is being circulated in TAFE colleges and it seems to be authorised by a Mr Figart of Unley, who is, I understand, an employee of the Liberal Party in South Australia.At first glance, it looks like one of those lost scrolls—a Liberal Party policy. We know that it cannot be a policy, of course, because when the Leader of the Opposition farewelled his colleagues on their blunder-bus tour a few weeks ago, he admitted that he could not set any targets for youth unemployment because he did not have any policies. It certainly does appear to be part of a campaign of lies about vocational education and training.

PARA.TAB: Under Labor's track record, the document states that the number of young Australians in employment based training—that is, apprenticeships and traineeships—is at its lowest level for three decades. This is a porky. This is an absolute canard that coalition members have been told to repeat like parrots up and down the country. It is totally wrong and it is high time that those who were putting it around were well and truly nailed.

The facts are that three decades ago apprenticeship commencements stood at some 29,000 nationally. Commencements for 1994-95 were just over 53,000 and when we add the commencements for traineeships, which were introduced in 1995, we have almost 70,000 people entering workplace training. In the last year the coalition was in office, commencements were 34,794—less than half of today's figures. I have a graph that shows that. Here we are; there you were. I table the graph. You could not defend a record like the opposition's because it is so pathetic. The Liberal Party in South Australia can publish untruths about the situation but the truth is that the Leader of the Opposition did not care about apprentices back then and he certainly does not care now.

When this government established the Australian National Training Authority, we committed ourselves to developing the work skills essential for a competitive Australia. This year our funding for growth in vocational education and training has provided an extra 147,000 places for young people to obtain those skills that business and industry require. This government has committed $1 1/2 billion to provide extra training places for our youth. Over the five years of growth from 1993 to 1997, this government will have funded an extra 735,000 places.

Earlier this month, the Prime Minister met some of the products of this government's investment in training when he farewelled 40 of our young people who have just finished their training and who are representing Australia at the International Skill Olympics against 27 other countries. Those young people are currently competing at Lyon and I am sure we all wish them well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. Is the minister going to allow the Maritime Union of Australia to take charge of the future of ANL, despite having already had some $15 million wiped off its value through earlier capitulations to the MUA on top of the $145 million ANL has already lost while its future has been held hostage by the MUA? Will the minister give an assurance that the government will go ahead with the sale of ANL regardless of the selfish opposition of the MUA and end this fiasco and further huge losses for the taxpayer?

—As the honourable member and indeed the whole House knows, the future of ANL is the subject of negotiations at this very moment between the trade union movement and the company P&O, which is anxious to purchase the company. The outcome of those negotiations is something we will have to wait and see about. I have indicated clearly, and indeed government actions bear this out, that ANL will either be sold or be significantly restructured. Those are the two options and they are two options the government will consider in light of the negotiations.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs. The minister would be aware that a sixth Australian scientist has been appointed to the leadership of an international agricultural research organisation. What were the reasons for that appointment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Members will be aware of the very important day that occurred this week—World Food Day. The figure that springs to mind in connection with that anniversary is the 800 million people who each day in this world go to bed starving. Dealing with that fact is one of the most difficult issues which faces the world community. It is one in which Australia has a particular role to play. I thank the member for bringing attention to this particular appointment.

PARA.TAB: One of the ways that this problem can be addressed is by agricultural scientists worldwide applying their talents and their science to increasing agricultural production to make it more efficient, more productive, and to make agricultural methods more sustainable. Australia does, as the member indicates, make a significant contribution in this field. Only this week, our scientific credentials in the agriculture field were given a further boost by the appointment of a sixth Australian scientist to lead a major international agricultural research centre. That is six out of only 22 worldwide, so we are really fighting very much above our weight in this area.

The appointment of Dr Eric Craswell as the new Director-General of the International Board for Soil Research and Management, IBSRAM, means that in the last year three senior scientists from ACIAR, the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research, have been appointed to lead international research centres. Our contribution is not just significant; it is second to none. IBSRAM promotes soil management research in developing countries. In other words, it focuses on the welfare of the soil, which is the most fundamental resource for agriculture and the prime consideration in natural resource conservation.

One of the reasons we can take pride in this is the increasing part played by the aid program which operates through ACIAR. It is not just a funding body for agricultural research. It puts together collaborative, cooperative teams of scientists from Australia and other countries to work together to solve problems, and that has given our scientists international experience which makes them highly valued in the research community. This would not happen if it were not for the supportive climate fostered by this government, and indeed supported by the opposition, through the aid program. As long as I am minister responsible for this, those opportunities will continue.

I conclude by drawing attention to the science writer of the Australian, who is one of the few voices crying out for recognition of the fact that this is a field in which Australia leads the world. He points out in a recent article:

The doctrine of excellence is to focus your efforts on the field in which you enjoy your greatest natural advantages—and do everything within your power to enhance them. Devising new ways to produce food sustainably could be Australia's true opportunity for greatness.
In the time it took—

ANSWER.PARA: for question time—
4000 children died of malnutrition-related disease. Without a huge international effort, that toll will double and redouble . . .

PARA.TAB: But this country has the answers, if only it has the vision to apply them—and the will.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Today we had the notable presence in the gallery of our three surviving Victoria Cross winners. Two are particularly great Australians. The third is also a particularly great Australian, but I remember that he booted me up the backside when he was on the training staff of the army officer training unit. He is a good friend. I am reminded of further complaints on Monday and Tuesday of this week of the very great difficulty people sitting in the gallery, especially towards the top of the gallery, are having in hearing words on quieter question time days, let alone on rowdier question time days. I am told that the acoustics, particularly in the back two rows, on the front section and the two side sections, are difficult. Mr Speaker, I am wondering whether you might look at this, because if people are good enough to come to the gallery they should at least be able to hear the proceedings from the floor of the House.

—I know that this is a problem which from time to time members do raise. We will have another look at it. It may in fact go to things like ministers talking to the chair and also using the microphones in that respect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Mrs B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Do you claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do indeed.
—Please proceed.

—During question time today, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) was given the task of furthering the misrepresentation in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald relating to a talkback radio session that I did in Queensland last week. It related to a question that I was asked about the Child Support Agency. I would like to correct the impression that somehow I was opposed to a safety net being in place. I am not, let me make it clear. What the Sydney Morning Herald and the minister did today was to totally take the quote out of context.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member will show where she has been personally misrepresented. Those on my right are not helping.
—I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say there has been a good deal of complaint and concern about the way in which the tax office operates the Child Support Agency.
There is then the quote which the minister has apparently taken from the paper. I then went on to say:

I think we again have to look at the importance of family life, of what happens to children when there is a break up, and I am acutely aware of the inefficiencies of the administration of the tax office and the program as it is administered. Our aim is to, in a more simplified way—

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the member has shown where she has been misrepresented and by showing that quote.
—The important thing is that I was talking about the inefficiency—
—You are debating the issue. Resume your seat.
—No, Mr Speaker—
—No, you are. Resume your seat.
—I said particularly that this function will ensure the payment is made for children who need the maintenance.
—Resume your seat.
—I seek leave to table the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter of privilege and contempt and I ask that it be referred urgently to the Privileges Committee for investigation. I cite as justification for this request section 4 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 which is listed on page 954 of House of Representatives Practice which says in part that contempt is recognised if conduct constitutes an improper interference with the free performance by a member of the member's duties as a member.

PARA.TAB: I also recommend, when you consider this request, that you review the Coleman case which is listed on page 706 of House of Representatives Practice and the advice about the obstruction of officers of the House in the execution of their duty or other people employed by the House, or entrusted with the execution of its orders, or the molestation of those people on account of their having carried out their duties, constitutes contempt.

The matter of concern is that thousands of Australians, particularly in Western Australia but quite possibly Australia-wide, have been and quite possibly continue to be denied telephone access and possibly access by correspondence to many federal MPs and possibly therefore to government agencies and departments.

I am also concerned that some MPs belonging to the Labor Party have been and possibly will be prevented and impeded from performing their duties as elected representatives of the people and, tragically, may also be acquiescing in all of this contempt. I raise as support of my request an article in the West Australian, written by Mr Randal Markey and published on Saturday, 7 October. I refer you to the article. I will not read it out but I will quote it in small part:

SPEECH.PARA: The Community and Public Sector Union, which represents staff in MPs' offices, has accused Assistant Treasurer George Gear of failing to comply with work bans over a pay dispute.
The article went on to say:

PARA.TAB: "No other electorate office in WA (including those of Ministers) is failing to follow these bans.
"I would urge you to support our action as your other WA Federal colleagues are."

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Gear said that it was not helping him hang on to his seat of Canning, which he holds by only 240 votes. He also said he did not tell his office staff what to do. The article continued:
WA Labor Senator Jim McKiernan said the bans were frustrating and would be counter-productive in trying to address the Government's loss of support among blue-collar workers.

I also submit a fax message sent to my office from a staffer of the President of the Senate. On receipt of this fax the staff in my electorate office expressed anger and the feeling of having been intimidated by it, or at least the threat of intimidation. The fax read:
To all SCABS, We are fighting for all Electorate Staff so why don't you help us to succeed for you as well. Please support us.

The contact number was in fact the President of the Senate's office. The action taken by the union and some staff members of ALP federal members amounts to a breach of privilege and contempt and should not be permitted to continue or happen again. For some time the offices of the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley), the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) and the honourable member for Brand (Ms Fatin), plus the offices of Senators Beahan, Cook and Evans and others, have had answering machines advising of no immediate contact being available due to industrial disputation. I am advised that even today this practice continues in some offices.

PARA.TAB: To cut off access and deny the people their right of access to their elected federal member for assistance on important and urgent matters and other issues is outrageous and scandalous and should be stopped. Furthermore, the action of the minister, the member for Canning, in seemingly acquiescing in this virtual thuggery and saying `he did not tell his office staff what to do' is a frightening admission by a minister of the Crown. The concept that ordinary Australians, battlers, can be cut off from making contact with their member of parliament to seek redress and advice is outrageous and is a startling admission that a federal member of parliament's work is and can be impeded by a union.

Mr Speaker, whilst not denying anyone the opportunity to withdraw their labour if appropriate or denying a much justified pay increase for our overworked staff, I ask that you consider the matter in light of section 4 of the act and refer the matter to the Privileges Committee. I seek leave to table copies of the article and the fax.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will look at the issue that the honourable member has raised.
