INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Anderson) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The failure of the government to provide job security and improving living standards for regional Australians.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a government that has become very long indeed on rhetoric about things like social justice, regional development, boosting exports, even retaining the family farm. We hear about how that is important for economic and social reasons now from none other than the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). But there is in fact a huge gulf between rhetoric and reality. As, in the broader context in Australia, the rich get richer and the poor become more numerous, the same is happening in rural Australia. Many of those more numerous poor are rural Australians, our wealth creators, those who provide the overwhelming base for our export performance, and those who, in these increasingly environmentally conscious times, ought to be seen and recognised as the custodians of our natural resource base.

PARA.TAB: Yet, thanks to the government, thanks to that policy drift, their inertia, their reform fatigue, what we really see, despite the rhetoric, in rural and regional Australia is increasing dislocation, increasing poverty, increasing loss of job opportunities, and nowhere do we see these problems more evident than amongst young people in the country.We see anecdotal and real evidence of young men leaving the bush in droves and young women leaving even faster. Tragically, it is often the most talented people with the most to offer for the future, the people who will be most needed in the future in rural Australia, who are leaving.

My electorate is no exception. We have noted something of a contraction in the size of the work force in Gwydir since the recession set in over the last couple of years of some 4,500 people—many of them young people, many of them skilled, many of them people who will be needed when things turn around. This is despite the fact that two of Australia's wealthiest agricultural shires are in my electorate—Narrabri and Gunnedah. In the case of Moree, this is reflected in the town by the unbelievable number of vacant homes that are on the market—no purchaser available. In Gunnedah, a couple of hundred homes in what is not a very big town do not even have the power turned on any more.

There has been an explosion of farm debt, but the government over the past 13 years has refused to do anything about arresting that decline in our rural fortunes. This has had a significant impact on job opportunities and returns for efforts made in rural Australia. We have seen farm debt go from $7 billion when this mob came to power to $17 1/2 billion today. Again, the young are unduly affected. They are giving up hope and questioning their role in the so-called lucky country.

Today we heard some statistics from our spokesman in this area about the unemployment of youth; that is, those from 15 to 20 years old. The national youth unemployment rate is 28 per cent. That is a disgrace. Look at what is happening in country regions. I understand that in one district of the Mallee area the youth unemployment rate is about 66 per cent. Two-thirds of the young people in that area do not have a job. The Wide Bay-Burnett region has a youth unemployment rate of 41 1/2 per cent. The central west of New South Wales has a youth unemployment rate of 32 per cent. In central Queensland that figure is nearly 40 per cent.

Those figures probably disguise the reality. It is probably worse in many of those areas but it is covered up by various programs which are designed to disguise the full extent of the real problem and to train people for jobs that tragically will often not be there. Why will they not be there? Because the government is severely inflicted with reform fatigue. Murdoch was spot on when he said that Australia's economy is a disgrace. Didn't he stir up a hornet's nest when he talked about youth unemployment? We saw a mad scramble from those opposite trying to discredit what he had to say. It is very interesting.

The people in the bush are losing hope. There is a loss of belief by country people, our wealth creators, in their future just when the experts are now widely beginning to talk about a bright future. A little while ago, Graham Blight made reference here in Canberra to that fact. Graham Blight is well known and well respected in this place. He predicted that agriculture would be back at the forefront of governments' agendas in coming years for very good reason. He pointed to the fact that by the year 2025, when I will be 68—it is not so far away, in 30 years time—the world will need another 300 million tonnes of wheat a year just to feed itself, another 260 million tonnes of corn, another 210 million tonnes of rice and another 16 million tonnes of fish. Imagine the fibre that we will need to clothe people and the material that we will need to put roofs over our heads globally. Let us put all that into perspective: the biggest crop that Australia, as the world's second biggest exporter of wheat, ever grew was just 22 million tonnes in 1982-83. We will have to find another 300 million tonnes in 30 years time.

What are we doing about this problem? There is policy paralysis, drift, a loss of hope and a loss of direction. We are giving away our best talent—the bush—at the very time when we ought to be giving it positive direction and confidence and when we should be telling people that there is a future, because there is. But what are we doing? We are seeing the government destroy the heartland of Australia.

It is not just Labor in this place that is destroying our heartland. Their cohorts in Queensland and New South Wales are also contributing to the problem. There is an appalling lack of consultation on matters such as SEPP46, the state environmental planning policy. There is no consultation with the people at the coalface, the people who actually have stewardship over the environment. They just say, `Here's what you'll do. Here's how you'll do it. We'll control you. We won't give you the freedom to go out and act in the best long-term interests of either your industry or the people who will follow you in it.'

Then we come to forestry. What an absolute debacle, what an absolute mess, we have seen from those opposite. Investment is drying up, and there is one indication of that. We hear all their talk about growing a bigger timber and paper products industry. Whilst they talk about it here, it actually happens in New Zealand. They will establish 100,000 hectares of softwood plantation this year. In Australia it is estimated that 8,000 hectares will be established. Some 100,000 hectares will be established there while 8,000 hectares will be established here.

What is the difference in the job opportunities? What is the opportunity for value adding wood and timber paper products in this country? Unlimited. This year, 40 per cent of the timber and paper product needs of New South Wales alone will be imported—across the nation, it is $3 billion worth—and that figure is growing rapidly. How much investment is on hold because of the uncertainty? Around $2 billion worth in value adding of our product.

What is the government doing about it? Well, it is slashed across the papers every morning, isn't it: total and absolute chaos. When we ought to be talking about more opportunities, more jobs, more plantations and more timber, what are we doing? We are shutting the thing down to the huge disadvantage—again, let me emphasise this—not just of country people and young people in the bush but of the nation's economic performance. In case you had not noticed—and here is one of the ministers who is very good on spending money—we have to generate wealth in this country if we are to then distribute it. And here we are again undermining the people who need to be encouraged to invest, to employ people and to produce a bigger cake so that there is more to go around for everyone.

I now turn to the issue of competitiveness. The tyranny of distance is a great problem. I have to touch on this. I cannot resist it as my opposite number over there keeps talking about how he has reformed Australia's waterfront. A recent study was carried out of 46 ports around the world. Although we have spent $400 million since 1989, the beginning of the government's reform program, what has actually happened? Sydney has slipped from 24th to 31st and Melbourne has gone from 28th to 37th in terms of world competitiveness. Did you hear the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) guffaw when I accused the government of having reform fatigue? Did you hear it? It is wonderful, isn't it?

I cannot help but mention something we ought to be very proud of in this country: we are the world's No. 1 exporter of beef product. But you know what? Such is your reform fatigue that we are no longer competitive at home. The first rule of being an effective trading nation in any given commodity is to make sure that you are competitive at home. But what do we find in the case of the beef industry? We are not competitive at home. So how are we ever going to make it? We have got American and New Zealand product on our shelves. How are we ever going to make it in the important Asian markets to our north if we cannot do our best here?

The fact of the matter is that the industry is on its knees at the moment and, with it, the wellbeing of thousands of producers. And here is the rub for you blokes: so are tens of thousands of Australian workers. We have had report after report and study after study which have clearly indicated that we are grossly underperforming to such an extent that the only reason we are competitive on world markets at all is that our beef producers receive as little as half of what their opposite numbers in New Zealand and America get. For years the government has ignored time and again the problem—although the government did decide a couple of years ago that they would have their own industry commission look at this whole issue again.

What the commission had to say was really very interesting. The first thing it said was that we are competitive only because of the low prices paid to Australian producers. It went on to say a few other things that members opposite might be interested in. One is that change has been painfully slow and that greater industrial relations flexibility and productivity are the key to the industry's future. But here is the bit that is really interesting:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission has found that greater flexibility, particularly greater use of enterprise agreements, could bring about significant productivity gains with benefits for . . .

Who would you expect would get the benefits? Farmers? The nation? Do you know who the commission nominated first? The workers of this country. The first who would benefit are the workers—then the producers, the processors and, after that, some consumers, as the commission put it.

PARA.TAB: It is reported in another place that, if we could pick up the hundreds of billions of dollars that are out there to be gained by some improved performance, the benefit to workers would be about 25 per cent of that better return. What did the government do with all this? It sat on it for 14 months. There were 23 major recommendations, and the government picked up one, basically.

After 14 months the government introduced some legislation into the second chamber in this place. This is Australia's major agricultural export industry, except when wool overtakes it occasionally. How importantly did the government regard the reform process? Perhaps it is reflected in the fact they picked up just one of 23 recommendations and introduced it on a day when the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) was not even in Australia. It was appropriate that he was in America on that day. That is fine, but the government had 14 months in which to choose a day when the minister would be here to introduce it. But, no, they did not, and so it goes on and on.

When we raised enterprise bargaining with them, which they claimed had basically been put in place in the industry—you heard it again from the minister here—he said, `That's fixed it all up. We don't need to address the other areas here.' And it just so happened that on that day something had fallen off the back of a truck: an independent report on the Department of Primary Industries and Energy which said:

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to this industry—
and this is a matter of only weeks old even now—

with some exceptions, progress has generally been limited, with little to show in terms of widespread and quantifiable increases in productivity and efficiency. The [general nature of] enterprise bargains achieved to date have not been particularly innovative or successful in encouraging improvements . . . In many cases, they have been little more than a means to achieve a general wage increase.

So there you go—abysmal failure in one of Australia's most important regional industries and most important export industries. Confronted with the evidence from his independent report, Senator Collins over in the other place—and this is very interesting; this is just two weeks ago—went on to say:
. . . AMH is engaged right now in its abattoirs at Rockhampton in an exercise to do just that—
improve work practices—
in cooperation with the unions and under the supervision of the Industry Commission.

I think he meant the Industrial Relations Commission. That is really very interesting. For years and years they can ignore the reform process at the cost of workers, at the cost of the industry and at the possible demise now of the industry; but in the space of two weeks they can act when a complaint comes in from the other side. I reckon that is an enormous vote of no confidence in your system in general and an enormous vote of no confidence in the commission in particular, because they were meant to be overseeing this. In short, the whole process is nothing short of a national disgrace. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —Since I have been a minister in this government every MPI from the opposition I have debated has been based on a false premise. Today's MPI is no exception. Not only is today's MPI based on a false premise but also there has been an array of falsehoods asserted in the speech we have just heard. I intend to return to a few of those towards the end of my speech.

PARA.TAB: The MPI refers to the question of job security. It is the case that this country has had one of the most rapid rates of job growth in the entire OECD over a period of several years. In the year to the three months to July—in other words, the most recent quarter for which statistics are available from the Department of Employment, Education and Training—employment growth in Australia as a whole was 4.4 per cent. This represented 347,000 new jobs in Australia as a whole.

The implication of the MPI is that rural and regional Australia has missed out on its fair share of that employment growth. What are the facts? The facts are that employment growth in non-metropolitan Australia was much stronger than the average. In fact, in the non-metropolitan area employment growth totalled no less than 6.2 per cent over that period, which is almost twice as great as the 3.4 per cent job growth recorded in metropolitan Australia. That is the first point: rural and regional Australia have shared very substantially in the exceptionally strong job growth that has gone on.

Of the 347,000 jobs created in Australia in the course of that year, 170,000 of them—that is, almost half—were in non-metropolitan areas. Indeed in all states, except Victoria and Western Australia—and it is interesting to note that the opposition spokesman and Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), somehow tried to blame Labor state governments for the poor performance—more than 50 per cent of the job growth was outside the capital city. Guess which political parties are in office in those two states!

Furthermore, this is not a short-term trend. It is a trend that has been occurring throughout our term of office. It is true that there is considerable variation in unemployment across regional Australia, just as there is considerable variation in unemployment across metropolitan Australia. The Deputy Leader of the National Party's own region, which is north and central west New South Wales, has a rate of 6.6 per cent, which is well below the national average of more than eight per cent. In the Murray-Murrumbidgee area of New South Wales unemployment was as low as 4.4 per cent. The highest level of unemployment in Australia is not in non-metropolitan Australia, it is in western Melbourne.

Of course what matters about unemployment is the policies to reduce it. We are reducing unemployment. Unemployment has fallen in almost all the regions of non-metropolitan Australia. We gave the economy a fiscal kick-start, which the opposition opposed, from the recession. We are maintaining an accord which has provided a framework that has facilitated strong employment growth. The opposition has opposed that. We have introduced the job compact to provide a fundamental structural change in the labour market in favour of job growth, and particularly job growth opportunities for the disadvantaged in the labour market. The opposition has opposed that.

The fact is that the MPI today is from the political party that believes people who live in regional Australia are not part of a broader Australian nation. The National Party has always pretended that somehow regional Australians do not have the same interests as other Australians, which is a nonsense. Moreover, the National Party has always believed that the only people of worth in regional Australia are primary producers and other small business operators. They want to pretend that the indigenous population does not exist, that the social security recipients in regional Australia do not exist and that wage and salary earners in regional Australia do not exist.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't publish the regional figures.

—The fact is that what this government has done to enhance Australians' living standards is every bit as relevant to regional Australia as it is to metropolitan Australia—if anything, more so. It is interesting that the member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) raises this issue about the youth unemployment statistics. The speech we have just heard from the National Party spokesman is a clear illustration of the way in which those youth unemployment statistics are abused. He said that in certain regions two-thirds of young people in that age group are out of work. The statistics do not show any such thing and you know that.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that, as a result of this government's efforts, participation rates in secondary-tertiary education have increased out of sight. The fact is that most people in the 15- to 19-year-old age group are not in the labour market; they are in the education and training system, as they should be. The figures quoted are of those who remain in the labour market, who are a distinct minority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not to be worried about.

—No, nobody is suggesting that for a minute. But what we are saying is that you have to interpret these statistics correctly. What we are talking about is that, in the 15- to 19-year-old age group, around about nine per cent—obviously far too high still, and nobody disputes that for a minute—are out of work, actively seeking work. All these figures you quote fail to take into account that basic point: in interpreting these statistics, the great bulk of young people are appropriately in the education and training system.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that what this government has done to enhance Australians' living standards is every bit as relevant to regional Australia as it is to metropolitan Australia—if anything, more so. The government's economic policies have centred on making Australia a more competitive nation. Which industries are the beneficiaries of that? The most competitive ones, of course, which are mining, agriculture, downstream processing and tourism, among others. Where are they primarily located? In regional Australia. The government's social policies have ensured that the benefits of the economic growth generated by these economic policies have been equitably distributed. Doesn't regional Australia benefit from that?

TALK.START.PARA: —They haven't; that's the point.

—I just made the point that, if anything, in terms of employment growth, regional Australia has done substantially better in proportionate terms than metropolitan Australia. Don't the pensioners in regional Australia benefit from the 12 per cent real increase in the value of the pension when measured against the consumer price index? Of course they do. I have not had time to check the figures, but I imagine that pensioners are over-represented in non-metropolitan Australia, given the relative attractiveness of the non-metropolitan lifestyle to many older people. That means that our policies of increased adequacy and financial security for pensioners benefit regional Australia more widely. Don't the low income families in regional Australia benefit from the approximate doubling in the real value of additional family payments and their extension to low income working families under this government or the introduction of parenting allowance this year? Of course they do.

PARA.TAB: Self-employed and small business families earning low incomes are eligible for these payments. But you never hear the National Party talking about that. Won't the mothers in regional Australia benefit from the maternity allowance to be introduced next February? Of course they will. Don't families in regional Australia benefit from Medicare? Of course they do. Don't families in regional Australia benefit from expanded child-care assistance; won't they benefit in retirement from expanded superannuation provisions; don't families in regional Australia benefit from expanded education participation? Of course they do.

If I recall some data from my previous portfolio accurately, education participation has increased more rapidly for those from regional Australia. In education, as in employment, a disproportionate—if anything—share of benefits have gone to regional Australia. For example, I recall introducing a higher education equity strategy in my previous portfolio, one which explicitly focused on raising participation rates of people from regional Australia.

You have to take all these things into account if you are going to talk about living standards. This is as true of non-metropolitan Australia as it is true of metropolitan Australia. Of course most of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission's $930 million in this year's budget goes to non-metropolitan Australia. But the National Party never welcomes that.

The fact is that this government governs for all Australians. I know that it is a matter of great embarrassment to the National Party that we hold more seats in regional Australia than it holds. The very foundation of the Australian Labor Party straddles both regional Australia, most famously, Barcaldine in Queensland, and metropolitan Australia, particularly Balmain in my own electorate. We remain the largest political party in non-metropolitan Australia. That is because we regard Australia as one nation.

Compare this with the opposition, who talk a lot about inequality but whose only policy is wage flexibility—which we know is code for wage cuts. We know that this means: accept the contract or get the sack. Who does this threaten most? People who have nowhere else to go. Workers in non-metropolitan Australia are the most vulnerable to these policies.

But we do recognise that regional Australia has particular needs and particular circumstances. My own department, the Department of Social Security, for example, has a comprehensive access and equity strategy in place to ensure that all Australians who are entitled to social security payments do in fact receive them, regardless of where they live.

We now have 216 regional offices of the Department of Social Security around Australia, 66 smaller offices mostly in regional areas, and nearly 400 visiting services, to ensure that people in small towns can access the department. Teleservice centres mean that the department is contactable by telephone from anywhere in Australia for the cost of a local call. We have a network of field officers and community agents particularly servicing Aboriginal Australians.

Most recently, of course, we have introduced the drought relief payment. Some 10,400 farm families experiencing exceptional drought circumstances are receiving this payment. It has paid jobsearch allowance rates but does not have an activity test requirement, and the value of the farm asset is exempt from the income test.

The National Party do not quote the drought relief payment because it is something they would never had the wit or the wisdom to introduce. This is because it is targeted on those most in need: farmers earning no income or, for that matter, making large losses. The National Party has never been in favour of that. Unlike National Party drought policies it is a cash transfer and so does not provide windfall gains to particular people or distort the pattern of rural prices and production. It is an efficient targeted instrument for helping those in most desperate need.

An amount of $82 million was provided to these farmers last financial year. A further $36 million was provided in the first two months of this financial year. This will continue for as long as it is needed for up to six months after the drought declarations are lifted. It is part of a broader drought strategy, expected to cost some $770 million over four years. This is the sort of thing that we are doing for the people for whom you say we have no concern.

But government policies for regional Australia do not stop there. In particular, Working Nation allocated $150 million over four years to the regional economic development program. Just to take one example from many, it was this government that provided non-metropolitan Australians with the same choice of television broadcasting channels as exists in the capital cities.

The fact is that the Labor government is interested in developing regional Australia. We are interested in economic development, we are interested in social development and we are interested in ecologically sustainable development. The National Party is interested only in feeding prejudices for the purpose of winning votes.

I would just make this point: of course, the premise of this MPI is false. Early in the debate, among the many falsehoods in his speech, the National Party spokesman made this assertion: the poor have got poorer and have become more numerous under this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly more numerous in the bush.
—These are both demonstrably false propositions which it has traipsed out.

PARA.TAB: Most of these assessments are done on an analyses which are based on the so-called Henderson poverty line, of which Ann Harding, whose paper was quoted the other day, is a strong critic. The fact is that the Henderson poverty line since 1983 has risen 21 per cent in real terms—that is to say, in excess of the inflation rate. It has not stayed static. Ann Harding, in the paper that was quoted earlier, acknowledges that this has the effect of inflating the numbers in poverty.

In the United States they have a poverty line which is indexed to prices; in other words, it stays constant in real terms. In contrast to the United States, which has shown an increase in poverty, with a poverty line increased just to maintain it in real terms, if you do that exercise here under this government, you show a substantial decline of the order of around about 30 per cent in the numbers shown to be in poverty.

These poverty statistics and these international statistics have to take account of the different conventions and the different methodologies employed in different countries. On any realistic or reasonable assessment, this government has improved substantially the circumstances of people in this country who are the worst off. This is not just people dependent totally on social security payments; this is low wage work working families.

If you convert the introduction of additional family payment for low wage working families, which is a measure that this government introduced, taking into account that that is a tax free payment, and consider what the gross wage equivalent of that would be for a family with two children, for example, it is the equivalent of a gross wage increase of $125 a week. That is the sort of thing that this government has done for low income Australians in both the metropolitan areas and the regional areas of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I was disappointed by the monologue of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin), which amounted, really, to a pious justification, or an attempt at justification, of the rather dreadful situation in this country. The minister seemed to operate on the basis that, if you repeat an untruth often enough, some people will ultimately believe it.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy Speaker, listen to these words:

SPEECH.PARA: Its struggle has always been on behalf of the weak, against the strong for the poor, for those who have never had a chance as against those whose privileged positions have enabled them to prosper even though millions suffer.

Whose words were they? They were the words of Prime Minister Curtin, from his policy speech on 28 August 1940. The Labor Party has forgotten those words because in the 1995 of today many millions of Australians continue to suffer.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday was the International Day of Poverty. Of course, that gave us the opportunity in this country to highlight our very real poverty problem right here in our own backyard. The government, and the minister in particular, should hang their heads in shame on their appalling track record in increasing inequality between rich and poor over the last decade. Real wages have fallen in the last 12 years; the cost of a mortgage has increased by 50 per cent; and unemployment remains at a record high, with youth unemployment running at least at 28 per cent—and, indeed, very much higher in many other specific parts of the country. Prime Minister Hawke in his policy speech in 1987 said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . by 1990, no Australian child need live in poverty . . .
What a sick joke to be perpetrated at the expense of the Australian people.

PARA.TAB: This government—former Prime Ministers, current ministers and current members—are prepared to say absolutely anything at election time in an endeavour to crawl back into government. It has been estimated that 1.9 million Australians, or 11 per cent of our entire population, are currently in poverty, and 592,000 of them are children aged up to 14 years. Prime Minister Hawke said in 1987 that no child need be in poverty by 1990. Yet here we are in 1995, five years later, and we have almost 600,000 Australian children up to the age of 14 years in poverty. My own home state of Queensland is the most poverty-stricken state in Australia, with 350,000 people living in poverty.

It is interesting to note also that coalition members—members of the Liberal and National parties—represent the poorest electorates in Australia. My electorate of Fisher is one of the poorest electorates in Australia. The minister has come into this place and has read out a whole set of statistics with a view to mislead us, with a view to persuade us that the situation is other than the reality which we face every day of the year.

More than one-quarter of children and elderly people in Queensland live in poverty. Nearly one-quarter of young people under the age of 25 live in poverty. So much for this government which claims that it has been the government of the underprivileged. So much for this government which, in its 13 years in office, has simply masqueraded around as the champion of the underprivileged. What a con! This con will be exposed once and for all at the federal election, whenever it is held. Whether it is held on 9 December, as has been tipped, or whether it is held in February or March next year, the government's failures will be exposed once and for all.

The government claims to be interested in sole parents, but in Queensland two out of every three sole parents live below the poverty line. The average weekly disposable income is lower in Queensland than in any other place in the country. The national situation is also appalling. Since Labor came to office, the earning of the bottom 10 per cent of income earners has declined in real terms; yet the earnings of the highest 10 per cent of workers has increased by 17 per cent. We have repeated those figures in this place over and over again. The government has not come up with any satisfactory answer, and people are really seeing through this government as the fraud that it is.

The OECD surveyed some 12 countries and only three countries—Australia, the US and Canada—experienced a real decline in the earnings of the least well paid 10 per cent of workers in the last decade. Let us compare the situation here with the situation in the United Kingdom, where people in that group had increases of some 11 per cent. There has been a fall in real household incomes in 70 per cent of neighbourhoods and a real increase in income in only 30 per cent of neighbourhoods in Australia. The minister has the hide to say that things are better. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) says that things will never get better than they are at the moment. Put in plain English, recent research indicates that average household incomes in the bottom five per cent of neighbourhoods have fallen by more than $7,500 in real terms, while the top five per cent of neighbourhoods have increased their incomes by more than $12,000 on average.

The Prime Minister agrees now that the gap between the rich and the poor has widened, but he claims that the recession is over and that we are now in a brave new world. Does the Prime Minister—the person who likes the French clocks, the person who likes the Italian suits—have any compassion at all for people on the poverty line struggling to make ends meet; the people Prime Minister Curtin sought to support in 1940? The simple fact is that this government is a government which has lost contact with its origins. It is a government of the quick dollar; a government of the slick deal. It is no longer the government of the underprivileged, and traditional Labor people are deserting this government. In fact, 52 per cent of blue-collar workers have now deserted this government. That is a matter of concern for you, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, representing the electorate of Scullin, because 52 per cent of blue-collar workers will not have anything to do with this government—the government of big business and not the government of the little Australian.

The government has deserted Labor's traditions of equality and is adopting the view that the widening gap between the haves and the have-nots does not matter. The Keating government, of course, is wrong. It is most important that we have social cohesion and equality in this country. The coalition, upon election to office, will seek to ensure that the disparities which presently exist are reduced. It is obvious that Australians are not better off under this Labor government. The government always talks about the social wage, but the government's most heralded social wage or so-called safety net is ineffectual for many Aussie battlers.

Under Labor the education of children has taken a battering. In 1980, 48 per cent of students from lower income households who completed year 12 went on to higher education, but by 1989 the figure had fallen to 35 per cent. Do not be fooled by the government's false attempts to explain away these grim facts with the comments made by the minister. The government continues to fudge figures in the hope that it will continue to confuse the Australian people. I believe the government will stand condemned at the next election.

The Minister for Social Security claimed that the federal social wage is $1,774 for every Australian and that this has increased by more than $700 since 1983. This figure is arrived at by adding all federal spending on health, education, housing and child care and dividing that by the number in the population. Again, this is another clever play with figures.

It is obvious that, with the increase in the Australian population, the minister is misleading the Australian people. The simple fact of the matter is that this so-called federal social wage is not benefiting the people whom the government claims it is benefiting. It is also obvious that 40 per cent of the lowest income earners receive only 35 per cent of the social wage, while 40 per cent of the highest income earners receive 46 per cent of the social wage.

So we have a situation where the government has endeavoured to confuse the Australian people yet again. Don Russell, the current Australian Ambassador to the United States, has said that he wants to come back here to ensure we do not create in Australia the kind of underclass they currently have in the United States. Everyone agrees that the ambassador's comments are totally out of order for a diplomatic representative of Australia, but the simple fact of the matter is that we already have the working poor in Australia. One has to go no further than today's Australian to read about this. It cites the case of someone working on a single wage and actually earning $200 less than he would be earning if he was receiving the dole. That is a matter that should appal every reasonable Australian.

This government has failed to provide job security. We have heard the statistics about youth unemployment in regional areas. The minister has endeavoured to hide the real facts by confusing the matter of training and education with unemployment and in doing so hopes the terrible statistics will somehow be improved.

The people of Australia will not be fooled by that any more than they have been fooled by so many other comments of the minister. I believe that, if one looked at the principles that the Labor Party has historically stood for and one looked at the inequality in this nation at the moment, one would see that this Labor Party is no longer the Labor Party of the underprivileged and no longer the Labor Party of the battler. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be here this afternoon to contribute to this debate because—
—You are on your own now.

—You want to leave because you do not want to hear what I have to say. I have never heard such blarney as I did in the contributions of the member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) and the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper). They made extraordinary claims which bear no relation to what is going on in this community.

PARA.TAB: I will just talk about the policy sclerosis which struck the Liberal and National parties when in government before 1983. Which government had the gumption to reform many of the primary industries which these National Party members supposedly represent? Was it the Liberal Party and National Party coalition? Not on your nelly. Was it the Labor Party? It was.

What are some of the industries in the primary sector that have been addressed by the Labor Party? They include the wool industry, the dairy industry, the meat industry, the sugar industry and the horticultural industry—including fruit, vegetables, vineyards and tobacco, just to name a few—plus we have created an aquaculture industry. We do not get any credit for that from the opposition.

I heard a spokesman for the dairy industry on Good Morning Australia recently. He said that, whilst a lot of people have gone out of the dairy industry because of the industry's restructuring, its productivity has increased tremendously. I forget the exact figures, but the spokesman said that the industry now has less than half the number of producers, yet they are producing five or 10 per cent more dairy products. Is that a successful policy drive by this government? This industry has become more competitive, by its own admission. Who has achieved this? The Labor government—not the coalition.

Which government had the wit and wisdom to introduce a national landcare program? Was it the coalition when they were in office? No, it was the Labor Party in office. How many Landcare groups are there around Australia currently? There are 2,200 active Landcare groups. How much money per annum is being spent on these Landcare groups, which are supported by primary producers throughout Australia? It is $150 million. Was that an initiative of the coalition when they were in government? Did they seek to reform the way in which people treat the land in this country? Did they look at sustainable economic development in a proper sense? Did they look at micro-economic reform when they were in government? No, they did not. They suffered from the same policy sclerosis that they are suffering from now.

A number of statistics have been bandied around here this afternoon, some of which relate to unemployment. But I want to go to some figures referred to by the member for Fisher. He talked about household disposal income. Let me make it very clear for all to understand: full-time adult average weekly earnings have increased by 7.2 per cent between June 1983 and June 1995; real household disposal income has increased over that same period by 41.8 per cent; and real household disposal income per capita has increased by 20.9 per cent, almost 21 per cent.

We are getting this tirade from the opposition about Australians being worse off as a result of the actions of the Labor government. In fact, they are measurably better off as a result of the deliberate policy determinations made by this government. I will go to some other facts which have implications for what is being said.

The previous speaker, the member for Fisher, talked about the social wage. Let's make it very clear: the social wage includes expenditure on health, education, housing and child care. Under a coalition government, of which the present Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, was Treasurer, between 1970-78 and 1982-83 the change in the real value of the Commonwealth social wage per person was a reduction of 17.5 per cent. That is, there was a 17.5 per cent fall in the social wage under the previous coalition government.

Since Labor has been in power, since 1982-83, the social wage has gone up by 73 per cent. Yet the opposition still has the gall—with the National Party supposedly representing regional Australia—to come in here and expect us to believe the nonsense they are perpetrating, that somehow or other Australians are worse off under Labor. Nothing could be further from the truth.

I make the point that the National Party and, indeed, the Liberal Party purport to represent the interests of business. One other area which has been reformed under Labor is the tax system. Let us just have a look at a couple of figures which demonstrate yet again why Australians, wherever they are—rural, regional or metropolitan Australia—are measurably better off under Labor than they have ever been, certainly a lot better off than they were under the previous coalition government, and a lot better off than they will ever be under a government administered by the opposition.

One interesting figure is the amount of money the government spends for its own purposes. Government revenue as a proportion of GDP under the Howard government in 1982-83 was 26 per cent. Under the current government that figure is 25.3 per cent. We are spending less of our income as a proportion of GDP. Government outlays as a percentage of GDP when Mr Howard was the Treasurer were 28.6 per cent. Under this government, this year, they are 25.1 per cent. That is just another example.

One of the interesting issues in relation to the ability of business to get on, to do its job and be competitive, and to families surviving, is income tax. What is the comparison between the rate of income tax under the opposition when it was in power and the rate of income tax now being experienced by Australians wherever they might live? Top marginal tax rates under Mr Howard were 60 per cent. They are now 47 per cent. The bottom marginal tax rate under Mr Howard was 30 per cent. It is now 20 per cent. The company tax rate under Mr Howard was 46 per cent. Under this government it is 36 per cent.

What other points of comparison do we need to demonstrate how measurably better off Australians are, wherever they might be, than they were under a Howard coalition. And how much better off are they than they would have been had, God forgive us, the coalition been in government during the 1980s and early 1990s.

We have heard these arguments about regional economic development. The point that was made, properly, by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) was that the employment rate has grown faster in non-metropolitan Australia than in metropolitan Australia. I will give you a few examples, Mr Deputy Speaker, of unemployment in areas represented by National Party members.

The leader of the debate for the opposition this afternoon was the member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson). In June 1994, unemployment in the DEET region of Moree, which is in Gwydir, was 12.9 per cent. In June of 1995, the figure was 8.9 per cent, a reduction of four per cent in that member's electorate

In Taree, in the electorate of the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), the unemployment rate in June of 1994 was 15.3 per cent. It has dropped by 5.2 per cent in the last 12 months. We saw the member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) in here this afternoon. In his electorate, the unemployment rate in June 1994 was 14.4 per cent. The unemployment rate in June 1995 was 7.9 per cent, a fall of 6.5 per cent.

These are the people who are trying to tell us that, somehow or other, people in the bush, in regional Australia, are worse off under a Labor government and that things are getting worse. Things are getting measurably better. Indeed, the policies of the government have been supported by our opponents. Members of the National Party have given high praise to the regional economic initiatives put in place by this government, especially in relation to employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —And so they should.

—Of course they should. It is worth pointing out that one of the most significant initiatives undertaken by the Department of Employment, Education and Training has been the development of area consultative committees, which represent combined industry, union, community and government partnerships to deal with local employment and training issues.

PARA.TAB: National Party members have given high praise to these initiatives. They have said to the government, `We want you to do more in our electorates because what you are doing is good for our electorates and good for regional Australia.' Yet the opposition, this afternoon in this House, are trying to argue that somehow or other Australians are worse off in regional Australia than they ought to be or than they would be under a coalition government. Nothing could be further from the truth.

That is clearly and amply demonstrated by the statistics which are available for all to see in public documents—absolutely distorted in the way the opposition have spoken about them. Those statistics clearly demonstrate that the argument put by the opposition in this matter of public importance this afternoon is completely fallacious. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In introducing the government's amendments to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) really gave the game away when attempting to justify them. This is a government which has made a deal at the expense of students. The government and the universities appear to have agreed that there will be additional places if today's students cough up the money.

PARA.TAB: I do not need to remind the House that this government constantly tells us that it is opposed to up-front fees for Australian undergraduate students. This is the government that introduced the HECS scheme and has relentlessly boosted the level of HECS. This is the third time the government has proposed to increase the rate of HECS repayments.

This government, despite the minister's disclaimers in his speech, has winked for a long time at the indisputable fact that Australian undergraduates are being charged up-front fees through the back door. Australian undergraduates are paying for courses not for credit, and when they pass those courses are being credited for them. It is a way of enabling them to get into the system. The government claims that it is unable to establish the validity of these claims. If that is so, then its information sources about the higher education system are very poor.

The coalition has no objection to the particular amendments which have been put forward. They were foreshadowed in the second reading speech—they were not clearly foreshadowed as amendments, I might say—which introduced the bill. The point was foreshadowed and we do not object to that. What we do object to is the hypocrisy of this government in saying that it is unable to fund these additional places unless the students themselves cough up the money. That is blackmail against today's students. It is totally unjustified.

When the Senate decides, as I believe it will, to support the coalition's amendments to this legislation, I challenge the minister to make it clear that the government places so little weight on access to the university system that it is prepared to take places away from Victoria and South Australia. If the government does that and decides that it will cut places out of the system, that will not be a result of the decisions of the coalition. It will not be a result of the decisions of the Senate. It will flow directly from the government's own priorities.

What is clear is that these places are the lowest possible priority of the government. The minister feels free to spend tens of millions of dollars out of the national priorities reserve scheme, which is really the ministerial slush fund, yet he threatens students with the loss of places. This is contemptible. It will be noted by students around Australia and I have no doubt that it will be resolutely and absolutely rejected by them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad there are so many members of the government in here to hear me speak about taxation. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), which was introduced in this place on 29 June of this year, makes a range of amendments including changes affecting foreign controlled companies; changes affecting dividends paid out of capital accounts, which were announced in this year's budget; extending the accelerated depreciation of ships to 30 June 2002; a number of changes to the collection of tax; reducing the twice monthly remitter threshold from $5 million to $1 million as announced in this year's budget; increasing the infrastructure borrowings rebate to 36 per cent in line with the company tax rate; and changes to the superannuation guarantee system allowing employees to elect that employers do not make superannuation guarantee contributions and by allowing the notional earnings base to be used to calculate superannuation contributions.

PARA.TAB: There are three aspects of this bill in particular which I wish to address today. The first one relates to the part of the bill dealing with foreign income and in particular with tainted income. The Australian controllers of a controlled foreign company are not taxed on that part of the controlled foreign company's tainted income—that is, income including passive and certain other business income which is less than five per cent of its total income which passes the active income test. The commissioner may make adjustments reflecting arms-length values when determining a controlled foreign company's attributable income but it has not been clear whether the adjustment affects the active income test. A lack of power to make adjustment to amounts used in determining the active income test may result in a CFC satisfying the test where it should have failed.

This bill seeks to clarify that where CFCs have entered non-arms-length transactions with related parties the commissioner is allowed to make adjustments reflecting arms-length values to determine whether a CFC has passed the active income test. Aspects of this particular part of the bill have been raised with the opposition, in particular by the Corporate Tax Association. We are aware from comments made through the Corporate Tax Association that there is more than one company group adversely affected and the legislation would have produced inequitable tax consequences if it had been enacted in the form of the bill.

Of particular concern is the aspect that the application of the amendment incorporated in the bill is to apply for statutory accounting periods ending after 30 June 1995. For a CFC with a statutory accounting period ending after that date, the amendment is therefore applicable as from the beginning of that particular statutory accounting period and therefore has retrospective application. I understand an amendment will be moved in relation to that matter and the opposition will be supporting that particular amendment.

The second aspect of the bill that I wish to turn to relates to dividends paid out of capital accounts. The current position is that all dividends received by resident public companies from resident companies and franked or grouped company dividends received by resident private companies from resident companies are free from tax as a result of the intercorporate dividend rebate. Certain distributions debited to a company's share capital or share premium account or asset revaluation reserve are characterised as dividends. The result is that these distributions qualify for the rebate and effectively give tax redistributions to corporate shareholders and pass on franking credits to shareholders ordinarily unable to access them.

The bill disqualifies dividends that are debited or paid from amounts transferred from, first, share capital accounts, secondly, share premium accounts or, thirdly, asset revaluation reserves from being rebatable or frankable dividends. Share premium accounts include share premium accounts tainted by the inclusion of amounts other than share premiums or amounts which cannot be identified as share premiums in the company's books and which do not therefore satisfy the section 6 definition of `share premium account'.

As a consequence of the introduction of the new measures, most of the rebatable dividend adjustment provisions in the legislation have become redundant and are being repealed. The amendments will apply to dividends paid after 7.30 p.m. on 9 May 1995 unless they were declared prior to that time. Dividends from amounts transferred before 9 May from a share capital or share premium account or asset revaluation reserve are not subject to the amendments nor are dividends paid under certain transitional arrangements.

These measures may have, we believe, some unintended consequences and the Insurance Council, in particular, has argued that the legislation could have the effect of preventing Australian companies from franking dividends paid from the ordinary retained earnings where movements occurred to and from the company's asset revaluation reserves as part of their ordinary business.

I understand that the government is proposing certain amendments in relation to this provision in particular. What the Insurance Council pointed out is that there is a serious technical deficiency in the current drafting of part of the bill in so far as it relates to rebatable and frankable dividends. The council believes that the legislation, as currently drafted prior to any amendment by the government, could have the effect of preventing Australian companies from franking dividends paid from ordinary retained earnings where movements occurred to and from the company's asset revaluation reserves as part of their ordinary business activity.

The impact of this legislation, if enacted in the form that has been presented, could be disastrous for many Australian companies and the anomaly is clearly something—which the Insurance Council, in particular, believes and we would concur with it—that was never intended at the time the proposals were announced in the federal budget on 9 May. I will not take the time of the House to go into the technical detail that has been raised by the Insurance Council of Australia, as I understand this is the subject of the amendments which will be moved in the committee stage on behalf of the government.

The third area which I wish to address in relation to this somewhat technical legislation relates to the notional earnings base of the superannuation guarantee charge. Currently, employers can use their pre-21 August 1991 employee earnings base if they continue to contribute to the same fund and under the same law award arrangement or schemes as for an employee for whom they were contributing immediately before 21 August 1991. If they restructure, they generally will have to contribute under the ordinary time earnings base.

The bill amends the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 to extend the use of pre-21 August 1991 employee earnings bases if employers restructure their superannuation funds. An employer will be allowed to keep pre-21 August 1991 earnings bases if the employer contributes under the same law award arrangement or scheme to, first, a new fund under the same earnings base as the original fund if employees transfer between the funds and receive substantially the same or improved rights to benefits; secondly, an existing fund in relation to an employee of a former employer who transfers to the fund from the former employer's fund because of a business acquisition if the base was used in the former employer's fund; or, thirdly, a former employers fund for employees who transfer to the new employer because of a business acquisition.

The amendments affect the calculation of the superannuation guarantee charge from 1 July 1995 where qualifying restructures occur after 28 June 1994. The effect is that employers reorganising funds after the announcement need not lose an existing employee earnings base for contributions made for contribution periods after 1 July 1995. Employers who restructured after the statement by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) on 28 June 1994, which was when this measure was announced, but before 1 July 1995 will have changed to the ordinary time earnings base from the time of restructure. On 1 July 1995 they will be able to revert to the pre-21 August 1991 earnings base to which they previously contributed. The amendment affects an employer's contributions only from 1 July 1995 so that contributions already made by employers during 1994-95 and contributions due for that year will not be reduced.

The Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia has raised a particular concern in relation to the notional earnings base. ASFA believes that the changes should be effective from the commencement of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 and should cover all employer and/or fund reconstructions irrespective of the date of those reconstructions.

The problem which ASFA points to refers to the definition of earnings base in the superannuation guarantee legislation in circumstances where there has been a reconstruction. Paragraph 3.3 of the Treasurer's discussion paper, issued on 4 December 1991, stated that the earnings base for superannuation guarantee contributions would be that set out in the governing rules of the scheme or in an award, provided that, firstly, the scheme was in existence on 20 August 1991 or, secondly, the scheme was not in existence on 20 August 1991 but is a successor to a scheme that was in existence on 20 August 1991 and the earnings base used is no narrower than that used by the original scheme.

When the superannuation guarantee legislation was enacted in 1992 no provision was made for these successor funds circumstances. The current bill seeks to address this situation, but only from 1 January 1995. I should indicate that in their representations ASFA is not seeking the retrospective operation of the amendments in order to allow employers to claim refunds from funds. If considered necessary, a provision to prescribe such claims could be included in the legislation.

My question in relation to this particular matter—the notional earnings base as it relates to the superannuation guarantee charge—is one which has been effectively raised: why shouldn't the changes be effective from the commencement of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act and cover all employer and/or fund reconstructions, irrespective of the date of those reconstructions? I hope that when the Treasurer or the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) come to speak again in this particular debate they could give some indication to the House and to the coalition regarding that particular matter because it does seem to be an anomaly in the way in which the provisions of this bill have been drafted.

Apart from those matters, there are a number of other technical and mechanical aspects of this bill which I will not detain the time of the House this evening by going into in great detail, but those three matters are matters on which the opposition, whilst it does not oppose the legislation, would seek some clarification. In relation to the first matter that I mentioned, we will be supporting an amendment to change the actual date which is set out in the bill itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1995. I was wondering whether, given that the previous speaker was the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews), an amendment had been moved to bring back the GST. I guess we will have to wait and find out when we take the vote. This bill covers quite a number of areas of taxation issues. It covers issues such as foreign income, rebatable and frankable dividends, bankruptcy and losses, reduction of PAYE early remittance threshold, group certificates and other PAYE provisions and superannuation guarantee matters.

PARA.TAB: One of the things that I have come to learn in the time I have been here is how complex and big our tax act is. It covers some 5,000 pages at last count. In my first few months here, after I was appointed to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, at the tail end of the taxation inquiry, I learnt that the taxation law was very complex. People around the room in that PAC inquiry all agreed that something had to be done. I know now that there is a lot of work being done in the Australian Taxation Office on simplifying the tax act. In the meantime, we have to deal with the current situation and we have a number of these amendments which seem to come before the House and the Senate every year.

The taxation law is a bit like social security provisions—the more you get into it and the more you look at different provisions, the more complex it seems. It does not matter what governments try to do, there always seems to be a complication and anomaly that can throw up an injustice, like something that will affect somebody differently from somebody else. We never seem to be able to get the balance quite right in terms of fairness and equity on the one hand and simplicity on the other hand without affecting somebody somewhere along the line. I know that there is a lot of work going on and there is a project called the taxation law improvement project under way at the moment.

I guess it was partly because of the desire for simplicity—at least that was one of the attractions—that the opposition decided to promote a consumption tax, a goods and services tax, before the last election. One of the arguments in favour of the consumption tax was that it was simpler and everyone would pay the same amount of 15 per cent on all goods and services, except food. That was supposed to be simpler and therefore easier to collect. That was one of the great attractions put forward for it.

Even though I do not agree with a consumption tax and never have, there are a lot of people, including some in the tax office, who argue quite genuinely that they believe that that is an attraction of a consumption tax and that we will eventually have one. I hope we never do because I believe it is an inequitable tax and a regressive tax. I do know that some of my friends and people in the community genuinely believe that, because of this supposed simplicity and equality—although it is not really, of course—with everyone paying the same flat right of consumption tax, it is therefore simpler and more easy to administer and harder to avoid. I do not happen to believe that.

I think that it has been pointed out that even a GST is not foolproof or avoidance proof and there could still be a black economy associated with a consumption tax. I guess that was one of the arguments put forward—the need to simplify the tax legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. If we were debating a consumption tax, the honourable member's remarks would be relevant. But, given that there is no such proposal in this bill and the title of this bill is quite clearly defined and not open to all sorts of related purposes, I would ask you to bring the honourable member back to the point of the bill before the House.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Snow)—I suggest that the honourable member for Macarthur adhere to the point of the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, this is a wide ranging bill on a number of issues relating to tax, and I was covering them in a broad ranging fashion, as is the custom on many bills in this House.

PARA.TAB: I have already said that there is a need for simplification, but tax is also a very emotional issue. Unfortunately, in this country it seems to be fashionable to talk about reducing tax. We are, as we quite often hear, the second lowest taxed country in the OECD. We were the lowest taxed country; I believe Turkey is now apparently lower taxed than we are, because of some fiddling of the figures or whatever. So now we are the second lowest taxed country in the OECD. Unfortunately, some people in the government seem to think that is a badge of honour and we should boast about that. I believe that it is a bit of a problem and people in the community are increasingly seeing it, if they are honest, as a problem because the revenue is important.

People do expect a certain level of service and quality of services from governments at all levels. If we are going to have that service, people do have to face up to the situation that people have to pay tax and the revenue has to be there. It has to be fair and equitable, of course. But to suggest that we pay too much tax, as a lot of people do, particularly on the other side of the House and in the business community, et cetera, is not only dishonest but unfair and damaging to the Australian economy and the fabric of society.

Unfortunately, because of the `greed is good' mentality, particularly of the opposition, we have this situation where expectations are raised. Any suggestion that we pay more tax or that individuals pay more tax is treated with horror and we have all sorts of people running for cover, saying, `We are a lower taxing party than you are,' et cetera. I believe that is an undesirable feature of current Australian politics. We really do need to face up to the fact that people have to pay tax and they should pay the tax that is due. That does not mean that ordinary workers—PAYE taxpayers—should necessarily pay more tax.

One of the biggest problems is compliance and the avoidance industry, where companies or people on better incomes are able to minimise tax through all sorts of clever accountants and tax minimisation schemes. Of course, one obvious one that I have come across in the last few weeks is the move away from PAYE towards the PPS scheme. We have a number of examples, particularly in the construction industry, where workers are forming themselves into companies or becoming contractors and, therefore, somehow or other qualifying to be PPS taxpayers rather than PAYE taxpayers. That is totally against the spirit of taxation laws, and I understand that that is being looked at by the tax office.

It cannot come too soon as far as I am concerned. Not only is this an organised attempt to supposedly bring more flexibility into industrial relations, thereby basically smashing industrial relations and smashing trade unionism by everyone becoming a contractor—which would suit the opposition's industrial relations policies perfectly—but also this is potentially eroding the revenue in a big way. That is one area that I will certainly be keeping an eye on in terms of tax policy to make sure that that does not continue and that people do as they are supposed to do—pay the tax that they are obliged to pay under the PAYE system, whether or not they want to call themselves contractors or subcontractors.

I have talked to a few friends recently, including people that I know in the taxation area, about the idea of making the tax system simpler. Most PAYE taxpayers probably get a small refund every year. They get their Tax Pack every year, and hopefully the Tax Pack is correct and they can get around all the supposed errors in it. It used to be called Form S. It possibly still is called that. I have not done my tax this year yet. I should not admit that, should I? I have only about two weeks to go. The ordinary battlers, the PAYE taxpayers who earn an ordinary income, fill in their tax forms and they might get a small refund—somewhere between $100 or up to $1,000 a year, if they are lucky. It seems to me that the tax system is administered in a rather expensive way.

A good idea might be to bring about, on a properly costed basis, a situation where ordinary taxpayers who earn only wages—who do not have other complications which preclude them from filling in a Form S, for example—be given the option of not bothering with a taxation return. By perhaps ticking a box at the beginning of the year on, say, their employment declaration certificate, they might opt out of the taxation system, in the sense that they would not have to bother with a taxation return, and in return they might get $500 or $1,000, whatever is a reasonable rate. I have not costed this, so I do not know.

That would probably save the Taxation Office a lot of money. It would save a lot of paper. It would not cost ordinary taxpayers. Of course, you could always opt back into the tax system if you thought you could get more of a refund from filling in the form. But, if they are just average taxpayers who might get a few hundred dollars a year, they could opt out of the system and get more in their pay packets, which would add up to the same amount—an averaged out amount every year—and they would not have to bother with the form.

That does not mean that you would have to cut staff in the Taxation Office. It would ensure that the valuable staffing resources in the Taxation Office were directed away from processing thousands and thousands of ordinary PAYE taxpayer forms towards looking at the tougher areas of taxation—getting some of the big fish and making sure that some of the people who make a bit of an industry out of ripping off the tax system and paying as little tax as possible actually pay their taxes.

We do not necessarily need to raise tax levels in this country, if only we could get everyone to pay the tax that they should be paying. That has been the major problem. It was exemplified in the late 1970s when the current Leader of the Opposition, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), was Treasurer. We had the famous bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, and a lot of pressure was put on the then government to do something about that when it became public knowledge.

The then Treasurer did make some belated measures, and for his reward he got castigated by his own party in Western Australia. We are still seeing the effects of that in the 1990s with some of the internal Liberal Party politics in Western Australia, which are an echo of the bad days of the seventies and eighties. I lived in Western Australia in the 1970s, and I can recall the Liberal Party slogans and stickers that used to be put up at election times by the Liberal Party that `taxation is theft'. Obviously, the people who run the Liberal Party in Western Australia, the ones who have got the numbers over there, do not think that anyone should pay tax or that it should be voluntary rather than a responsibility.

The bottom-of-the-harbour schemes existed in the 1980s, and this government, from 1983 onwards, had to try to plug the hole in the tax system by bringing in various measures. The measures are ongoing, such as the ones in the bill that we are voting on today.

Of course, we have problems also in the Senate with taxation issues. It is very difficult when neither party has a majority in the Senate to get agreement on some of these complex areas. That is understandable. Tax is a very complex area, and the sooner we get some simplification as a result of this major project being undertaken in the tax office then the better we will all be.

There should be equity and honesty in taxation. There should be an equitable progressive taxation system whereby those who can afford to pay tax most pay the most and there should be relative relief for those on the lower end of the income scale. Our taxation system largely attempts to do that, although perhaps it does not always get it perfectly right. But, as I have said a number of times, it is a very complex system, and we will always find somebody who will say that they are disadvantaged. I guess that's life. The social security system is similar in that respect.

What has made it difficult is this `greed is good' mentality. The same thing happens in other countries. The conservative parties—the opposition in Australia—build up this expectation that we are all paying too much tax, and that makes it very difficult for governments to be responsible in taxation and, at the same time, have policies that ensure their re-election. I agree that at election times people do get a bit carried away with promises and expectations. But what has made it very difficult in this climate which has been created, particularly on the other side of the House, is the suggestion made to people—and suggesting it often enough so that people believe it—that as a community we are somehow paying too much tax.

We are not paying too much tax. We need the revenue so that we can provide the community services and social justice that people expect and that Labor governments certainly stand for. It is not an easy thing, but anything that we can do to tighten avoidance and ensure that the revenue base is there but at the same time make it as equitable, fair and simple a system as possible is to be commended. I therefore commend these measures to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) was introduced into the House on 29 June this year. It makes nine substantive amendments to our tax laws. The provisions set out to amend several principal acts, including the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 and Bankruptcy Act 1966. The changes in the bill include those affecting controlled foreign companies; dividends paid out of capital accounts, as announced in the 1995 budget; and extending the accelerated depreciation of ships to 30 June 2002.

PARA.TAB: Further, changes are proposed to the method of collecting tax, reducing the price monthly remitter threshold from $5 million to $1 million, as announced in the budget, and increasing the infrastructure borrowings rebate to 36 per cent in line with the company tax rate. There are also changes to the super guarantee charge system in regard to allowing employees to elect that members not make SGC contributions under certain circumstances and by allowing the notional earnings base to be used to calculate SGC contributions.

As to rebatable and frankable dividends, this bill proposes to amend the income tax laws so that dividends that are debited to share capital, premium accounts or revaluation reserves of a company are disqualified from being rebatable or frankable. The reason the government is taking this kind of action is apparently to stop companies providing tax free distributions to corporate shareholders or transferring franking credits to shareholders by inappropriate means. This particular measure is therefore aimed at limiting any potential tax avoidance.

The only problem is that there is ample evidence that the government is yet again trying to crack a walnut with a sledgehammer. There are unintended consequences of the proposal before us which impact on ordinary commercial transactions that are totally lawful. The Insurance Council has had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that the legislation, as currently drafted, could have the effect of preventing Australian companies from franking dividends paid from ordinary retained earnings, where movements have occurred to and from the company's asset revaluation reserves, as part of their ordinary business.
The council went on to say:

The impact of this legislation, if enacted, could be disastrous for many Australian companies, and the anomaly is clearly something that was never intended at the time the proposals were announced in the federal budget . . . Because the effect of the provisions is to deny a company the ability to frank its dividends, the impact of the deficiency—
that is, I think, the deficiency in the bill's wording—
could extend beyond Australia's corporate sector to many thousands of individual and institutional shareholders, in receipt of dividends which a company was unaware could not be franked.

The Insurance Council has provided an example to illustrate this anomaly. Where a company owns a building at 30 June 1994 which cost, say, $100,000 to purchase but is now valued at $150,000, the amount to be credited to the revaluation reserve is quite obviously $50,000. There is also a corresponding debit to the asset account.
