However, by 30 June 1995, where the value of the building has fallen to $100,000 the company will debit the asset revaluation reserve and credit the asset account with the amount of $50,000. This entails a transfer of an amount from a `disqualifying account', the asset revaluation reserve account, to a `non-disqualifying account', the asset account.

PARA.TAB: Under section 461 of this bill, as part of the write-down, the company will credit the $50,000 I have mentioned in the example to the notional disqualifying account. If no other events occur, and the company pays a dividend of, say, $200,000 in July 1995, with the full amount being debited to its retained earnings, section 46G(1), as currently drafted, will provide that $50,000 of the dividend so paid will not be rebatable and will not be capable of being franked. Mr John Hodgkinson of the Insurance Council, in describing that particular situation, has said:

SPEECH.PARA: This situation will not be unusual and is likely to impact on many companies who have amounts moving into and out of asset revaluation reserves, for perfectly legitimate commercial reasons, e.g. complying with accounting standards.

He has also made the observation that there is nothing to connect the asset revaluation reserve movements with the payment of a dividend. It is totally ridiculous for a company to be placed in the position of paying a dividend in a proper manner but then finding that dividend cannot be franked or rebated to recipient shareholders.

PARA.TAB: The Taxation Institute of Australia also raises the concern that this legislation will impede legitimate corporate reconstructions. Where this takes the form of the insertion of a holding company between the shareholders and an existing company, companies should not be hindered in undertaking legitimate corporate reorganisations.

The unintended consequences of this bill should be addressed. I have been informed that the government has prepared some amendments—and they came to hand late this morning—to address the concerns of the Tax Institute and the Insurance Council. I got them this morning at a quarter past nine. The bill was scheduled to be debated at 10 o'clock. I did not have an explanatory memorandum for those amendments, which go to 2 1/4 pages. Again, this is an example of the disdain with which the parliament is treated when it considers complex legislation.
On the matter of the changes affecting the tainted income of controlled foreign companies—CFCs—there is a retrospective element. The explanatory memorandum states:

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments will clarify that the Commissioner of Taxation may make adjustments, reflecting arm's length values to amounts used in determining whether a CFC has passed the income test.

Without wanting to go into great depth now, because I will do so later in the detailed stages, the problem here is that this amendment will be applied retrospectively for the accounting periods commencing before but ending after June 1995. Therefore this measure is applicable from 1 July 1995 and as a consequence it will in some cases have a retrospective impact on the attributable income of CFCs where their financial year does not conveniently end on 30 June 1995. That is not uncommon, although it is not right either. That is most inequitable.

PARA.TAB: I have constantly made the point that retrospectivity as a rule should be avoided in any legislation and in particular in tax legislation. Retrospectivity is only acceptable to me when it does not create losers but, even then, it should still be avoided. Retrospective tax legislation by this Labor government is far from unusual, as I am sure the House is aware. It has been a tool of Labor and it has not hesitated to use it. However, it is clear that such retrospectivity undermines certainty, credibility and fairness in the tax system.

With the constant stream of tax amendment bills coming before this place, as well as the draft rulings from the Australian Taxation Office, it is obvious that the taxpaying community does not need the added uncertainty of retrospective tax changes. There must be community confidence in the certainty of the law—certainty that today's legal act does not tomorrow become the trigger for a penalty or obligation by law created subsequent to that legal act and applied retrospectively.

With tax law, taxpayers need to be able to determine their obligations with at least a modicum of certainty. But with retrospective tax legislation not only must taxpayers assess their tax position according to current law but also they need to determine what the intent of the relevant law was at the time it was drafted and passed through the parliament. That is necessary because one day the legislation will be retrospectively amended along certain lines.

The problem is that we expect too much from taxpayers and accountants. How can taxpayers be expected to pre-empt what was the real intent of the law with their scarce resources, when parliament and its supporting bureaucracy couldn't get it right in the first place? The parliament, and especially the government, should be accountable for their errors, not taxpayers. Retrospectivity is a denial of natural justice and a repudiation of fairness where it occurs in our tax system. Not only is the tax system almost unintelligible, compliance costs exorbitant and there is no stability in the tax regime, but also with retrospectivity there is a serious element of guesswork, in trying to get an understanding of tax law. Stability and certainty in the tax system are key concepts this government simply has not been able to grasp.

This bill comes before the House just over 10 years since the government announced its reform of the Australian tax system—otherwise aptly known as RATS. This announcement followed the much heralded 1985 tax summit, you will recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, where the much supported option C of the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was rejected by Bob Hawke in a deal with the ACTU heavies. RATS was supposed to provide a tax system which is simpler, fairer, does not increase the overall tax burden, does not disadvantage welfare recipients, moderates wage pressures, does not stifle investment, growth and jobs, and has widespread community support.

Key aspects of Labor's changes included the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and dividend imputation. Labor might postulate that it has succeeded in meeting its objectives, and quite often it does. However, the reality is they have failed dismally. The overall tax burden has increased. Taken as a percentage of gross domestic product, public sector revenues have increased from 33.4 per cent to 34.4 per cent. Of this, the federal component appears to have fallen, but only because grants to the states have been slashed. Then, of course, when compulsory superannuation is added—because, let us face it, it is a tax on earnings—the overall tax burden has increased. Mr George Megalogenis put it accurately in the Australian of 19 September 1995 when he wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: The total tax burden on workers is greater now than it was 10 years ago today—
that was on 19 September—
when Paul Keating unveiled his historic tax reform package to slash marginal rates and restore fairness and credibility to the tax system.
Mr Megalogenis went on to say:
Australians are also paying more in indirect taxes than they would have under the coalition's goods and services tax plan . . .

How is that? Australians are now also paying more in indirect taxes than they would have under the coalition's goods and services tax plan. Well, we know Labor always rants about the reduction of the top marginal rate from 60 per cent to 49 per cent, yet Labor still collects more income tax in real terms than the Fraser government ever did. Why is that? Bracket creep is the answer, as it always has been. Many middle income earners are now in the highest tax bracket. Labor's cuts to the marginal tax rates were removed by stealth, as you will recall, Mr Deputy Speaker.

PARA.TAB: Anti-tax avoidance and evasion measures have been taken to ludicrous degrees, when the most simple method of limiting avoidance is, and always was, a goods and services tax. A goods and services tax would force many tax dodgers to start declaring their real level of income, thereby allowing the government to get off the back of honest taxpayers. Labor's tax system is definitely not simpler, and it is in no way fairer. Shifting huge wads of the cost of compliance on to employers may be electorally clever but economically it is disastrous. As a partial consequence, the objective of not stifling investment, growth and jobs has been a farcical failure.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! I draw the attention of the gentlemen on my left to standing order 57 and ask that they pay the speaker with the call the courtesy of observing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Real tax reform, encompassing a GST, or a broad based retail sales tax, would better achieve an increase in national savings, investment and economic growth. As for limiting the negatives for welfare recipients, as claimed a little over 10 years ago by the present Prime Minister, a GST or retail sales tax can be introduced, with welfare recipients receiving compensation, of course. However, the introduction of a GST would be a bonus to those on welfare because it would better provide an environment for them to get out of the welfare poverty trap in so many cases. To put it lightly, this government has totally failed to grasp the real reforms needed to provide a simpler, fairer and more equitable tax system. Of Labor's 10 years of so-called tax reform, the Financial Review of 15 September 1995 had this to say in an editorial:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's taxation system stands as probably the most all encompassing symbol of what has been both good and bad about the Labor Party's long period of power at the federal level.

In the same way, the tax summit in Canberra 10 years ago epitomises both its initial enthusiasm for reform and its increasing unwillingness to embrace those changes where the electoral equation seemed uncertain.
With tax, the upshot is a system which contains a number of intelligent initiatives—
and they refer to dividend imputation and capital gains tax—
one notorious fiasco (the FBT) and a huge omission (a consumption tax).

Ten years ago, the present Prime Minister saw the merits of a consumption tax, yet in 1993 he actively campaigned against a measure he knew to be for the national good. Because Labor has botched tax reform and made meaningful reforms politically unacceptable, we are now stuck in a time warp, trying to simplify current tax laws.

PARA.TAB: Yet even in this endeavour, Labor is incapable of doing the job properly. The primary goal of tax simplification should be to make the law easier to understand, reduce the cost of compliance and bring logic and rationale into the tax system. In this, Labor has failed. Labor is not prepared to examine policy issues which must be rectified if the tax system is to be simplified. The Financial Review in the editorial which I referred to a moment ago concluded by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: What is needed now, a decade after the tax summit, is not more talking, but rather the will to tackle the major tax issues which remain outstanding.

While these include the need for a commonsense review of FBT, by far the most important is the need to start laying the public relations groundwork for the eventual introduction of a broadly based consumption tax. . .
Until this is done there will be little scope for a proper, and long overdue, restructuring of our onerous income tax scales.
The editorial in the Australian on that momentous date of 19 September, celebrating 10 years of Labor's failure, said:
Tax reform is notoriously difficult to achieve. It always will be difficult, no matter how apparently propitious the moment for introducing reforms might be.
But the distortions are getting worse and the pressure to reform will only build.
The most obvious target for reform, as the growing number of nations that have adopted it will testify, is in the area of broad-based indirect taxation.
We know that a broad based tax system is off the agenda because of the way Labor behaved during the last election. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry I was not present to hear the entirety of the remarks by my friend the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) but I did catch the last topic he discussed—a broad based consumption tax. May I say forthwith and with some alacrity that that is not a subject that I intend to touch upon in my remarks this afternoon. I note the presence of my good friend the member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) at the table.

PARA.TAB: When I spoke on an FBT cost of compliance bill a couple of sitting weeks ago, I began my remarks by saying it is hard to imagine anything more depressing than a tax bill. I can think of other depressing things around this parliament, such as the salad bar in the members' dining room and the answers that we are sometimes forced to listen to at question time from some of the more narcotically boring members of the government front bench. There are certainly many other equally maudlin prospects but a tax bill is probably about the worst.

Our tax system is embodied in the monstrous Income Tax Assessment Act, the first volume of which I have with me this afternoon. It is really now not so much a matter of a grimace of horror but a matter of black humour. It has become so complex and so far beyond the comprehension of ordinary Australians, be they individuals striving to earn an income in some field or workers for a large corporation, that resort to expensive and certainly very well qualified advisers is really the only answer these days if you have a problem with the tax office. I believe it is really so complex that perhaps we could say that the tax act itself is one of the chief causes of this country's economic woes.

The attitude of the tax office towards this complexity is quite clear: they love it. There is nothing a tax bureaucrat likes more than a good dose of complexity. This was revealed in a startlingly topical article in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald, which contained some comments made by a senior Treasury official, the head of the federal Treasury's tax policy division. He may not be from the Australian Taxation Office, but he certainly fits the description of a tax bureaucrat. Mr Ken Henry, in defending the complexity of the tax legislation, said, `Well, that was what was needed to deal with a complex world.' They have no sympathy whatsoever for the ordinary citizen who suffers the burden of this act and the general taxation scheme—whether it be income tax, fringe benefits tax or sales tax. I believe that the complexity of the scheme keeps those bureaucrats safe in their positions of power and authority.

If Mr Henry said `bad luck' when people complained to him about the complexity of the act, then it is quite clear that there is no sign of a move towards a simpler system under this government. There does not even seem to be any sympathy for the prospect of a simpler system. When we debated the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill last month, I pointed out that, in seeking to reduce the cost of compliance and the burden on the public, we are actually adding another 60 pages to the legislation. That legislation was 342 pages long when I was born in 1961. It now exceeds 5,000 pages. Enough said about that.

I refer back to Mr Henry's comment that, as life is complex, we have to have a complex tax system. During the debate on the cost of compliance bill, I proposed that, as technology changes and the nature and incidence of employment and earnings grow more complicated as the years pass, the revenue raising means of a government will have to adapt to these changes. The government is choosing a most mechanical and intrusive approach and is enacting highly technical legislation. In the case of the compliance bill, the legislation imposed a liability on the employer. This will necessarily fetter or restrict an employer's or an individual's ability to produce earnings or a return on the capital that they may invest. The employment opportunities and further investment prospects are likewise restricted. That is the true meaning of the cost of compliance.

The cost of compliance of any tax system or any part of a tax system goes beyond the monetary penalty and the opportunity cost to the existing taxpayers. Every legislative act or administrative act of government has an effect on the psychology of investment. I describe it simply as the atmospheric effect. Consideration has been given to the atmospheric effect caused by our tax system in a report by a group called the APEC Capital Markets Working Group, whom a newspaper article describes as `a group of business and financial market leaders who will lobby the Australian government to strengthen efforts for Australia to become a major financial centre in this region'. It is something that you hear quite a lot about in the government's rhetoric. This group of business and financial market leaders wrote a report which they presumably gave to the government. They pointed out quite clearly that Australia's tax system has a number of competitive disadvantages, including an international reputation for being unsympathetic to regional headquarters, and is considered to be a significant disincentive. There is really no point in saying anything further after hearing those comments from that group.

You have to consider the position of the taxpayer—whether it be a corporate taxpayer or an individual—and how that person is treated by the tax office. Only yesterday I had a telephone call in my office from a constituent who was having his first tax audit. It sounded as though he was about to have his first child or his first dip in the sea at Bondi Beach. He was a little bit nervous about how the tax office was going to treat him, and he probably had good reason to be nervous about it.

In June, the Australian Financial Review published an article by a former officer of the tax department, Mr Douglas. Mr Douglas is a lawyer who now practises as a partner with one of Sydney's larger law firms. He pointed out that, during his time in the tax office, the culture had changed as a result of some rather radical administrative changes. He said that they did not report in a horizontal fashion. The compliance officers, the lawyers within the tax office, are the doves. The hawks are the accountants, the bean counters, who in a rapacious fashion are out to squeeze every last cent from the taxpayer. The lawyers within the tax office take a more measured approach that emphasises the rights of the taxpayers. In the past, the compliance people had their own little section. The other section of the tax office, which dealt with individuals, large corporations, small corporations, rural producers and any other special working groups, would go to see the compliance group—that is, the lawyers—to check their work as they were carrying out audits. In that sense, there was a nice system of checks and balances on them. This was described as the horizontal style of organisation. For some reason, this was changed to a vertical system.

The tax office was reorganised so that each section which dealt with large corporations, small corporations, individuals and so forth had their own little in-house compliance officer or officers. They were much smaller in number. This meant that the burden on them to check the work of the hawks, the people carrying out the audits, was so great that they began, through no fault of their own, to fail in their task.

Mr Douglas also told me that working in the same physical environment with the compliance officers over in the corner of the office made them feel somehow intimidated when making decisions or giving advice that was adverse to the interests of the hawks. If one of the audit officers came up with a proposal to issue a draft ruling that would be adverse to the interests of the taxpayer and he was very keen to do this, the compliance officer with whom he might go out and have a beer on Friday or with whom he might socialise—like any other Australian office, people who work together occasionally spend time together outside work—might feel a little less inclined to perform his duties in a strict fashion. He may say to the audit officer, `Look, I think you're going a bit far with your proposed draft ruling.' He would go soft on it. In that sense, the hawks were getting their way.

The reason given for this change in the culture of the tax office was enormous pressure on the tax office's revenue raising activity. That is clearly driven by a very loose fiscal discipline here in Canberra. From the top down, enormous pressure is placed on the tax office to raise as much revenue as possible with no regard to fairness. This reorganisation has given ascendancy to the hawks within the office. There is much to be done after the next election in reforming the way the tax office behaves when it deals with our citizens. No doubt after the election the government of this nation will change and a more sensible approach to this monstrous piece of legislation and its administrative underpinnings will be taken.

In speaking to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1995 before us this afternoon, I would like to make a few remarks about the provisions regarding the pay-as-you-earn tax system and the peculiar proposal for a system of tax vouchers, which is really a cloak for a system of granting the tax office free loans. I would like to also speak about some provisions to do with the superannuation guarantee levy and reiterate a few other things about the absurdity of the tax act.

Regarding the PAYE tax system, it seems as though this amendment is just another burden imposed on small and medium businesses. The existing law, as I understand it, says that companies which remit pay-as-you-earn tax deductions of under $5 million per month are obliged to remit them once a month. So the cost to their business of making the calculations and the bank charges that they will pay on that occur once a month.

Suddenly, this threshold is to be reduced to $1 million. This will of course require many more companies to send in that money twice a month. For some of them, it will go close to nearly doubling the cost of performing that transaction. Again, the explanatory memorandum gives the reason for this. It is all because the government needs another $275 million in the 1995-96 year of income. There you have it—the loose fiscal discipline in Canberra working again to cause a bigger burden on the poor old innocent taxpayer.

The consequences of this grab for more money in this climate are serious. They really should not be underestimated because the prospects for next year, despite the rhetoric from the government frontbench—we have grown used to it and we take little notice of it these days—are looking rather grim.

I point out to the House that the ABS has a relatively new indicator. It is called the composite leading indicator. It is composed of eight different indicators: economic statistics, which have some element of predictive capacity to them, and others that have great bearing on the prospects for Australia's real GDP movements—things like housing finance, the changes in the United States' real GDP and of course real interest rates, which are inverted in the calculation.

The ABS put this together and then recalculated the figures going back to 1971. They do it quarterly. The significant thing is that in the June quarter of this year the index suffered its greatest quarterly fall since the June quarter of 1974. For the June quarter of 1995 this composite leading indicator suddenly falls off a cliff, as it does for 1974. If this indicator is a reliable guide to future movements in our own GDP—in the next, say, four quarters—we can say that it is not unreasonable to expect that our real GDP in the second or third quarter next year may be close to even negative.

Despite all the rhetoric, if this leading indicator has the predictive capacity that the ABS claims it does—they are a reasonably conservative lot when it comes to describing the power of their statistics—and the indicator has really fallen as much as or a little more than it did in 1974, I would need to be convinced that we are not going to have negative growth about this time next year.

Tomorrow morning we have an opportunity to ask questions of the Governor of the Reserve Bank when he makes an appearance before the Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration of this House. I look forward to taking the opportunity to ask him what he thinks is the significance of this sudden fall off a cliff. If you look at the elements within it individually, you will see that the movement in real interest rates caused by the bank's hiking of the official discount rate about this time last year has made a large contribution to that. But, generally speaking, I would just like the question answered.

Here we are debating another depressing tax bill—a bill which will raise another $275 million for the government in this year of income in an atmosphere which is looking increasingly grim. In this climate, I would describe imposing an extra burden on small and medium businesses as lunacy.

I would like to talk a little about the proposed tax voucher system, which I understand is intended to replace the old tax stamp system. This sets up a scheme whereby self-employed people, or non-employee taxpayers—those brave individuals who are out on their own in the economy trying to earn a dollar—

TALK.START.PARA: —In decreasing numbers.

—In decreasing numbers. Never more so than in the marginal seats of this country. These include all those tradesmen who ply their trade in the building industry and who have suffered so grievously during the past year since those official discount rate hikes have pushed the building industry off a cliff. They are the sorts of people whom this new scheme of tax vouchers is aimed at.

PARA.TAB: The scheme says they can trot along to the tax office and purchase a voucher issued by the tax office. This means that purchasers will get a credit against their tax liability when they submit their return at the end of the year. It seems to me that this new system is something of a nonsense because the purchase of these vouchers will not give any relief from provisional tax.

Taxpayers would be better off putting the same money into an interest bearing account at a bank. Despite the awful fees and charges that such a depositor would suffer, that would certainly be better than making what is in effect an interest free loan to the gentlemen in the tax office and the lunatics who occupy the front bench of this government. I hope that is not an unparliamentary term.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—I think it might be. You might just withdraw it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw it for the time being.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—No; you will withdraw it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw it absolutely and say the `misguided gentlemen who occupy the front bench of the government'. What is the point, then, of setting up a scheme whereby you are making what is, in effect, an interest free loan to the federal government? The net effect of it is that the Treasury will get this year's revenue a little earlier but still collect the provisional tax. I think that is just a sneaky little tactic.

PARA.TAB: There is much more in this bill to cover but, with the little time left for me to speak, there is certainly no time to do that in any detail. I point out to the House that I have been looking through the table of provisions of the first volume of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I have tried to look up a provision that deals with infrastructure bonds because there has been some discussion among the branch members of my party in my electorate about infrastructure development in and around Sydney.
Mr Rocher interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a discussion about many other topics, none of which encompass a broad based consumption tax, my honourable friend, but in particular deal with infrastructure bonds. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Thomson) was just getting started, and he was warming up nicely with some encouragement from the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). Here we have another raft of tax legislation. The government seems committed to increasing the size of the tax legislation willy-nilly, day after day, week after week.

PARA.TAB: The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) is poorly drafted. I cannot remember, and I do not know whether the member for Curtin can, a single piece of legislative change that has come into this House that has not been amended by the government when the House has considered it. I do not think we have had one tax bill that has not been amended with the government's own amendments before it has been passed by the parliament.

It is poor drafting, sloppy processing and poor administration, and my colleagues acknowledge that. It does not seem to worry the government because, after all, they do not have to pay for drafting mistakes. It is the taxpayer who pays for drafting mistakes. The cost of collecting tax does not appear to worry the government either. The government can increase willy-nilly the compliance cost and not be worried about it in the slightest.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) covers a range of things such as the changes affecting control of foreign companies; changes affecting dividends paid out for capital accounts; extending the accelerated depreciation for ships; a number of changes to the collection of tax, including reducing the twice-monthly remitter threshold from $5 million to $1 million; increasing the infrastructure borrowing rebate to 36 per cent in line with company tax; and changes to the superannuation guarantee system, including allowing employees to elect that employers not make superannuation guarantee contributions and allowing the notional earnings base to be used to calculate superannuation contributions—all very interesting and burdensome for the Australian community.

Because this is a money bill I want to talk about the debt and where Australia is economically. It is a disastrous situation. Our high foreign debt is limiting every capacity that Australia has. The government keeps saying that it is not borrowing much overseas. In fact, about half of the total Australian debt is government—

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing like it.

—Look at your statistics. Half of it is government. You do not know the facts. Half of the total borrowings in Australia—public and private—is government. If you look at your outgoings in your own budget, you will find that about $9 billion is going out just to pay the interest charges. That is almost the size of your education or defence budget. And you are content to live with that!

PARA.TAB: If one looks at the fact that we are running a current account deficit of about $26 billion a year, one could say that we are actually borrowing funds overseas—we have to fund that deficit somehow—to pay our interest charges. The worst type of management a nation can have is one which borrows to fund its debt. There is only one place where that finishes up. I think Mr Micawber mentioned on a number of occasions the `grave circumstances'—g-r-a-v-e. Those are the circumstances you have put Australia in.

The Australian debt currently stands at over $180 billion. This is about an eightfold increase since 1983 when the debt was $23 billion. That is the record of the current government. Our total debt-foreign liabilities, which is the debt plus foreign equity in Australian companies, stands at about $260 billion—five times the level of 1985. This is what this Australian government has done to this great nation.

The current account crisis, the deficit we have, for 1994-95 was $26.8 billion—the highest annual deficit that Australia has ever run. I do not know how this year is going to finish. The government, with an election on its hands, is likely to blow its predictions right out of the water. Any talk of the country being in surplus next year or the year after is crazy.

The ratio of our gross domestic product to our current account deficit, as calculated by the OECD, is a lot worse than Mexico. In 1994 we were about equivalent to Mexico. This year Mexico is way ahead of us. We are just really at the bottom of the list. These are the OECD figures. This is the ratio of our foreign debt to the proportion of our GDP. That is a reasonable relationship to make.

Standard and Poor's international currency agency rates Australia 49th out of the 51 countries it surveyed in terms of current account deficit—49th out of 51! No wonder Mr Murdoch had some comments to make about your Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his descriptions of Australia's success. Mr Murdoch does understand what the real needs of Australia are. He does understand the levels of youth employment. The Prime Minister says, `One of the reasons we've got high youth unemployment is Mr Murdoch is not getting involved in our make-work programs where the taxpayer funds a company to take on employees.' That is not a solution which is a workable solution.

Australia has been left behind by many other countries in addressing its deficit. There is the deficit blow-out to 6.6 per cent of GDP. Comparable deficits were recorded by Finland, UK and Canada in 1989. We were at about the same level of deficit as a proportion of GDP as Finland, UK and Canada. In 1995 the OECD projects that these nations will be able to get on top of their current account deficits. The projections are: Finland, a current account surplus of 1.8 per cent; United Kingdom, a deficit of 0.1 per cent; and Canada, a deficit of 2.2 per cent. All of these performances are far better than Australia's. But the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and the Prime Minister fail to acknowledge any of it.

We have had discussions over the last week or so about whether or not local interest rates are affected by the foreign debt. Of course they are. The Prime Minister—despite all his shoving, skating and weaving—finally had to acknowledge that internal interest rates are affected by our foreign debt. Australia has the equal highest prime rate for corporate in the advanced industrial world. Australia's short-term three-month interest rate is exceeded only by Italy, Spain and Sweden—all countries that are running a higher deficit regime than Australia.

I know that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker), who is at the table, is from the left side of his party. He has a compassionate heart and has a real wish to see those in need, the battlers of Australia, taken care of and supported. He would not be supporting the ripping down of homes in the Sydenham area by the federal government to make way for airlines. He would not be supporting the processes of battlers being out of work. He would not be naturally supporting those, but he is bound by his ministerial oath. I understand that. But I would have thought he would be working very hard and encouraging the government to work very hard to reduce the debt so that opportunities to employ in Australia were greatly increased.
When one looks at the impact of the debt on interest rates, one just has to quote the budget papers. The 1995-96 budget papers, on page 2.36, states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a high level of foreign borrowing relative to GDP can impose costs on an economy by making it more vulnerable to external shocks and by raising interest rate premia on borrowings.

It is there in the budget papers and it has been there all the time. The Treasurer tried to avoid the fact that he knew it was there. In the 1993 report to the government on national savings, Vince Fitzgerald, the government's own employed consultant to look at savings and the direction the government was taking, said:
We need to pay higher interest rates to compensate for the risks inherent in our high external debt.

So it is there. We are paying much more for houses, cars and consumables of every sort because of the high interest regime the government has. Large current account deficits place upward pressures on rates. The Prime Minister jacked up interest rates in 1989 to rein in the current account deficit. Mortgage interest rates reached 18 per cent and led to the recession that we had to have.

PARA.TAB: I guess at that time it was of no surprise to Australians to hear the Prime Minister make the claim that an economy which cannot travel at four per cent without spilling over into imports should give the game away and that we ought to be able to run this economy at least at four per cent. It is not running at four per cent growth now. It is dropping off. And look at the mess that is still there. When the recovery got under way the Prime Minister still kept interest rates high to stabilise the current account in that way. The Commonwealth has been the prime driver in so many ways of Australia's deteriorating foreign debt. Vince Fitzgerald said:

SPEECH.PARA: In short, the foreign debt position of Australia, and for that matter the current deficit, which is dominated by interest payments on the past accumulated debt, are attributable only to a small extent if at all to private sector net borrowing; rather they are essentially attributable to government and, indeed, to a significant extent represent borrowing to finance public consumption rather than investment, at least at the Commonwealth level.

So what has that done? That has forced Australian borrowers off the Australian market and onto overseas markets. That has been detrimental to the nation as well. It has been the Australian management of it: not only has the debt been created by the government in its own thirst for funds to finance its own consumer programs, but also it has had the double whammy of forcing Australian companies offshore where they have had to borrow and where the government, of course, is paying a higher rate for money that it is borrowing—which means a higher interest rate the Australian taxpayer at one time will have to return.

PARA.TAB: Mr Willis claimed at one stage—and I heard him say this:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most stupid, ridiculous assertions that has ever been made by an opposition is . . . that foreign debt means that there is a higher interest burden on ordinary Australians.
He said that in the House of Representatives on 21 September. One can run through those who disagree with Willis—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! I am loath to interrupt the flowing eloquence of the member for Mitchell, but I would be pleased if he could refer to the Treasurer by his correct title.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. One wonders whether in fact he is Treasurer only in title rather than in both title and action. But that is his title and he should be referred to by his title. He is the Treasurer of Australia. But one wonders whether, with statements like this about interest rates, he really understands what he is doing.

PARA.TAB: Those who disagree with the Treasurer are the Prime Minister; Vince Fitzgerald; Allan Ostler, Chief Economist of the National Bank; Professor McKibbin of the ANU; Steven Morling, Reserve Bank Research Economist; and Robert Subbaraman, Reserve Bank Research Economist. The Prime Minister contradicted his Treasurer and, on 20 September 1995, in Orange—and I was in Orange on the day before he was there—said:

SPEECH.PARA: We must work to deal with the problem of the current account deficit so that we're not paying too high a premium on world interest rate markets.

There it is from the Prime Minister. It does affect our Australian economy, it is serious and it is the thing that is worrying more Australians than anything else: the high debt and what it is costing them—the amount of the farm we have had to sell off, the amount of the Australian economy we have had to sell to overseas interests to balance the books.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want to sell the lot.

—No, Minister. You have changed the Foreign Investment Review Board rules since you have been in office. You have allowed more of Australia to be sold. Before you came into office, you used to be able to invest in Australia if it was of benefit to Australia. But now you just say that, if it is of no detriment to Australia, you can do anything you like. This is the Labor Party that is so nationalistic!

PARA.TAB: We do not make any claims about the goals that you have made claims about. What I am pointing to is the hypocrisy of the Labor Party: they have no beliefs at all, except in saying anything or doing anything to hold office or to get themselves into office. Nothing could be a better illustration of the attitudes of the Australian Labor Party, in regard to the economy and their care for their fellow Australians, than Mr Keating's own words on the current account matter. Going right back to 1986 I will give about 10 quotes from the Prime Minister over a period of 10 years. You would think the Australian press would have learnt that he cannot be trusted on these issues.
But let me read from 14 May 1986. There the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is so undisciplined, so disinterested in its salvation and its economic well being . . . the only thing to do is to slow the growth down to a canter . . . Then, you have gone. You are a banana republic.

That is the famous banana republic statement on the current account deficit. On 2 July 1987 he said, `What we are saying is the worst is over.' That was about the current account deficit in 1987. That was a laugh, wasn't it? The Prime Minister, on 13 May 1988, said:
It—
that is, the policy—
will continue lower the current account deficit and, in doing so, restore Australia's sovereignty over its own affairs.
This was years before the current high level total debt of $260 billion, or a net debt of $180 billion. On 27 November 1989, he said:
The current account problem is created by the new investment. It is not created by the government's incapacity to deal with the underlying current account deficit.
On 16 February 1990, he said:

Too much of a good thing can still be too much of a good thing. I mean, basically the glass is too full and the effervescence is spilling over the sides and that effervescence is the current account and inflation.
Come back to November 1990. He said:
This is a recession that Australia had to have.
On 3 March 1991, he said:
The current account deficit remains Australia's most pressing pressure. I think we have to be quite clear about that.

Over a period of five years it has still remained the problem. From the banana republic statement of 1986 to the 3 March statement in 1991, it is quite clear that the Prime Minister has achieved nothing in five years.

PARA.TAB: On 21 March 1991, the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The worst is now behind us. The government established the strategy to deal with the current account deficit and inflation and has stuck to it and is succeeding.
On 19 April 1991, he said:
We are looking at establishing the current account deficit well below the proportion of GDP reached in the late 1980s.

It has got worse. It is far worse than the current account deficit in Mexico. As we have learned today, Finland, the UK and Canada have solved their problems, but Australia's problems are still bad. The Prime Minister was making those promises in 1991—`It is time we fixed it up' and `It is well on the way to being fixed up'. On 26 February 1992, he said:
Labor's plan for the next four years will recreate over 800,000 jobs without increasing the current account deficit.
On 30 July 1992, he said `So you know, success breeds success'—in terms of the current account. On 2 December 1992, he said:
I say an economy that can't travel at four per cent without spilling over into imports should give the game away, we ought to be able to run this economy at four per cent at least.
On 4 July 1995, he said:
As the economy gets back to a sustainable rate of growth, so too will we see a subsidence in the current account deficit. In other words, we have got the position covered.

That is 10 years of absolute failure, year after year making a statement admitting that failure and not being able to deal with the most horrific problem that is worrying every Australian. It has increased our costs. It has meant that we have had to sell far more of our assets than was needed. It has meant that Australians are not in control of their own destiny—and that is the most worrying item that concerns Australians in New South Wales, Queensland, Western Australia and all those parts of Australia where the Labor Party will lose seats at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we are again, debating yet another government tax bill, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1995. The 4,000 or so pages in the tax legislation are not enough. We are about to get another great stack of new regulations, new taxes, new burdens on the Australian people.

PARA.TAB: The facts are that this government just goes on a taxing binge every time the budget is presented to the Australian people. In the last coalition budget—sadly, far too long ago—the total tax receipts were $40.7 billion. In the budget presented to us this year from the Labor government they are $124.4 billion. So the Australian taxpayers have lamented each budget as new and more severe tax measures have been imposed upon the Australian people.

All this comes from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who told us in November 1992, `What I am promising is not to put up tax'—I repeat: what I am promising is not to put up tax. Of course, every budget since then, following on all those prior to that, has massively increased taxes.

In the current budget individual income tax is up 13.6 per cent; the Medicare levy up 18.4 per cent; company tax up 15.4 per cent; super funds tax up 13.2 per cent; fringe benefits tax, 4.4 per cent, after being up 131 per cent in the previous budget; other income taxes up 8.3 per cent; sales tax up 22.3 per cent; fuel excise, 7.7 per cent—in fact, fuel excise has increased seven-fold in the life of the Labor government; other excise duties up 8.8 per cent; and customs duties up 3.2 per cent. So the list goes on and on. These enormous increases are really costing Australians dearly.

It is not just business that pays taxes, it is not just rich people that pay taxes; every ordinary Australian pays them every day. A bite of every pension payment, a bite of every disability pension and a bite of every welfare benefit goes to paying taxes—the government's indirect tax regime. At the last federal election there was so much criticism of the coalition's GST proposals. But it is interesting to note that Labor is now collecting more from the indirect taxes the coalition was going to abolish than the coalition had aimed to collect from its GST. All of that has happened without any of the compensatory measures that the coalition was proposing. There are none of the alternative benefits that were going to be provided and none of the benefits to the national economy. Just on a raw tax basis, Labor is now collecting more from its sales taxes, its fuel excise and the like than the coalition would have collected from the GST.

So there is no doubt about who are the big taxers in Australian history: it is the Labor government. In spite of all of the talk about simplification and tax cuts, the fact is that the burden gets greater each year and the complexity gets greater each year. That is one of the real tragedies of our current tax system. When the Income Tax Assessment Act became law in 1936, it contained just 126 pages. It had grown to 1,328 pages by 1983. So in its first almost 50 years it gained something like 1,200 pages. But in the life of the Labor government the Income Tax Assessment Act has grown close to 4,000 pages. In just 13 years, it has more than trebled in length. In all, Australia now has more than one million words of tax law spread over 7,000 pages. According to figures provided to a Senate estimates committee last year, it now costs more than $1.1 billion just to operate the Australian Taxation Office. That is almost four times what it cost a decade ago. The ATO now pays $213 million a year for leasing and maintaining its offices and is the biggest rent payer in most Australian capitals. At the time of that committee inquiry, the ATO had almost 18,000 permanent staff working in 25 separate offices to collect our tax.

All of that cost is basically borne by the victims of the Australian tax system. A recent study by the Australian Tax Research Foundation found that it cost business $123 for every $100 of company tax it pays to the federal government. It will cost companies around $4 billion in hidden calculation and other compliance costs to pay next year's company tax bill. The costs in Australia are almost 11 times higher than those in the United Kingdom. For the majority of companies, the cost of compliance is higher than the amount of corporate tax that they pay. That is an incredible indictment on the current system. It costs most companies more in compliance costs than in actual tax. When we have a system of that nature, is it any wonder that business complains about the complexity of our tax law? This legislation fails to address those sorts of problems.
I think the National President of the National Tax Agents Association, Ray Regan, summed it up well recently when he said:

Complex unworkable laws produce unfavourable tax audit statistics. It is a statement of fact that at least 74 per cent of all businesses which are audited have their returns amended as a result of the tax investigation. Fringe benefits tax almost constantly identifies an error rate of between 80 and 100 per cent of returns audited, resulting in substantial additional tax payable and returns being amended for up to four years.

In fact, in 1992 the ATO conducted 104,000 audits on individuals which collected $84.5 million-plus in additional revenue, resulting in each taxpayer having to pay back an average of $900 each . . . our current tax system is repeatedly producing unacceptably high audit amendments that not even the tax office can disguise as simply targeting those taxpayers where mistakes were most likely to be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that Ray Regan?
—It is. If you were listening, you would have known it was Ray Regan. It is a pity that you do not listen to what he says and do something about it. He continued by saying:

PARA.TAB: The fact is many taxpayers come out of a tax audit with a very bad taste in their mouths, believing it was simply impossible to comply with existing legislation which has seen the legislative services division of the ATO writing such complex rules which now compel more and more specialist cells to be established in the ATO, because not one tax auditor could possibly understand the maze of legislation that exists.

SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation Office cannot understand the maze of legislation which exists, but the poor, individual taxpayers are expected to. The last Tax Pack was crammed with errors, yet taxpayers who made a mistake were penalised and required to account for every one of their actions. The fact is that the existing law has become unreasonably complex and impossible for ordinary Australians to understand and comply with. It is high time that our tax law was addressed and we looked seriously at simplifying it and achieving an understandable law which people were able to deal with.

PARA.TAB: The fringe benefits tax is the classic example of this. Most people just give up in despair at the complexity they face when trying to adequately fulfil the requirements of the fringe benefits tax law. It is almost impossible to keep the required documentation, so when the tax office comes along most businesses just ask in despair, `How much do you want?' and, instead of arguing, they pay up and shut up.

That is not the way tax law ought to be administered, and it is not the way a responsible government should act. This government continues with its constant binge of tax collection and its constant approach that businesses only exist so they can pay higher and higher taxes to the government and that citizens only earn wages so they can contribute more to the government's coffers so the government can then go on its wild spending programs.

I understand that today the government released some kind of a book to chronicle its achievements in government. Frankly, I do not know why they needed a book to do that; a postage stamp would have been absolutely adequate. I have seen a number of books in newsagencies which on the outside cover says, `The complete and unabridged achievements of the Labor government,' but when you open them up you find that every page is blank. I think most people would wish that their tax law had a lot more blank pages.

The Labor Party's entire record would be better presented as blank pages than this wonder book that you can now apparently get on the Internet. Labor is attempting to persuade the public that it has actually achieved something worth while. A much more worthwhile publication is out now that has on its cover a phrase that would be very well known to members sitting opposite. The front page says, `This is as good as it gets.' It is a quote from Paul Keating.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—Is the Assistant Treasurer identifying himself with that statement? I understand that the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Beazley) has. He also thinks this is as good as it gets and it will never get any better. I have to admit that this might be as good as Labor can do and it might be as good as the Prime Minister can do, but it sure ain't good enough for the Australian people. If this is as good as the government can do, it is time they gave it away and let somebody else get on with running the country and achieving worthwhile things for our nation.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of specific matters I would like to address in relation to this legislation. This might seem to be a very small matter, but I think it is one of some significance and importance. Just over a year ago, there was a terrible bus crash in Brisbane which took the lives of a number of my constituents. An inquiry into that bus crash was undertaken—as has happened with many other similar accidents in Australia over recent years—and it was recently completed. In almost all of those inquiries—certainly the inquiry into the crash of the Maryborough bus—it was stated that lives almost certainly would have been saved if passengers in the bus had been wearing seat belts. In fact, the federal and state governments have agreed to make the fitting of lap-sash seat belts compulsory in all new coaches.

As new coaches are sales tax free, no sales tax applies to the seats and seat belts fitted to those vehicles. However, there are a small number of existing coaches which can be upgraded to meet the new safety standards with the fitting of new seats and lap sash belts. In cases where the seats and seat belts are retrofitted, incredibly, they attract sales tax at the rate of 22 per cent.

Coach operators are not obliged to upgrade their existing vehicles to meet the standards applying to new coaches. They can continue to operate them indefinitely. I am told that the cost of fitting modified seats and lap sash belts to an existing coach is approximately $35,000 per vehicle, a significant amount. The imposition of a 22 per cent sales tax on such an investment is an enormous disincentive for any coach owner to introduce such improved safety measures.

The Wide Bay Tours coach that was involved in the accident near Brisbane last year could not have been fitted with these seats. More often than not, the older coaches do not have adequate anchor points. You really need to build these in at the time the coach is constructed. But there are some coaches around, particularly those constructed in recent years, that could have the safer seating fitted.

I believe we should encourage the owners of those vehicles to fit the alternative seating. They should not be discouraged by harsh taxation. You really have to question the government's sincerity in endeavouring to upgrade coach safety when it imposes such a heavy tax penalty on those who voluntarily chose to install Australian Standards seats with lap sash seat belts.

I first raised this matter with Treasury in November last year. I sent subsequent reminder letters but I still have not been given the courtesy of a reply. Sadly, that is typical of Treasury. It seems to adopt a very arrogant approach to correspondence. It is common—in fact, it is the norm—to wait six, nine or 12 months to get a response to submissions put to it. That is disgraceful, and a discourtesy to members of parliament or anyone else who writes to make a constructive suggestion.

This is not a big revenue item. I have already mentioned that a lot of coaches are able to be retrofitted with these sorts of seats. Surely, if even one life was saved, there would be massive benefits to our community. If even one accident victim was less severely injured, the cost returns to the nation would be overwhelmingly realised.

I call on the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), who is actually in the chamber on a rare visit, to take this matter on board. I ask him to go back to the letter I wrote to Treasury in November last year, consider it carefully, and make a considered judgment on whether there should be a sales tax concession in these sorts of circumstances.

While dealing with sales tax matters, I would like to refer to another anomaly. I had the courtesy of a reply from the Assistant Treasurer on a matter I raised with him initially on 20 June 1994. I finally got a reply on 9 March 1995—about a nine-month turnaround, which is par for the course. Sadly, the answer, when I got it, was no.

With this particular matter—another safety matter—it was drawn to my attention that builders' safety cut-out boxes, which are an important electrical safety item, are subject to sales tax when they are a stand-alone item. If they were included in a product as part of a larger piece of machinery, the identical item would be sales tax free. Again, it seems to me that the general principle should be that matters essential to safety in the workplace—in many cases, things that are compulsory—should be sales tax exempt.

The minister's reply in this instance is really quite extraordinary.He admitted that there was an anomaly and said that there were a couple of ways it could be solved. One would be to exempt all goods of this nature from sales tax—I thought that was a commendable approach—but he was worried about the effects on his budget. He does not look at ways in which the government might be prepared to save money; he prefers to place workers' lives at risk by imposing this ever-increasing sales tax on a product which could help save many people from electrical injury.

He suggested that another way out of this anomaly would be to exempt from tax all products that require the safety cut-out box. That is a perfectly noble suggestion except that the minister completed his letter by saying, `The government does not propose at this stage to change the tax treatment for such items.' He admits it could be done, he admits it is an important safety feature, he admits there is anomaly but he will not do anything about it. Sadly, that is the approach so often taken by the government when anomalies in the current taxation system are drawn to their attention.

Our current tax law, for all its complexity and its attempts to stamp out avoidance measures, has become all the more complex and difficult to understand. In the process, every time changes such as those before us tonight are made, a new set of anomalies is created, a new set of distortions is put in place.

There needs to be radical reform of the tax system. This government thinks that this is as good as it can get. It is certainly time it stood aside and called the election tomorrow. Then let's get somebody in there who can fix these problems and ensure that our nation has a fairer and more appropriate tax system.

TALKER.NAME: Mr GEAR
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —If we want to talk about reform of the tax system—with a call for it from the opposition—maybe we could get a few clues from them about what sort of tax regime they would want. I see the member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) in the chamber. I know he was a bit embarrassed yesterday when he proposed that the GST—
—He let the cat out of the bag.
—I said yesterday that he was only saying publicly what others are saying privately.
—Don't misrepresent me, will you?

—I thought I was doing you a favour because I said you were only saying what your leader said a couple of months ago. It is not as if you were out of step with your leader. You were totally in step with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in saying that a GST had not been ruled out.
—He didn't say that.

—The opposition leader did; that was the headline. They talk about reform of the tax system—they are always calling for it—but there are never any details. Do you notice that about the opposition? It does not matter whether it is a debate on tax, higher education, law and order or social security—you can go through the gamut of what we debate here in this parliament—they always say that things could be better. They have a slim book over there with our words of our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on it but there is nothing inside. It is empty.
—There's nothing worth while saying.

—The Independent member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), who had to leave the Liberal Party, at least takes some interest in the tax system. I am not asking him to speak for the Liberal Party, because he is no longer a member of it. If he were, I am sure we would get some more detail from him. Sadly, he is an Independent. The previous speaker in this debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1995, the member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss), talked about the fact that this was a high taxing government—
—Sure is.

—How come the government in this budget, as a percentage of GDP, will raise $3,500 million less than your leader did when he was last Treasurer. If we had taxes at the same percentage of GDP that the Leader of the Opposition had, we would raise $3.5 billion more this year than he would have raised. So who is the highest taxer? It is the Leader of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: You talk about the complexity of the tax act; you talk about the number of pages. We used to have a simple tax system once—for the rich, that is. They had a choice of whether they paid it or not. That was when the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer. That was a simple tax system: `Will I pay tax or will I not? I don't think I will pay tax.' That was a simple system.

We had a real slim tax act back in those days. We did not have many people in the tax office. And look what happened: all of the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. It was not as if the Treasurer of the day was not warned. The tax office was up there begging him to do something about it, but he would not. That is the sort of tax system the Liberals ran the last time they were in government, and here they are preaching to us about how we should run our tax system.

There are a number of reasons for the number of pages in the tax act, for it being as voluminous as it is. The simple fact is that we put a lot of decent tax on the books—things like a capital gains tax and a fringe benefits tax, which the opposition never supported. What about the capital gains tax? Are you going to get rid of it? No. What about the fringe benefits tax? Are you going to get rid of it? No. You are not going to get rid of that one either. You did not support it when we brought it in here, but you have seen over time how decent these taxes are.

I know that the only reason you are not getting rid of them is that you cannot afford to. With all of the promises you are going to make in the next election campaign, you actually need the revenue that these taxes bring in. We know that is the real reason you are going to keep them—not out of any sense of decency. We had that debate, and the member for Curtin was here. He was a member of the Liberal Party then and he voted and spoke against them. He said that the sun would not come up tomorrow if we had a capital gains tax. He did not mention the fact that every other country in the world had one. The bottom-of-the-harbour schemes were made possible because we did not have a capital gains tax. You voted against the capital gains tax. And the fringe benefits tax. What a rort! Under the now Leader of the Opposition, if you had the choice why would you take all of your income in cash? You would be a mug. You would pay tax on it. The fringe benefits tax now is a fair tax.

We talk about compliance costs, and the previous speaker, the member for Wide Bay, spoke about compliance costs. I know a little about the compliance costs of the fringe benefits tax because, on behalf of the Treasurer (Mr Willis), I went around and spoke to firms about the compliance costs of the fringe benefits tax. We came up with a package, introduced a couple of weeks ago, which slashed the compliance costs of the fringe benefits tax.

I remind the House—the member for Menzies was here—about the shadow Treasurer. This shadow Treasurer is a beauty. He goes down to a tax forum in Old Parliament House—the old hairy chest, the big speech: `I am going to slash the costs of complying with the fringe benefits tax.' What happens? The next day, I introduce a bill to do just that and what do we get out of him? We got three little amendments, which he did not even move himself. He left it to the member for Menzies to move them. We saw three little amendments, which did nothing more than tinker with ours.

Do not kid us about compliance costs. We have seen how good you are. When the shadow Treasurer talks about tax reform, he has nothing up his sleeve but his arm. We know that now because we gave him the opportunity the day after he said he would slash compliance costs. He had nothing. I made the point before: when these people come around and talk to you about slashing compliance costs on the FBT, about cutting taxes or about doing anything with the tax system, do not believe them. They have nothing in the locker.

The other thing I said at the time we were debating the fringe benefits tax was that in most cases it is a voluntary tax. The government does not force firms to give people cars. The government does not force employers to say to people, `We will give you an around-the-world holiday,' or to pay any of the other expenses like a child's education expenses or private health insurance. We do not tell firms to do that. That is something they do themselves voluntarily. So if they are paying the fringe benefits tax, they are doing it because they choose to. Why do they not just cash it out? They would not be in the fringe benefits tax system any more.

So do not talk to us about reducing compliance costs or about simplifying the tax system because we know it is all rhetoric. If there was anything you had to do about the taxation system, surely we would have had a glimpse of it by now, apart from the suggestion of the member for Menzies and the Leader of the Opposition that the GST still burns in the old heart of the Liberal Party. There is no doubt about that. The GST is still there.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—You know. You should not shake your head. You walk around here and talk to the guys in the corridors and they all say, `That GST was a beautiful thing. We just didn't sell it properly.' Given the chance, you would put it back in again tomorrow.

PARA.TAB: The last thing I will say about the taxation system is that you talk about high taxes. We have actually reduced John Howard's 60c to 47c and the 30c to 20c. That is always forgotten. What about 30c reduced to 20c? You do not think that helps the battlers? And we collect $3,500 million less tax than John Howard did as a percentage of GDP. So there you are.

Lastly, you quoted Ray Regan. Anything Ray Regan has to say about Tax Pack or about the complexity of the tax laws is done out of vested interest. Ray Regan has a vested interest in making sure that people out there think we have a tax system which is just too insurmountable to tackle. He would like you to think that the Tax Pack was riddled with errors. You did not quote the tax ombudsman, but did you see what the tax ombudsman had to say about Ray Regan's complaints? He said they were basically baseless.

Do not worry about Ray Regan. Ray Regan will whip up a storm about Tax Pack. If we had not one error in it, he would be out there with a press release. He has the press releases written before we put the Tax Pack out. There is no doubt about that because he has a vested interest in driving people to use accountants. He is the president of the accountants association, so do not quote Ray Regan to us. We know where he comes from.

Let us get back to the bill. I have had a bit of fun here because I have been responding to some of the most outrageous claims we are getting from the opposition. I thought I would have to put them in their place. The member for Menzies and the Independent member for Curtin complained that the CFC amendments would have a retrospective effect. I remind members that the CFC provisions are anti-avoidance measures. The proposed amendments will simply overcome a weakness that has been exploited by parties seeking to escape accruals taxation on income that should be taxed under the CFC measures. The alternatives to their proposed treatment in the bill is to defer the commencement of the amendments by a year. That would allow all of these activities to flourish for another year and we are not going to do it.

There was also some debate about the Superannuation Guarantee Act, about the changes that apply for reconstructions after the date of effect; that is, 1 July 1992. I am informed that the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia suggests early application of the amendments on the basis that the Treasurer's December 1991 information paper canvassed successor scheme restructuring. Many things are canvassed in papers but subject to submissions, discussion and review. So it was with possible successor scheme rules.

The bill introduced in parliament on 2 April 1992 did not provide for employers to continue to contribute under a pre-1991 earnings base if they changed funds. It provided no successor scheme rule and parliament showed no intention of providing for such a rule in its consideration and passage of the bill which became the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 with effect from 1 July 1992.

Employers who restructured their superannuation schemes before 28 June 1994 did so in the knowledge that the law required them to use the standard ordinary time earnings base after the restructure. True, the possibility of a successor fund rule was discussed before the law was made, but the law foreshadowed when it was introduced before the date for which it was to apply included no such rule. Until the Treasurer's statement of 28 June 1994, no employer had any reason to expect to keep a lesser earnings base after restructuring superannuation funds.

Employers who bought a business or business assets and transferred the associated employees had no reason at all to expect to keep a lesser earnings base on the former employer's use for those employees. Not the December 1991 information paper, the April 1992 bill, or the parliament's consideration of it suggested such a possibility. These amendments led employers to avoid the administrative cost of changing the earnings base for their superannuation contributions.

The amendments apply from 1 July 1995 for restructures after the Treasurer announced these changes on 28 June 1994. Restructures before that time have already incurred the cost of changing to the standard base ordinary time earnings and restructures before that time were made with no reasonable expectation of going back to a lesser measure for superannuation contribution. For this reason, these amendments apply only in relation to restructures occurring after the Treasurer's announcement.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move opposition amendments Nos 1 and 2:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Schedule 1, page 7, item 20, omit "ending after 30 June 1995" substitute "commencing after 30 June 1995".
(2)Schedule 1, page 9, item 21, at the end of proposed section 46I add the following subsections:

" `(6) For the purposes of subsection (3), "transfer" means the movement of funds, whether by accounting entry or otherwise, where the company, in making the transfer, had the intention of facilitating the distribution to shareholders of an amount or amounts which would otherwise represent a distribution from a disqualifying account.'

`(7) An amount transferred from a disqualifying account to a non-disqualifying account which occurs pursuant to an order of the court under the Corporations Law shall not be taken to give rise to a credit under (3) above in the company's notional disqualifying account.'"

The first of the amendments to which I refer seeks to replace words `ending after 30 June 1995' with `commencing after 30 June 1995'. The Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) has already alluded to the reason. It involves a matter of retrospectivity. Let me say at the outset I have no objection to the intention of the clause to come to grips with avoidance practices. I made that abundantly clear in my speech on the second reading. This matter of retrospectivity has been raised by representatives of concerned taxpayers—notably, but not exclusively, the Corporate Tax Association.

PARA.TAB: I have covered many of my reasons in my speech in the second reading debate so I will not traverse the whole raft of those. On the matter of the changes affecting the tainted income of controlled foreign companies, CFCs, there is indeed a retrospective element. I think the Assistant Treasurer has acknowledged that in summing up the second reading debate. It applies to companies whose financial year, or tax years, if you prefer, did not end on 30 June 1995. The explanatory memorandum states—and I will go over that again:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the amendments will clarify that the Commissioner of Taxation may make adjustments, reflecting arm's length values, to amounts used in determining whether a CFC has passed the income test.

I regret that the Assistant Treasurer, for whatever reason, was not here during my speech on the second reading but I am sure he has got the gist of it from the advisers. The problem is that the government amendment, as it now stands, will be applied retrospectively for accounting periods ending after 30 June this year.

PARA.TAB: It is therefore axiomatic that part of the relevant tax year to attract this burden occurs before 30 June 1995 and therefore becomes taxable for that part of the tax year prior to 30 June last. Therefore, the measure is applicable from 1 July 1995 and, as a consequence, it will in some cases have a retrospective impact on the attributable income of CFCs. The amendment I am proposing to clause 20 of schedule 1 will ensure that no company which has a statutory accounting period other than one which involves the end of a financial year on 30 June will be affected by the application of the new tainted income rules.

I want to stress that not many companies do not wrap up their tax years or financial years on dates other than 30 June each year. Therefore, there is not much revenue involved in this. It is unquantifiable, I guess, but there is very little involved in this. That just makes it even more important to me that there should be an absence of retrospectivity and there is really no excuse for not treating taxpayers equitably. It is only fair.

Remember that it has only limited application. Because it has only limited application, it is not worth breaching a principle of abhorrence of retrospectivity which we should hold if we value certainty under the law. My proposal is only fair because, as the bill now stands, a company has, for example, a statutory accounting period ending on 30 September 1995, the tainted income provisions of this tax amendment bill becoming applicable from 1 October 1994—that being the beginning of that particular accounting period.

There is no need for revenue or other reasons. There is a good case to be made out on equity grounds for accepting this amendment. I just want to finish by saying that presence of retrospective legislation does undermine certainty, credibility and fairness in the tax system. Retrospectivity is a denial of natural justice, in my view, and a repudiation of fairness in that system. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mr GEAR
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be supporting either of these amendments. The first amendment, as I said in my closing comments, will defer the start of the CFC measures by a full year and that would allow the people who avoid the CFC to continue to do that for another year. For that reason we are not going to do it.

PARA.TAB: Turning to amendment No. 2, government amendments Nos 3 and 4 will address certain transfers pursuant to a court order but only where there is no arrangement to pay a dividend from the amounts transferred. It would not be appropriate to allow dividends from amounts transferred from disqualifying accounts to be rebatable or frankable, even if they were transferred pursuant to a court order. This is because these dividends could enable the reduction of taxable capital gains by corporate tax holders and franking credit trading.

Moreover, under the proposed new Corporations Law, transfers from disqualifying accounts will not have to be made pursuant to a court order. Therefore, the proposal by the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) would not be effective under the new Corporations Law regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the time of the House long because I spoke about this matter in my speech on the second reading. I just wish to repeat, without rehearsing the argument at length, that the opposition has sympathy for the amendment which has been moved by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) because, as he pointed out, it does have an element of retrospectivity and it does adversely affect at least a number of companies, as the Corporate Tax Association has pointed out in its submissions. The Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) has really advanced no good reason why these particular amendments should not be accepted.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.
