Part II of schedule 1 will ensure that dividends paid out of share capital and asset revaluation reserves will not be rebatable or frankable. This is an anti-avoidance measure. The amendments moved to schedule 1 will prevent the anti-avoidance measure from applying to ordinary commercial transactions.

PARA.TAB: Amendment No. 1 provides for the addition of a new disqualifying account in proposed section 46H of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. This new account will consist of shareholders' capital held in a statutory fund of a life assurance company and will enable the company to transfer share premiums to statutory funds without triggering adverse tax consequences.

Amendment No. 2 will amend proposed section 46H to exclude profits from the revaluation of assets held in the statutory fund of a life assurance company from the definition of the asset revaluation reserve disqualifying account. This will prevent adverse tax consequences arising from transactions of life assurance companies undertaken in the ordinary course of business.

Amendments Nos 3 and 4 provide that the provisions of the bill will not apply to certain transfers called excluded transfers. An excluded transfer is a transfer to offset accumulated losses that are permanent, a transfer from an asset revaluation reserve to reflect a reduction in the value of an asset or a transfer to make a distribution to participating policyholders. These amendments also ensure that if any part of the amount transferred is transferred under an arrangement to pay a dividend or to replace an amount from which a dividend was paid then the amount transferred will not be an excluded transfer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendments 5 and 6 amend part 3 of schedule 1 of the bill. That part proposes denying net capital losses incurred before a taxpayer's bankruptcy or release from debts under bankruptcy law. The main purpose of these amendments is to treat such taxpayers as incurring a capital loss if they pay a debt that was taken into account in calculating denied net capital loss. The amendment will bring the treatment of net capital losses more into line with the existing law's treatment of revenue losses.

PARA.TAB: Amendment 5 is a technical amendment to ensure that proposed subsection 160ZC(4A) achieves its intended effect. The amendment ensures that the provision will deny only the net capital loss of the year immediately preceding the bankruptcy or release from debts. This will, in turn, ensure that other amendments being made to this part of the bill do not give rise to multiple capital losses for the one payment and that the subsection does not deny earlier years' net capital losses that may already have been offset against capital gains.

Amendment 6 will ensure that a taxpayer who makes a payment in respect of the debt will be taken to have incurred a capital loss in the year in which the payment is made if the taxpayer incurred a net capital loss that is denied under proposed subsection 160ZC(4A) and the Commissioner of Taxation is satisfied that the debt was taken into account in working out the amount of the denied net capital loss. This amendment also specifies how to calculate the amount of the capital loss taken to have been incurred because of the payment.
Amendment 7 corrects a minor technical error in schedule 3, page 41 of the bill. I present the supplementary explanatory memorandum to the bill.

—My reason for moving the earlier amendments, which set out to do what I understand the government proposes to do with 2 1/4 pages of further amendments to the main bill, surrounds an absence of advice from the office of the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) which, despite liaison with it during most of yesterday, did not result in me receiving a copy of the amendments until something like 9.20 this morning, with the bill due to be debated at about 10.00 a.m. I did not get the explanatory memorandum that goes with the amendments until 10.15 a.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —A few weeks ago a virus deadly to the Australian feral rabbit population escaped from a fenced off quarantine area four miles off the coast of South Australia on Wardang Island. Apparently, it stayed on the island for some time. This virus—the rabbit calicivirus—was being tested by a consortium of the CSIRO, the state DPI and the Animal and Plant Control Commission of South Australia with, I understand, involvement from the New Zealand government, the NFF, the wool board, the Wool Corporation and so forth.

PARA.TAB: The escape raises the possibility that a vector—perhaps a bush fly or other carrier—is able to transfer the virus from one area or another with deadly result to the rabbit. Up till now scientists have only thought that the infection could move from one rabbit to another by very close physical contact.

The rabbit, apart from the advent of the European perhaps, has probably turned out to be the most effective imported destroyer of the environment in the history of this country—or probably, for that matter, in the history of any country. No feral animal has destroyed more vegetation and produced erosion and false drought than has the European rabbit in this country for 100 years. Even after the advent of the very successful myxomatosis virus, which has been operating for some 25 years, the numbers of rabbits are still in the tens of millions, and we are failing to handle the increase in those numbers at the present time.

There is no doubt that the number of rabbits got to a high of between 600 million and a billion in this country. I remember as a small boy seeing thousands of pairs of ears in the evening light—the ground bare, warren-ridden and pockmarked—and in some cases rabbits were 10 feet up the trees, ringbarking the bullock bushes as they went.

Some people earn a living out of rabbits at the present time as a sort of offshoot of this feral population by either shooting or harvesting them in some way or another. That is fine, but in this case all those people in effect are living off the destruction by the rabbit of private property and the destruction of our landscape.

There have been some statements in recent times, since this escape, which I would have to say are somewhat irresponsible. I refer to some statements by Dr Hugh Wirth. I know that Hugh Wirth for five or six years has felt, as President of the RSPCA, that we should be using more humane methods. But I would like to point out to him that since that time, five or six years ago, the debate has come a long way. Last year the Nature Conservation Council of New South Wales conducted a two-day seminar, the whole purpose of which was to discuss ways of eradication of feral animals in Australia. That was a big move when you think back to the animal liberation debate of only a few years ago.

We simply do not have the luxury of not using the good fortune that we may now have found ourselves in. We have found a vector to move this thing around. It is worth pointing out that this RCV virus is in 40 countries. So far it has never proved effective on anything but the European rabbit. Even other wild rabbits in other countries have not been affected, as I understand it. Some people obviously do not know what the current procedure is. As myxomatosis has become less effective, we are back to the old-fashioned methods of poisoning, bulldozing and what have you with the commensurate destruction of the environment in those areas where that is happening.

When the disease—as it is now on the mainland—is brought back under CSIRO control, which I hope happens in the near future, I hope that these experiments go on, because after 80 years of all the money and effort that we have put into trying to get rid of our most destructive imported pests it would seem to me to be ridiculous to go in any other direction. There are absolutely no positive results from the rabbit in Australia—not in any way whatsoever. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to speak about an issue that is dear to my heart, and that is the seven years of neglect of the Hunter region under the Fahey government. I particularly want to talk about facilities for young athletes in the region. Members opposite will probably not be aware that the Hunter has a greater population than Tasmania and contributes more to the GDP of this nation than most areas—indeed, more than the whole of Tasmania—yet we do not have a single first-class athletic facility. This is an area that is less than two hours drive from Sydney that is going to host the Olympics in the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: I was very pleased the other day to hear, less than six months after coming to power, Michael Egan, the Treasurer for New South Wales, indicate that he will pursue the establishment of a first-class facility in the Hunter region. It will be a regional facility, and hopefully it will be constructed on surplus railway land in the suburb of Glendale, which is in the electorate of my very good friend and colleague the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown).

This will mean that athletes in our area who do have a national and state ranking will be able to train seriously towards representing their country at the Olympic Games in Sydney in the year 2000. Athletes such as Katie Hall, Jacquie Munro, Mindy Slomka, Andrew Laverick, Lucas Moffat and Clinton Mackevicius—not all residents of my electorate but people from around the Hunter region—and dozens of others will now have the opportunity to train with first-class facilities, so guaranteeing that they will be competitive and that Australia will be proud of the effort that they put in.

Apart from that, the injection of $4 million, plus the availability of land on which this facility can be constructed, provides another avenue for helping young people in the Hunter region—and that is employment. I have already approached officers from the Department of Employment, Education and Training and I have approached my federal colleagues from the Hunter and suggested that we should look, under the Working Nation program, at training programs being involved in the development of these facilities. I am confident it will happen. After all, I am sure the skills that young people will learn as they are constructing these facilities will be in great demand in Australia in the lead-up to the Olympic Games. They will be constructing sporting facilities that will be in high demand, not only by Australian athletes but by athletes who will come here for up to 12 months before the Olympics actually take place to acclimatise themselves to Australian standards.

I cannot think of any better place to do that than in the Hunter region. Some will go to the Illawarra region. I am aware, Mr Speaker, of your interest in that area. Although it is not as good as the Hunter, it is still quite a good area and certainly close to the major competition centres.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that a reflection on the chair?
—I am sure that the member for Wide Bay would love some to go up there, but I am not sure what will attract them.
—A good member of parliament.

—Yes, but unfortunately they do not have one. Mr Speaker, I should not respond to interjections. I am looking forward to this. I sincerely hope that it will come to pass. I am confident that it will. Our athletes in the Hunter region can look forward to training in first-class facilities within a very short time.

—Tonight I would like to raise an issue highlighted by the Chairman of the CSIRO, Professor Adrienne Clarke, in her Brodie-Hall address in Perth the night before last. Professor Clarke is one of Australia's leading scientists. She mentioned that Australia risked losing control over one of the most powerful technologies reshaping today's society. She said in her speech that biotechnology is critical to Australia's future in agriculture, the environment and medicine. With the world population predicted to rise to at least 10 billion by the year 2050, biotechnology could transform agriculture and how food is supplied to the world's population.

PARA.TAB: What is biotechnology? In Professor Clarke's words, biotechnology is based on two key pieces of knowledge: firstly, we can grow cells of living organisms, plants, animals, bacteria and fungi in culture in artificial conditions and, secondly, we can isolate the genetic material that defines the nature of these cells and move these genes from one cell to another, known as genetic engineering. The main impact of this technology has been felt in agriculture and medicine, but applications in fields such as forensic science, security and mining are becoming commonplace.

Some examples of recent developments include the first engineered fresh tomato, now being sold in shops in the USA, and tomato paste is being manufactured from engineered tomatoes in the United Kingdom. The UK also has green cheese made genetically, and engineered rennet is marketed in the United Kingdom as green cheese, as it does away with using rennet from the stomachs of baby calves.

In the area of medicine, children in developing countries can now receive vaccine for cholera and hepatitis B by eating a genetically engineered banana. On the other side of the coin, biotechnology is all about ownership of that information. There are many controversial issues about patenting, access and equity of that information. Professor Clarke warned that Australia is in very real danger of missing the biotechnology train and being left on the outer, with little control over its developing future. At the moment, rights of advancements and new discoveries made in Australia are usually sold to overseas interests. That means Australia gives up the rights of core technologies and then in the future has to pay the price to use that technology. For example, for every chicken eaten in Australia a royalty is paid to overseas owners.

Professor Clarke said it is critical that Australia retain control over its own emerging and core technologies, and that this means substantial investment by Australian business in Australian research and commercialisation of products. She said that Australia has the scientific capacity within CSIRO, the universities and a few fledgling companies to be among the world leaders in a few carefully targeted areas. But Australia is a very small player on the international scene and probably accounts for between two and four per cent of all new knowledge in this area, which is about right for our size.

The question is whether Australia has the framework to retain control over the technology we do develop. Professor Clarke says that presently we probably do not. If Australia fails to change its approach to this issue, it runs the very real risk of losing control of this matter. Professor Clarke argued that a structure similar to the one which kick-started the film industry is essential to commercialise Australian discoveries in biotechnology. I ask the government to consider various policies which could encourage Australian companies to invest in Australian technology.

Senator Schacht, in his opening address at the last Pacific rim biotechnology conference, said that Australia was aiming to be a leader in innovations, science and advanced industry within the Asia-Pacific region. While Australia has the ability to be a leader in technology, we do not appear to be able to maintain Australian ownership of these rights. Our future is at stake and the government must provide leadership in this area and encourage a climate that is attractive to Australian companies and agencies investing in our technological future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is entirely accurate to say that all members of this House, irrespective of political differences, are agreed that the totality of Australia Remembers ceremonies, some large, some small, all enable this generation of Australians to pause, to take time, to publicly, openly and with a generosity of spirit say thank you to an earlier generation that had borne the brunt and the sacrifice that is endemic in a nation at war. Such moments are important to our sense of community, to our understanding of why we are and who we are.

PARA.TAB: Over many years, like other citizens of Melbourne, I have participated at dawn ceremonies and Anzac Day ceremonies. I have been moved to comment on those occasions that, while the ranks grew thinner, the audience grew larger. One aspect of that was the number of younger people, children, who not only attended but increasingly are now participating in those ceremonies.

It is equally true that other events on our calendar—Christmas and Good Friday—are occasions when, for the great majority of our citizens, the assertion of spiritual values transcend the material and commercial considerations that are so dominant for the rest of the year. Communities, like man, do not live by bread alone. These events are an essential part of our community and assert our values which are critical to our perceptions of ourselves and our Melbourne community.

I am appalled at the fact that the Victorian Premier, with the cosy complicity of his close friends who operate the Melbourne casino, has blithely accepted the proposition that this is the one major business undertaking that must be permitted to operate on the morning of Anzac Day, when ceremonies are taking place, and on Good Friday and Christmas Day—days of immense religious significance to members of my community. These are family days. These are days for personal reflections. These are days when `the money changers have no place in the temple'. I am bound to admit that I do not believe in a casino-led recovery, or in a gambling-led recovery. Gambling does not produce wealth: it redistributes it.

For the operators of the casino, it is a redistribution that is immensely profitable for them. For the Victorian government, it is about collecting an indirect tax, a tax that for the most part falls most heavily on those who cannot afford it. To the Premier who has sacked judges, limited rights to compensation, whose commitment to privatisation exceeds his commitment to social equity and justice, I say: enough is enough. Nobody believes that Anzac Day morning, Christmas Day and Good Friday are essential to the operations of a casino. These days are sacred days for the people of Victoria and Melbourne and they are not to be transgressed by the Premier on behalf of his friends.

It is, I think, important to remind honourable members opposite of the speeches that they made when this House took the important decision that Anzac Day was a day of national commemoration. I for one accept the sincerity of their commitments as the legislation received the unanimous endorsement of the House. These commitments do not live with the Victorian Premier's cosy complicity with the decision that fundamentally attacks those very commitments, with the decision that involves a placid acceptance that the Melbourne casino is the one and only business that can operate on Christmas Day, Good Friday and the morning of Anzac Day.

I believe the time is now appropriate for not merely members of the Victorian parliament but for members of this parliament to say to the Premier that that is not a position which is consistent with the commitment given on behalf of members of the opposition and unanimously passed by this parliament. Anzac Day and what it stands for are too important. These other sacred ceremonies are too important. They should not be cast aside in terms of the business interests of those who are in positions of power and, unfortunately, are close friends of the Premier of Victoria.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott The Hon R.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ELLIOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects. It includes four measures announced in the 1995-96 budget.

PARA.TAB: The bill will give effect to the 1995-96 budget announcement that dividends paid out of share capital funds and asset revaluation reserves will not be rebatable or frankable. This is an anti-avoidance measure which will apply to dividends paid after 7.30 p.m. Eastern Standard Time on 9 May 1995, unless declared before that time or paid under certain transitional arrangements.
The measure is expected to prevent a significant loss to the revenue.

The bill will give effect to the 1995-96 budget announcement to increase the infrastructure borrowings tax rebate from 33 per cent to 36 per cent. The increase in the rebate corresponds to the change in the company tax rate and will have effect from a taxpayer's 1995-96 income year.
The estimated cost to the revenue of the increase in the rebate is $2 million in 1995-96, $8 million in 1996-97 and $10 million in 1997-98.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Reduction of PAYE early remitter threshold

PARA.TAB: The bill amends the law to lower, from $5 million to $1 million, the threshold at which a group employer is treated as an early remitter. As a result, the twice monthly remittance arrangements will apply to group employers who have annual PAYE remittances in excess of $1 million per year.
The amendment will bring forward $275 million into the 1995-96 year of income.

In the 1995-96 budget the government announced an extension of the operation of the provision allowing for accelerated depreciation of trading ships. The concession will phase out on 30 June 2002 instead of 30 June 1997. This extension parallels the extension of the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987. That act provides a grant against the capital cost of purchasing an eligible Australian ship.
This measure will cost the revenue $11 million in 1997-98 and $16 million in 1998-99.

Employers who do not provide the minimum level of superannuation support for their employees are liable to pay the superannuation guarantee charge. Currently, this charge applies even if an employee has already accumulated superannuation entitlements in excess of the reasonable benefits limit or RBL. Superannuation benefits which are in excess of the RBL are taxed at the highest marginal rate in the hands of the recipient.

This bill will allow employees with accumulated superannuation entitlements in excess of the pension RBL to make an election not to receive superannuation support from their employers. When an employee makes the election, the employer will be exempted from the superannuation guarantee charge in respect of that employee. Employees who make this election will, however, be denied income tax deductions for personal superannuation contributions.
The measure will have minimal impact on the revenue.
The bill will amend the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 to extend the use of pre 21 August 1991 employee earnings bases if employers restructure their superannuation funds.

Under the existing earnings base regime, as soon as an employer transfers members to another fund or amalgamates funds, the employer loses the right to contribute under a pre 21 August 1991 earnings base. A new employer acquiring a business loses the right to contribute to the existing superannuation fund on the pre 21 August 1991 base available to the former employer. The bill proposes to extend the right to contribute under the same earnings base if members transfer to another of their employer's superannuation funds or a reorganisation of superannuation funds occurs in a business acquisition.

The measure is consistent with the government's general approach to superannuation policy, which is to encourage appropriate restructuring of superannuation arrangements to ensure that benefits are provided with the lowest possible administrative costs.

The amendments will take effect from 1 July 1995 for reorganisations which took place on or after the Treasurer's announcement of the measure on 28 June 1994.The amendments do not have any impact on the revenue.

The bill will give effect to the announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) on 26 February 1995 of the government's intention to strengthen and extend the provisions of the law that deny deductions for losses where debts are released under bankruptcy law.

The amendment will ensure that, where an annulment of bankruptcy occurs in connection with arrangements under which debts are or may be released, revenue losses will be denied as if the bankruptcy had not been annulled.

In addition, the bill amends the capital gains tax provisions to ensure that net capital losses are also denied where a taxpayer has become a bankrupt or is released from debts under bankruptcy law. The revenue gain will be less than $1 million per year.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Group certificates and other PAYE provisions

PARA.TAB: The bill amends the income tax law to require group employers to provide original group certificates to the Australian Taxation Office rather than to employees. The changes will facilitate the introduction of optical character recognition equipment by the Australian Taxation Office. The new equipment will be able to more efficiently and accurately capture employment income data and assist in identifying areas of potential noncompliance.

The amendments have provided an opportunity to generally modernise the group tax provisions of the law. For example, a new system of tax vouchers is being introduced to partially replace the outmoded tax stamp system, and the Commissioner will be able to apply excess PAYE credits against other debts owing to the Commissioner, in line with more recently enacted collection systems. The amendments also use a clearer drafting style and structure than the provisions they replace.
The amendments are expected to result in unquantifiable revenue savings through increased integrity of the income matching system and some public debt interest savings.

Australia now has a comprehensive system for taxing foreign source income. The first two parts of the system were the foreign tax credit system and the controlled foreign company measures. The foreign investment fund measures constitute the third and final part of the system.

The bill contains an amendment to the controlled foreign company measures that will reduce compliance costs and facilitate corporate restructures involving foreign companies. The amendment will have the effect that only capital gains and losses which accrue after a company becomes a controlled foreign company will give rise to attributable income.This amendment will result in an unquantifiable loss to revenue.

The bill also contains three amendments that close potential tax avoidance loopholes in the foreign source income provisions. First, the rules for obtaining a foreign tax credit will be tightened to ensure that a credit is not available for tax which is effectively refunded to the payer or to another person. A credit will also be denied where a benefit is provided as a direct result of the payment of foreign tax.
Secondly, the amendments will clarify that adjustments reflecting arms-length values can be made to amounts used in determining whether a controlled foreign company has passed the active income test.

Thirdly, rules will be introduced to ensure that the controlled foreign company measures are not avoided by the liquidation of a controlled foreign company prior to the end of the period for which its attributable income is calculated.
The closure of these loopholes will result in an unquantifiable gain to revenue.
The bill also makes a minor technical amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Drought Relief Measures) Act 1995.
Full details of the amendments are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable members.

I also foreshadow that the government will be moving amendments to the bill in the House relating to the rebatable and frankable dividends, bankruptcy and superannuation guarantee charge—notional earnings base provisions. Copies of those amendments and a supplementary explanatory memorandum have been circulated to members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill gives effect to an important element in the government's package of shipping reform measures which was announced in the budget on 9 May 1995. The reform package continues the improvement in efficiency and competitiveness of Australia's major trading fleet, and assists in closing the competitive gap between Australian shipping and its major international competitors.

PARA.TAB: This bill introduces from 1 July 1995 an annual taxable grant payable in arrears to Australia's international shipping industry employers, based on the PAYE tax liabilities of seafarers on Australia's international trading ships. In addition to the introduction of the grant under this bill, the reform package includes two other key elements:

Firstly, the extension from 1 July 1997 until 30 June 2002 of the existing capital assistance measures available under the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987 and the associated accelerated depreciation regime under section 57AM of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. These measures, which at least equate to the capital incentives provided by other shipping nations, will encourage the continued investment in modern ships. The necessary amendments to the two acts will be introduced in due course.

Secondly, the implementation of the complementary industry efficiency reform measures developed by the shipowners and maritime unions in the Maritime Industry Restructuring Agreement, known as MIRA. These include a greater flexibility in the operation of the seafarers engagement system (the pooled labour scheme for ratings) and other measures which provide ship operators with the kind of cost savings and other benefits more generally associated with company employment.

The Australian Shipowners Association has estimated that, across the current major trading fleet (which includes both coastal and international trading ships), savings of some $15 million per year can be achieved under MIRA. The reform measures introduced by MIRA will also deliver cost savings and efficiencies to the offshore industry supply fleet which services Australia's offshore petroleum and gas industry.

The structure of the government's reform package is based upon the recommendations of the August 1994 report by the then Chairman of the Shipping Industry Reform Authority, Mr Rae Taylor AO. This report recognised the achievement of the reform programs implemented by government and the shipping industry since the early 1980s. These reforms had focused on reductions in crewing levels, a radical restructure of seafarer training and the introduction of modern, technologically advanced, fuel efficient ships into the Australian fleet.

Over the past decade Australian shipowners have invested some $1.6 billion in new tonnage. The average age of ships in the Australian fleet is 11 years, compared with 18 years in the world fleet. In 1983, a typical Australian trading ship had a crew of 33; today, that figure is 18. While in 1983 the Australian average crew size was well in excess of OECD levels, our crew levels are now lower. These are remarkable achievements.

Over recent years there has been a trend by OECD national flag operators towards registering their vessels under open or international registers. These registers typically offer attractive taxation regimes and the ability to replace wholly national crews with lower-cost mixed nationality crews, predominantly from the developing countries.

The Taylor report found that, as a result of this changed overseas situation, the competitive gap between Australian ships and comparable overseas ships operating under international registers was about $2 million per ship per year. The report, having examined the main areas of cost disabilities affecting Australian shipping, concluded that the PAYE taxation regime had a major impact on Australia's competitive position. Accordingly, the report recommended removal of the PAYE taxation cost element from Australia's international trading ships in order to match the position of overseas ship operators, where crews are exempt from PAYE taxation or where the taxation impact on crew costs is offset by other concessions.

The government accepted the thrust of the Taylor report findings. After examining a range of options in the crew taxation area, the government has decided that a grant based on the notional tax liabilities of seafarers serving on ships trading internationally would be the most effective and practicable means of achieving the objective. The bill now before the House introduces from 1 July 1995 an annual taxable grant payable in arrears to Australian shipping industry employers, based on the notional PAYE taxation liabilities on the earnings of Australian-resident crew members on ships in Australia's international trading fleet. Seafarers will, of course, have their PAYE tax deducted in the normal way and, like every other taxpayer, will be able to claim the rebates and deductions to which they are entitled in respect of their total earnings for the year.

I now turn to the details of the International Shipping (Australian-resident Seafarers) Grants Bill.Part 2, which takes in clauses 3 to 7, explains the expressions and definitions used in the bill. Clause 3 defines an `eligible ship' to mean `an Australian-operated commercial trading ship with a deadweight tonnage of 2,000 tonnes or more'. Clause 4 defines an `Australian-operated' ship to include ships on demise charter to Australian entities, as well as ships owned by Australians.

Clause 5 defines the meaning of `international voyage'. This is an important definition, as time spent on international voyages is one of the key criteria for qualifying for the grant. Calls at intermediate Australian ports as part of an overall international voyage are permitted, provided that any coastal cargo carried between Australian ports does not exceed the international cargo on board. In clause 7 are to be found general definitions, such as `seafarer', `Australian-resident seafarer' and `seafarer berth'. These again are important definitions as the grant is only payable in respect of bona fide, duly qualified seafarers who are ordinarily resident in Australia.

I would mention at this point that the term `seafarer berth' is used throughout the bill in the sense of a crew position or job on a ship, rather than simply a cabin or a bed. By adopting the concept of the seafarer berth and using the notional tax on the award wages or enterprise agreement wages, as applicable for that berth, the computation of the grant amount is reduced to a relatively straightforward calculation.

Part 3 of the bill, which covers clauses 8 to 12, contains the elements for establishing the entitlement to the grant and calculating the grant amount. Clause 8 sets the basic parameters for entitlement to the grant. Essentially, the grant is payable to the employer of the crew of an eligible ship which has spent the requisite number of days in international trade. Clause 9 sets out the method of calculating the amount of grant unit for each seafarer berth. Factored into the grant calculation is the number of days in the year that each berth is actually occupied by an Australian-resident seafarer. Therefore, if any berths are occupied by nonresidents, or if any berths are unoccupied during a repair or lay-up period or because the ship is sailing short-handed, then the grant units calculated for those berths will be reduced proportionately. The grant amount is simply the sum of the grant units for the seafarer berths on the ship.

Clause 10 establishes the eligible employment period, which is the period in respect of which the grant is paid. This clause also determines that the grant is to be paid to the actual employer of the crew and that the employer must be an Australian entity.

A number of ship operators in Australia appoint a management company to look after the day-to-day running of the ship, including crew related matters such as paying salaries and making the PAYE tax deductions. In such circumstances, it would be the management company that is the actual employer, not the operator. Because of the notional linkage between the grant and crew PAYE income tax, it follows that the employer of the crew is the appropriate recipient of the grant. Clearly, if the employer and the ship operator are not the same entity, they will need to reach a commercial agreement on the allocation of the grant moneys once paid.

If the employer employs the crew on a ship for the whole year, the `eligible employment period' is the whole year. If the employer only employs the crew for a part year, then the `eligible employment period' would only apply to the part year. These eligible employment periods are not transferable. For example, if during the period covered by the first employer the ship is wholly engaged in international trading and during the period covered by the second employer the ship is mainly engaged in coastal trading, the international trading days accrued by the first employer could not be transferred to the second employer.

Clause 11 sets out the formula for calculating the minimum number of days in international trading to qualify for the grant. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will note that the formula excludes non-operational days of repair, maintenance or lay-up from the minimum days calculation. There will thus be no advantage for an operator to obtain repairs, or lay-up the ship, overseas simply in order to accumulate more international trading days. However, once a ship has crossed the minimum days international trading threshold, the grant is payable in respect of the berth occupancy over the full eligible employment period, which would include any days of repairs, maintenance or lay-up. The grant will be paid annually in arrears after receipt of appropriate documentation from the employer.

The amount of grant is determined by clause 12 of the bill. The grant payable is the sum of the notional tax liabilities calculated on the award or enterprise agreement wages relating to the various seafarer berths on the ship. The method of determining eligibility and calculating the amount of grant is very straightforward and will not impose a significant administrative workload on the employer in substantiating a claim for a grant.

The arrangements will be administered by the Department of Transport, with the departmental secretary being the nominated decision-maker in respect of applications for grants. There are appropriate safeguards in the bill to enable authorised persons appointed by the secretary to make any necessary investigations to verify the substance of claim applications and to prevent fraud.

In common with other legislation involving administrative decisions, clause 22 of the bill provides for an Administrative Appeals Tribunal review, if there is dissatisfaction with a decision made in relation to a claim for a grant. The bill also facilitates parliamentary scrutiny of the scheme. Clause 25 requires the secretary to submit to the minister of the day a return of the grants paid in the previous year, and for the minister to table the return before both Houses of Parliament within 15 sitting days.

Mr Deputy Speaker, through this bill, the crew taxation disadvantages for Australian operators will be eliminated. Furthermore, by providing the benefit direct to employers, the whole amount will be directed to narrowing the competitive gap. This bill, together with the industry reforms implemented through the maritime industry restructuring agreement, will promote a more competitive international fleet. It must be remembered that, as recently as 25 years ago, Australian shipping had minimal involvement in international trades. Now there are some 30 ships regularly trading overseas. These ships are competing directly with overseas operated vessels at prevailing international freight rates, largely by exploiting market niches. This government's previous shipping reform measures have played a major role in this achievement.

The grant to be implemented by this bill is an integral part of a new shipping reform package which raises the benchmark for Australian shipping and provides the wherewithal to take the industry into the next century. It continues the cooperative reform process begun in the early 1980s and provides new initiatives to allow Australian shipping to improve its competitiveness in the international shipping market.
I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will commence my remarks on behalf of the opposition today by stating that we are opposed to the International Shipping (Australian-resident Seafarers) Grants Bill 1995 and that we will be dividing on it. How we handle that in the management of affairs in this chamber I do not know. As I understand it, Mr Deputy Speaker, this chamber is for non-controversial legislation. However, we will be opposing it and dividing on it, so if you want me to proceed I shall.

PARA.TAB: The reason we will be opposing this legislation is that this is simply yet another rort for the Maritime Union of Australia, the great friends of the Labor Party here in Canberra and around Australia. As the ACTU secretary, Mr Bill Kelty, will tell you, the Maritime Union of Australia is the heart and soul of the Labor movement in Australia, and it is for this reason that the taxpayers of Australia are dipping into their pockets to the tune of $19 million, in this specific instance, as they have been dipping into their pockets, or the government on their behalf has been dipping very deeply into their pockets, over the last many years to fund the rorts of the Maritime Union of Australia in various activities this government has embarked upon for them.

In this particular case we are spending $19 million of taxpayers' funds as the consequence of a deal that was struck to try and resolve a dispute that I think basically revolves around the privatisation of ANL. We can all recall a strike that took place last year as a consequence of the decision by the government to sell the share of Australian Stevedores, now known as Patricks, that was owned by ANL. You will recall a dispute that took place at that time, a national waterfront strike that cost this country probably in the order of $60 million in direct costs and many millions of dollars more in terms of indirect costs because of the enhanced reputation for unreliability this country has for its waterfront. As a result of that dispute, the government decided to do yet another taxpayer funded deal for its mates in the Maritime Union of Australia, and here we are today with living evidence of the cost of that deal.

There are many other examples of the way in which this government has reached deep into the pockets of the Australian taxpayers to fund the rorts of its mates. Today in the press, in relation to the sale of ANL, which is a central feature of the Australian shipping industry and indeed is seen as an icon by the Maritime Union of Australia, we see the farce, and the very expensive farce, of the incompetence of the government's management of the sale of ANL. It reflects also the incompetence of the government's management of our shipping and maritime industries here in Australia.

We now find out that we are not likely to have the sale of ANL to P&O proceed, as we had been told would be the case by the government since early this year. The Maritime Union of Australia has in effect vetoed the sale of ANL to P&O on the grounds that it basically does not like P&O. There has been a historic fight between the Maritime Union of Australia and P&O, and as a consequence of it this government has handed over to the Maritime Union of Australia the veto rights on the privatisation of ANL. We see that the Maritime Union of Australia has done exactly what people predicted would be done, and that is use that veto to stop the sale and to leave the ANL shipping company in the hands of the Australian government.

The cost of that is enormous. We are seeing in this legislation today $19 million worth of taxpayer funded rorts for the Maritime Union of Australia. But, if you look at the way in which this government has bowed to the whims and fancies of the Maritime Union of Australia over the sale of ANL, the cost of that to the Australian taxpayer is over $100 million dollars. Indeed, somewhere in the order of $145 million is the cost of the fiasco of ANL. That is the cost of this government's bowing down to the influence and pressures the MUA has imposed on the government over the management of and ultimate attempt to privatise ANL. It is some $145 million, plus $19 million per annum, plus the $816,000 that has been paid to Neville Wran, Malcolm Turnbull and one other member of the ANL board.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mates.

—Mates of the current Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton. That is $816,000 for part-time work over the last 12 months. Two days a week for one year and people like Neville Wran and Malcolm Turnbull are picking up something in the order of $300,000 for themselves. As a consequence of that, a total $816,000 has been shared amongst the three mates of the government.

PARA.TAB: So we start to see the bill adding up: $19 million for the shipping legislation; $145 million for the fiasco of ANL; and $816,000 for the three mates of the Minister for Transport led by Neville Wran. We also see the cost of the redundancies within the Shipping Industry Reform Authority process which amounted to something like $17.39 million and was yet another taxpayer funded rearrangement of the affairs of the Australian shipping industry. That makes a total cost of $71.29 million, of which $53.9 million was paid by employers, as well as the part paid for by the government of Australia.

Then if we look at the waterfront operations of Australia, which are an integral part of the Maritime Union of Australia, we come up with an additional bill of $450 million which was paid to some 4,000-odd retiring wharfies who were made redundant as a consequence of the government's so-called Waterfront Industry Reform Authority program. That $450 million was on top of the normal superannuation, accumulative sick leave and long service leave payments that those 4,000-odd retiring wharfies received as part of the government's reform process.

We start to draw together a very expensive picture of the way in which the government does business with the Maritime Union of Australia: $450 million for the MUA wharfies; $53.9 million for the Shipping Industry Reform Authority; $816,000 for the three mates; then another $145 million for the losses of ANL; and now $19 million for the legislation that is being debated here today. In anybody's book, that is an enormous amount of money for very little gain.

We question a number of points made in the speech given by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Dr Theophanous). He was simply reading a speech prepared by the minister's office, which he did with some degree of competence. For example, the government likes to use the great line which says that crew numbers of Australian ships are equal to those of international shipping trading nations. It is true, crew numbers are equal, but the fact of the matter is that crew to berth ratios in Australia for Australian flag vessels are much higher than those of most other shipping nations around the world.

It takes 2.3 crew to fill every berth on an Australian ship. A comparable nation with a much more efficient shipping industry would require about 1.7 crew per berth to fill each position on its ships. So here in Australia, because of the work practices in our maritime industry—six weeks on, six weeks off, somebody on sick leave, somebody on long service leave and somebody doing some training—it requires more crew to keep an Australian flag vessel operating than it does vessels from other countries.

We can draw other comparisons in terms of wages. Many people would point out that, even with comparable nations, Australian crews are paid more money than those in other nations. No doubt the government members would try to draw a comparison by saying, `You're comparing us with Burmese workers or Filipino workers.' No, we are not. We are comparing our sailors with sailors from countries which are like-minded countries to Australia.

Despite all of the costs that the Australian taxpayers have had to fork out, despite all of the talk, all of the time and all of the effort involved in trying to generate shipping reform in Australia, we still do not have a shipping industry that is competitive on all of the important points with other shipping nations.

The reason is that the MUA will not allow these things to occur. The MUA, for some reason, is so important that this government will not stand up to it, and will not do anything but dip into the taxpayer's pocket to try to solve the problem. Here today we have an example of precisely that: the taxpayers having another $19 million ripped out of their pockets by this government, to try to solve a little domestic problem for the labour movement in Australia.

If we really wanted to have an efficient shipping industry, be it international or domestic, we could move towards company employment. I know that the government says, `Yes, but we are going down the path that achieves similar results as company employment.' But you will not achieve the same results unless you have company employment, as is the case in so many other countries around the world.

We will not have an efficient and competitive shipping industry until all of the recommendations of the Rae Taylor report are implemented. It is interesting to note that the parliamentary secretary, reading his speech prepared by the minister's office, said that the government has picked up the main parts of the Taylor report. That is true. But they left out some other key aspects of the Taylor report, and the reason they left those key aspects out was simply that the MUA did not agree with them.

If we want to start to go down the path of having an efficient world competitive shipping industry that this country can be proud of, earning real dollars that do not cost the taxpayers money, there are many good recommendations in the Taylor report which, if they were picked up in total, would benefit the Australian economy.

In the same way, if the recommendations of the Inter-State Commission report of 1987-89, which flowed from the Webber report of 1984-86, were picked up in their entirety and implemented as a package—instead of some of the points from that report being selectively taken up, and some others dropped—we would have an efficient and internationally competitive waterfront in Australia. We do not have an efficient Australian waterfront because this government did not pick the hard bits of the Inter-State Commission's recommendations of April 1989, just as they have not picked up the hard bits of the Rae Taylor report of last year, in relation to the shipping industry in Australia.

There are a number of factors that have to be considered in this debate. One factor is the cost of the grant. When the government first announced the provision of a tax-free status for international seafarers, it was supposed to be a tax arrangement. It was not intended, as far as we could understand, to be given in the form of a direct grant. It is interesting to note that this grant is valued at about $19 million a year. You watch over the next few years, as coastal traders start to rearrange their schedules to ensure that they are eligible for the grant as well. I will bet my bottom dollar on the fact that those people in the coastal trades will see an opportunity to get some money for themselves out of this scheme; they will make rearrangements to their schedules, and they will have their snouts in the trough by getting into this grant system as well.

Instead of this grant costing us $19 million a year, as the government is boldly predicting, we can expect the cost to blow out several times over. We are going to see more and more money being poured down the throats of the Maritime Union of Australia and the government's mates.

People on this side of the House have real concerns about this legislation. We oppose it, and we oppose it strongly. Our principal motivation is that the people of Australia have had an absolute gutful of this government bending over backwards to satisfy the concerns of the Maritime Union of Australia and its members. You do not see this government bending over in the same fashion to satisfy the concerns of many other Australians. Take, for example, the drought-stricken farmers that this country has had over the last couple of years. Have you seen the government acting with equal generosity—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—Overwhelmingly yes.

—Okay, there we have members of the government saying yes. You should compare the cost of your drought assistance package with the cost of the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority. Compare the numbers of people who benefited from each—4,000-odd wharfies, $450 million, as against the numbers of farmers in Australia who benefited from the drought reform package. I think that package was worth $260 million, among many tens of thousands of farmers. These people—
—If tens of thousands of farmers had been affected by the drought they would have got it.

—Tens of thousands of farmers were affected by the drought; they got a fraction of the benefits provided by this government for a few thousand wharfies—4,000. That is $100,000 payment on average, for the average wharfie who was made redundant. You should look at the numbers of people being employed in the shipping industry in Australia and just compare what that works out to in terms of cost per employee, just out of the grant that you are seeking to pass in legislation here today.

PARA.TAB: I tell you there is no sector in Australian society today which has benefited financially from this government—per employee, per person—as much as the maritime industry of Australia. No other sector in Australian society has received more generous treatment than the way this government has treated maritime industry employees. That is what people have had a gutful about, because you are treating people in a way that is not equitable. It is here in this legislation and, over the past few years, in the way you have handled shipping industry reform, waterfront reform, and indeed the way in which you have handled the privatisation of ANL. There in your management of ANL you have allowed losses of that company to run up to $145 million—losses that we as taxpayers will have to take up. This is not going to be covered by a payment if you can ever sell ANL to P&O—which is not going to happen now. If you look at the losses that we are going to have to pick up you will see that it is $145 million that you have clocked up for the poor old Australian taxpayer.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! I ask the honourable member for Hume—I do not wish to sound too sensitive—to refer his remarks through the chair and be a bit more judicious with his use of `you'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly. I was not referring to you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Certainly I will follow the forms of the House. On looking at all of those things the House will see an enormous amount of money that has been spent by this government in one way or another, either through the losses in such shipping companies as ANL or through direct grants such as the ones that are being discussed here in the legislation before the House. The House will see an enormous amount of money going down the drain.

PARA.TAB: Look at the way the government has handled the privatisation of ANL. When it announced that you could not give ANL away—remember that the Minister for Transport said in that famous press conference, `You could not give it away'—ANL, according to the analysis of most people, indeed several consulting firms, accounting firms and even the Auditor-General's assessment of ANL at the time, giving a positive valuation, was roughly valued at $28 million. That was on the day the Minister for Transport declared, `You could not give it away.'

Because of his actions, his decisions, his incompetence, his preparedness to bend over backwards to the MUA, ANL—if you can sell it today after all this fooling about—will be worth nothing. The taxpayers, as we have seen in this House, will have going through the House a grant of $15 million being made available to assist in the sale of ANL. I forgot to add that to the bill. So add $15 million to all the other handouts that we have had for the shipping and waterfront industries and you can see for yourself that this government has poured an enormous amount of money down the drain when it comes to the waterfront and our shipping industries.

It might be justifiable to do that if, at the end of the day, we were going to have a world competitive shipping industry or a world competitive waterfront industry. But the fact of the matter is we do not now and we will not, as a consequence of this legislation or other actions undertaken by the government.

So all this money is being wasted. All this money is being wasted and achieving nothing, in terms of helping to make Australia a more competitive and efficient nation and helping Australian businesses to export more products so that we can create more jobs. At the end of the day, all of this is designed to create more jobs. If we have a world efficient waterfront and a world efficient shipping industry, we will create more jobs for Australians.

Is it any wonder that we have 8.5 per cent official unemployment and probably 14 or 15 per cent unofficial unemployment? Is it any wonder, when we have a waterfront that is inefficient and is not cost competitive, as is the case in Australia, and we have a shipping industry which is not cost competitive?

If we are to take the broader interests of the Australian community to heart, as should be the job of a government, we should be trying to develop as efficient and cost-effective an Australian maritime industry as possible, because the consequence of that will be that we create more jobs for Australians in downstream industries.

But this government is not interested in doing that. That is why we have an 8.5 per cent official unemployment level and a great deal higher unofficial unemployment level in Australia. The reason for that is the government's inability to tackle hard areas of reform, such as the waterfront, the shipping industry, the privatisation of companies such as ANL and industrial relations reform in Australia. It has reformed many other facets of Australian life but, when it comes to industrial relations reform, it has been a softly, softly, pour out the money approach that this government has taken.

For all of those reasons, the opposition will be opposing this. We believe that the Australian taxpayer has had an absolute gutful of having to fork out more and more money to the maritime industries of Australia to get a second best service out of the maritime industries of Australia. I think it is time the people of Australia stood up to this sort of rort, and we are going to do it on their behalf.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me touch on a couple of things that the previous speaker, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp), mentioned. He was talking about other countries in the world; he did not touch on the fact that other countries in the world have very similar taxation arrangements in relation to their shipping industries to those in the International Shipping (Australian-resident Seafarers) Grants Bill 1995. Most of the bill and the agreements that formulated the bill came from other countries' arrangements. Most shipowners should be, and are, well aware of the sorts of arrangements whereby other countries give great assistance to their shipping industries to make sure that they are committed.
—Which ones?

—In the Northern Hemisphere there are a considerable number. Most countries in the world give very strong support to their shipping industries, because of shipping's great importance to a country. Most countries are well aware of the importance of their coastal shipping and their international shipping.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—The honourable member should not encourage interjections by replying to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. I will not do that.

PARA.TAB: Of course, this was not acknowledged by the previous speaker at all. He implied that this bill had come out of somebody's head and had no relationship whatsoever to international shipping. Well, this bill does.

Of course, the coalition mentions selling. The coalition has always had a history of selling anything which is Australian, never protecting, never exploiting and never getting into encouraging Australia.

Mr Sharp mentioned wharfies, and he was great at building up what a wharfie got to retire on. I do not think wharfies retire on a lot of money; I am sure that most of us in this House will retire on a lot more than the wharfies retire on. It is a very poor comparison to make. Getting stuck into people who work on the waterfront and who have been made redundant or retired from their job, and somehow giving them a free kick—because kicking wharfies goes down great at a farmers' meeting—is pretty old hat. In today's world, we should be a bit broader in our views. We often hear that we should be looking at industrial relations in a different light and treating things in a different way. We still do not get that from the other side of the House. As I said, it is still looked at in terms of getting a free kick and kicking wharfies at a farmers' meeting. The opposition thinks this gains it some electoral advantage, but the country does not gain at all.

The previous speaker also said that other countries, when compared with Australia, had much cheaper shipping. He said that we cannot use crews from the Philippines or Burma which the other countries use. He did not name the other countries because he knows that it is practically impossible to do so. He knows that the reforms that have already taken place in Australia make our shipping rates comparable with the rest of the world.

Some other countries have incredibly bad histories in regard to treatment of their seafarers. The honourable member would be well aware of the Ships of shame report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. He would be aware of this bad treatment in other countries and of the ships that other countries allow to sail the seas of the world. Australia should not be ashamed of its high standard of income and its conditions for seafarers. It should not be ashamed that it sets standards for the rest of the world to come up to. We should not back down. We should not be the lowest common denominator when paying wages: people should not get paid after three months; they should not have dreadful conditions and food. The previous speaker was trying to get us sucked into that and we should not be sucked in.

He also said that farmers received a lot less than wharfies or seafarers. I thought that was a very poor analysis of the government's assistance. Farmers, in my electorate, have received very good assistance. I am very proud to say that we were able to assist those who needed assistance due to the droughts in Tasmania. RAS has put millions and millions of dollars into rural Australia. Farmers make great gains from reforms that have already occurred on the waterfront through technologies. I went to the terminal at Botany Bay where 50 per cent reform has occurred in the container area. A lot of that has to do with technology and electronic transfers. When things come in containers, the computers take over when they hit the waterfront. The wharfie driving the forklift gets the information and is better able to stack the yards. When the ship comes in, it is much easier. Those sorts of reforms have taken place and the whole economy of Australia gains from that, including our rural sector.

The purpose of the bill is to provide a system of grants to Australian shipowners who undertake international voyages. The grants will place Australian ship operators on a more equitable footing with their overseas competitors in respect of crew costs and provide an incentive for the Australian shipping industry to develop new international trading opportunities. The bill came about because of the restructuring in the shipping industry and the fact that the Australian government's principal objective is to ensure that Australian shippers have continuing access to competitive and efficient liner shipping services which are crucial to expanding trade interests.

In September 1994, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), cabinet ministers, the ACTU and maritime unions met to negotiate an industry reform package. As a result of negotiations, the Treasurer, Mr Ralph Willis, announced that the government had agreed to an introduction of a taxable outlays grant to be paid to owners and operators of Australian registered ships predominantly engaged in international trade. It would offset the impact on owners and operators of personal income tax on the earnings of seafarers on Australia's eligible international trading ships.

It should be noted that international shipping is important to Australia because it carries $35 billion worth of goods into Australia and $43 billion worth of exports from Australia. Currently, around 30 Australian operated ships are engaged in international trade. On this basis, the value of grants payable in respect of the first year, 1995-96, will be $19 million payable in arrears in 1996-97.

It is a pity that the other part of the arrangement, whereby the unions were looking at developing a consortium to acquire a majority interest in ANL with the government returning a minority shareholding, could not be shaken up and shaken out and made to happen. The unions have come a long way down the track in their reform package, including looking at the reduction in crew sizes, the crewing factors and changes to their employment arrangements. But it seems that it will still be a long time before Australians know whether we will still have a shipping line which we can call Australian or whether we will be at the whim of other nations.

The terms of agreement under which this bill was formulated were that the government was planning not to liquidate ANL but to restructure it, which, of course, may make it an economically viable enterprise. It was recognised that the competitiveness of ANL and other Australian international shipping operators depends on a range of factors, and they include taxation and industrial arrangements. Although this bill might go part of the way to ensuring that Australians still crew ships working in and out of Australia, it does little to ensure the integrity of the Australian shipping industry with an Australian owned shipping line.

The idea for this bill came forward as there was general knowledge among shipowners of other developed nations that they had access to their countries' special fiscal arrangements that were not available to Australian shipowners. There is a seven per cent taxable capital grant available but not all ships qualify for this as there are many ships which are chartered by Australians from foreign owners, and the grant does not apply to ships which are chartered or leased from non-Australians.

Most shipowners knew with precision the details of a wide variety of assistance measures made available in a number of OECD countries which were not available in Australia. Japan, the United States of America, France, Germany, Denmark and the United Kingdom were used as examples of differing approaches to international shipping industries. This intelligence was used to demonstrate the impact of different measures on the cost regime of Australian ships. The measures tested had to be commercially, politically and industrially sensitive and had to have equal application to vessels being operated by owners in a variety of commercial circumstances. The common factor was reduction in labour costs, but it was thought this should not be done at the expense of employees on the ships. So it was decided to look at the Danish idea of removing the PAYE element from the employer's gross payroll and that was adopted.

It was industrially neutral as it did not encourage the employment of foreign nationals; it was of equal benefit to all operators as it reduced labour costs; and it was politically sustainable as it would apply to Australian taxpayers who were absent from the country for a very substantial period during the year. Thus there was no change to the employees' net pay. So this bill should assist in the growth of Australian shipping.

In 1993-94 foreign shipping carrying Australia's external trade accounted for about $2.5 billion of our deficit on net services in the current account. This represented, by itself, 15 per cent of the current account deficit in 1993-94. Any growth of Australian participation in the carriage of Australian external trade will directly contribute to a reduction in the deficit on services in the current account analysis.

It seems that operators of coastal shipping are already rearranging their shipping schedules to ensure the eligibility of their ships for a grant under the terms of this bill. The effect of this will be to reduce the operating costs of those ships and the resultant savings will directly benefit the users of coastal shipping services. So although I believe this bill will be useful to help Australian owned and crewed ships, I would still like the whole arrangement to be considered so that ANL still remains part of our culture and our industry, and is owned by Australia. I have great pleasure in supporting the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened carefully to the member for Lyons (Mr Adams) trying to defend the government's position on the International Shipping (Australian-resident Seafarers) Grants Bill 1995 and I am in some difficulty in understanding the line of reasoning. The bottom line is that the government is subsidising ANL to the extent of $20 million in an attempt to buy off the Maritime Union of Australia. They have put pressure on the government by way of strike action and the government has caved in and tried to do a deal with the union in an endeavour to keep Australian ports open.

PARA.TAB: The member for Lyons struggled valiantly to defend that position with some facts and some figures that are not really relevant to the main argument. The situation is that this ANL saga is hopefully coming to a conclusion. We see in this morning's press that it still remains to be finally concluded with a sale to P&O. Again, the MUA are instrumental in preventing that final sale, but I will deal with that in a moment.

This particular bill is the legislative conclusion of a deal brokered between the government and the ACTU and the Maritime Union on 13 September 1994 after the MUA had instigated a five-day national strike to gain their point of view. They were worried, as we all know, about the future sale of ANL and what might turn up. The government has been trying to sell ANL since 1991. In September last year the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) relied on one valuation and said, in his classic quote, that ANL `could not be given away'.

In the House of Representatives only 10 days ago most of us on our side of politics clearly set out the arguments of the strange and wide range of valuations of ANL that took place, and yet that shipping line has yet to be sold. Minister Brereton sacked the board, put the ANL back for sale and, as of today, we have P&O making the offer of $19.5 million, less the losses that have been accrued from 1 April to 31 October. It is estimated that ANL is losing $2 million a month. So not only has the sale not gone through, but the government is certainly accumulating losses at a rapid rate.
The situation we have today is very relevant to this bill. It is worth quoting from an article in the Financial Review today, under the heading `ANL deal heads for the rocks', which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government's strategy to manage the sale of ANL is in tatters after the refusal of the ACTU secretary, Mr Bill Kelty, to push the powerful maritime union into a deal with the British shipping group P&O.

PARA.TAB: The Government had expected Mr Kelty to salvage the continuing fiasco of the shipping line's proposed sale by getting the unions to agree to terms.

SPEECH.PARA: So here we have the situation where this very bill was part of the agreement that the government would do a deal with the Maritime Union on the basis that they would avert a strike and that, hopefully, the sale would go through. The article says:
. . . it now turns out that the only likely exit route Mr Kelty foresees is the same as that pushed by the Maritime Union of Australia: restructuring under continuing government ownership.
And it further goes on to say:
Bill Kelty has a long history of strong and emotional support for the Maritime Union of Australia, calling it the heart and soul of the labour movement.

PARA.TAB: We have it quite clearly where the ACTU stand and where the Maritime Union stand in the whole argument. The maritime waterfront strike was used for blackmailing purposes, closing the ports for five days in order to get their point of view across. I draw the attention of the parliament to the political blockade that took place in Western Australia only yesterday. It had similar connotations and similar points of view, that is, the Western Australian government, legitimately, were threatening the privileged position of the trade union bosses in that state. They put forward some quite sensible reforms such as secret ballots.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not what the workers think.

—How could anyone argue with secret ballots before strike action? How could anyone argue with asking the members of any particular work force to have a secret ballot, as they do in shearing sheds to decide whether the sheds will be wet or dry? That has been a secret ballot for the last 50 years. How could the honourable member complain about that?

PARA.TAB: Other reforms included no more political donations from membership subscriptions to a particular party unless people decided to make that particular donation to a political party, a choice of a superannuation fund and not being coerced into a superannuation fund because the union hierarchy told people they had to do it, and ensuring that the unions chose between a state and federal award. They are all quite sensible suggestions and no basis for the major strike which held up the whole of Western Australia yesterday. That strike was purely political, as most Australians would understand, with Perth airport held up and the state transport instrumentalities at a standstill. It was all done for political reasons.

Similarly, we have the situation with the MUA using their considerable clout to hold up the ports around Australia just to get their own way. As Greg Bondar, the executive director of the Australian Chamber of Shipping, estimated, the national waterfront strike cost shipping $55 million.

The Australian Chamber of Shipping further estimated that 200 ships had been stuck in Australian ports during the five-day stoppage. To end the strike, which is the key argument, Minister Brereton offered an exemption of PAYE tax for all Australian seafarers engaged in international shipping. That was the deal after all this argument. As usual Minister Brereton said, `Here's a bit of a deal,' through Mr Kelty, his friend in the ACTU, `This is the way we will solve it.' Whilst the workers did not receive any additional take home pay, the exemption would make Australian seafarers up to $20,000 cheaper to employ, if you do some of the figures.

It is interesting to look at the figures. According to the Australian Shipowners Association, the base rate of pay for crew members is $40,000 per annum. That is not a bad rate of pay by anyone's standards. They have six months on and six months off. Again, that is not a bad set of conditions. They are on board 24 hours a day seven days a week and it is obviously fairly difficult and arduous work—I concede that. They work eight hours a day plus overtime. That is the nature of seafaring activities.

The Ships of shame report, which I have been associated with, looked at the problem of crews from overseas. They work from nine to 10 months for considerably less remuneration but it is hard to work out exactly what that is and what the conditions are. Through the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure the parliament has been trying to bring about a better set of conditions at the international level. However, it does not give the government the right, in an industrial dispute, to use taxpayers' money to overcome the problem of the Maritime Union of Australia trying to get the ships and break the strike.

The Shipping Industry Reform Authority estimates the savings to this particular taxpayer subsidy would be in the range of $700,000 per annum. Obviously, shipowners are quite happy about receiving, yet again, a taxpayer subsidy to keep their operation going. The key element is the tax break which has been suggested. Mr David Russell of the Taxation Institute of Australia said that the decision to provide PAYE tax breaks would produce a greater complexity in the tax system.

We had the remarkable situation where the minister said, `We'll give a tax break to the maritime seafarers on Australian ships,' and we had a conflict with Treasury and the tax office. Both Treasury and the tax office felt that the concession would be better provided through direct grant payments rather than through tax exemptions. However, as usual, Minister Laurie Brereton was not convinced, and the Australian on 28 December 1994 reported that Mr Brereton believed that the PAYE exemption was `the least complicated option' and that he was `confident of winning Treasury support' for his proposal. Needless to say, on this occasion, Treasury won and Minister Brereton lost. It is really an outrageous proposal to suggest that particular workers in the Australian context would have their tax paid by way of a direct government grant. What a remarkable proposition: that Australian seafarers would have Australian taxpayers paying their tax just to win a political deal!

The grants that the government is proposing total $19 million per year, just to win a short-term political impasse between the union movement and the government. The argument was between the government's proposal to sell the ANL—quite legitimately; it has been up-front about that since 1991—and the Maritime Union being unhappy about that. These grants, on the basis on which they were originally proposed, were a blatant breach of the principles of original PAYE tax exemption, and they still remain a pay-off to the union, as I say.

The explanatory memorandum of the bill states that the grants are being paid in order to place Australian operators in a better position, `on a more equal footing with their overseas competitors in respect of crew costs' and will `provide an incentive for the Australian shipping industry to develop new international trading opportunities'.
