What a remarkable thing, when ANL has been losing money for most of its existence! The Australian taxpayers—and the government, might I say—are now sick of that and are going to sell the operation.

The government is claiming that the grants are being made following a recommendation by Mr Rae Taylor of the Shipping Industry Reform Authority. The Taylor report, issued in August 1994, stated that Australia's international shipping industry faced competitive disadvantages due to high government taxes and charges—I stress that they were high government taxes—as well as inefficient wages and conditions for crew. Some of us, including the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), have been very close to these arguments over the past few years in terms of improvements, but we note in the Taylor report that government charges were one of the key factors in our shipping arrangements being internationally non-competitive.

The Taylor recommendations included a clawing back of the cabotage protection, smaller crew sizes, and tax exemptions for the industry. Following the five-day national waterfront strike, the only recommendation which the government followed up was the PAYE tax exemption, along with a guarantee to the MUA that Australian crewing and award conditions would remain on the ANL. That is the key to the whole argument that P&O is concerned about. If it purchases this particular operation, P&O wants to have its own terms and conditions as it sees fit in a commercial operation; and, of course, the MUA just will not agree with that.

The Taylor report was in fact all but ignored, except for the PAYE tax sweetener, and I have indicated to the parliament exactly why that was the situation. It really shows the hypocrisy of the minister claiming that the grants are part of a drive for greater competitiveness. They are simply a sweetheart deal to buy industrial peace from the MUA. Any citizen of Australia who has any understanding of the waterfront and of those arguments would clearly understand this position.

It is interesting to look at the arguments of how much ANL carries of our trade. Australian ships, in fact, carry only three per cent of all Australian international trade—a very small percentage—yet we get this major debate and argument about the role of ANL and the conditions of Australian seafarers. As I understand it, there are 21 Australian shipowners and 78 Australian owned and registered flag ships, and 30 of these are involved in international shipping. The grants that have been forward by the parliament will be in respect of 1,000 to 1,200 Australian seafarers.

Let us draw a comparison with what the government might do for other sections of the community. On 13 September 1994, at a time when 40,000 Australian farmers were affected by the worst drought on record, the government found only $14 million to assist them. On the one hand, we have 1,200 seafarers who are close to the government and close to Mr Kelty. The seafarers are receiving $20 million and yet the government could find only $14 million to assist farmers who are providing valuable and important export income and there are very carefully regulated conditions about the way in which the assistance could be given. With the farmers, there was not an open cheque as is the situation with the shipowners. The poor old Australian farmers struggled through that drought as best they could and with very little government assistance because they did not have the entree to the ACTU that the Maritime Union of Australia obviously does.

Mr Jack Waterford of the Canberra Times put it very clearly when he wrote an article in 1994 called `Me too please, Minister, me too!' drawing these comparisons. Mr Waterford said that the political lobbying industry would be thrilled by the deal struck between the government and the MUA. Anyone who wants to get an understanding of how to do a good job just has to have a look at the form guide here. Mr Waterford said:

SPEECH.PARA: After all, if the shipping industry can get this sort of assistance, why should other sectors not hold their hand out for similar concessions?
Mr Waterford, an independent commentator on the situation, drew this comparison. Mr Waterford went on to say:
Are not international airline crews in the same position? Could not the wheat industry claim that its international competitiveness is cruelled by domestic taxation arrangements?

Why should they not seek $20 million by way of government handout if they decide to hold up international airlines for three days? Why not hold them up for five days and see what the government would do in this situation and what Minister Brereton might offer by way of peace to get the airlines back in the air. Mr Waterford went on to say:

The government might find itself not only continuing to send good money after bad, but coping with hordes descending on Canberra claiming that the sailors' treatment is the appropriate precedent for their own situations. Some will seem to have convincing cases—even if they can't blackmail the Government with a $10 million a day strike. But that's the problem with failing to run a consistent tax policy and making little deals for short-term solutions to continuing problems.
Mr Charles Armstrong, representing the New South Wales Farmers Federation, said:

Do farmers have to take some form of illegal action to get government to help them at this time of drought? Farmers have not engaged in what was an illegal strike. They played by the rules and are yet to gain satisfaction, while militant maritime union members have gained their demands after a six-day strike that threatened Australia's vital export markets.

Here we have a very stark comparison between the government's attitude to drought stricken farmers and its attitude to some of its own mates within the trade union movement with the help of Bill Kelty. Bill Kelty is on the record as being very close to the Maritime Union and as saying that they are the heart and soul of the trade union movement.

PARA.TAB: Mr Alan Wood, writing in the Australian, wrote this very interesting piece:

SPEECH.PARA: Behind this situation is what amounts to a national extortion racket.
Mr Wood is a respected commentator. He went on to say:

The MUA runs a closed union shop in the maritime industry, protected by the Government and the industrial legislation. As a result of its monopoly position as a seller of maritime labour, the MUA is able to extract wages and employment conditions well above their true market value. Employers have had no choice but to pay up, although since they could pass the cost on in higher port and shipping charges, they have not complained much until recent years, when there has been more pressure from customers as a result of micro-economic reform elsewhere in the economy.

This information sums up the situation that the Maritime Union is able to exert considerable pressure on the government. We have the International Shipping (Australian-resident Seafarers) Grants Bill 1995 before the parliament in order to pay $20 million to enhance the conditions of Australian ship-owners as a result of political activity. The situation is not as a result of a sensible, well thought out position of making Australian ships more competitive; it is just more tax payers' dollars in an attempt to keep afloat a small proportion of the international fleet which helps in the export of Australian goods and services and an attempt to keep Australian ports open.

PARA.TAB: It is these blackmail tactics by the MUA which forced the Minister for Transport to provide this assistance to the 1,200 seafarers and we have this amazing situation before the parliament where $20 million is being used to pay for peace on the Australian waterfront.

I hope some of the reforms that some of us have seen on the waterfront, in terms of moving containers and better industrial relations, will flow through and continue to improve. I am not one to criticise the waterside workers. I think there are a number of other elements on the waterfront—the stevedores, the shipowners and some of the historical pressures—that need improving. But this particular decision by the government does not encourage anyone on the waterfront to expect that better, more stable and more sensible conditions could prevail. It sets the clock back to a situation where the government, in times of crisis, will always ask the poor old taxpayer to pay up yet again to solve an internal, domestic, political, union problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have heard from the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) is mostly false and I have to confess that I had a greater regard for him and his contribution to this place than to have expected much of the falsity I have just heard from him. His statement that the Australian taxpayers are paying Australian seafarers' tax by this legislation is completely baseless. It illustrates very clearly how little the opposition understands the legislation.

PARA.TAB: Seafarers do not get one cent from this legislation. They pay their tax, and will continue to pay their tax, like any other Australian taxpayer, worker, manager or executive. For the member for Corangamite to say what he did utterly astounds me. They do not get one cent from it. It is a blatant and a false statement and, really, what it does is confirm the opposition's animosity towards Australian seafarers. It is burnt into the opposition and they cannot help but hammer away at demeaning Australian seafarers. But those seafarers are constituents, they have families, they are part of Australian industry and they are out there in the tough international market.

We are looking to all sorts of schemes, programs and forms of assistance to encourage other Australians to go into the export industry, and that is all this is. It is an export measure to try to put Australian shipping on a more equal footing in the international market for the trades. So not one dollar, not one cent, of the measures in this legislation goes to Australian seafarers. The honourable member for Corangamite also makes reference to drought assistance. I do not recall hearing him complain that farmers were not being generously treated and there was consultation and involvement of the farmer organisations. The farmer organisations had some difficulty with the National Party, and with the opposition, but not so much with the government.

So that the record shows what we are dealing with, here are some of the ships that are operating in the international trades. In the carriage of natural gas there is the Northwest Sanderling, Sandpiper, Northwest Snipe and the Northwest Storm Petrel, and Ampol's Ampol Sarel. The first ones are all LNG tankers and the Ampol one is a crude tanker.

ANL has the Tranztas Trader, the Australian Trader, the Australian Venture and the Australian Endeavour, which are cellular container vessels, the Australian Advance and the Anro Australia. The Anro Australia is a RO-RO container vessel and the Australian Advance is a straight container vessel. For BHP, we can go through the Iron Spencer, the Iron Shortland, the Iron Flinders, the Iron Dampier and the Iron Gippsland. There is BP's Australian Achiever, which is a crude oil tanker. Caltex has the Australia Star—another crude oil tanker.

Holymans' CHL Innovator is a bulk carrier that carries, internationally, bulk refined sugar. What that is doing is helping Australian sugar get to international markets more competitively in Australian owned and Australian operated vessels. We can add to that CSR's Kowulka. That is also in the bulk sugar trade. Holymans' Alltrans is in bulk trade, Howard Smith's Express is in dry bulk trade and there is Mobil's tanker Mobil Flinders. These are not Australian seafarers. These are names of shipping companies and the vessels they operate in the international trades. There is also Perkins' vessel Frances Bay, which is a RO-RO trader, the Coringle Bay, which is a general trader, and Shell's Nivosa, which is a crude oil tanker.

None of those vessels are owned by ANL or by Australian seafarers but they do employ Australian seafarers. The benefit of the International Shipping (Australian-resident Seafarers) Grants Bill 1995 goes to those ship operators to help them to become more competitive in international trade, so offsetting similar measures from our competitors in those international markets.

Shipping is an important industry to this country. In 1992-93, our exports totalled more than $60 billion and those commodities included meat, minerals, fuels, manufactures, coal and processed foods. Approximately 70 per cent of our agricultural products and the vast majority of our mineral resources are exported and traded in overseas markets. In this context shipping is a vital component of the nation's economy and of Australia's ability to meet international trade demands.

When we turn to Australian shipping, the Australian Shipowners Association, in partnership with the maritime trade unions, has over the last few years embarked on a restructuring of the industry. It is a restructuring that has produced cost savings in the vicinity of $7 million per annum. Australian shipping is now amongst the most labour efficient in the world and crewing levels have been reduced from 30 on average to 18 per vessel. That is lower than OECD levels and well below the world average of 23. In contrast to the increasing age of international ships, which on average is 17 years, the average age of Australian ships is 10 years. It is a younger fleet.

Under these circumstances Australia should be recognised as having the capacity to compete with other countries. But crewing costs are not the only costs. There are other advantages that our competitors have by way of tax benefits and tax concessions that are not shared, that will not be available in this country until this legislation passes. The challenge for Australia is to place our shipping on a similar footing to that which operates in the nations of our competitors. That means we need to develop and make markets. We need to be using the same strategy and we need to be using our own vessels for greater export effort.

In overseas areas there is a range of assistance mechanisms. Foreign fleets are often heavily subsidised and the ships that carry Australia's trade are in receipt of numerous financial incentives from their governments. Singaporean maritime companies offer Australian seagoing deck officers or engineering officers, recognised by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, remuneration in tax-free US dollars. In other words, if you have an Australian master's ticket, or mate or engineer's certificates, those companies will employ you but they will pay you in tax-free US dollars. That is the kind of comparison that we have to make with our international traders and with our international fleets here in Australia.

On conclusion of employment those companies repatriate those seafarers back to their home port. Companies under the approved international shipping enterprise scheme get a tax exemption for 10 years. Canada in 1991 changed its tax laws to favour the relocation of foreign companies and seafarers so that they could remain competitive with many Asian ports.

Cyprus has been attracting many European shipping companies due to the tax incentives it provides and it is now grabbing a large proportion of Russian shipping. But Cyprus also figures prominently as a flag of shame. Cyprus is increasingly a haven for operators of substandard shipping. They are out there in the international market, so not only do they operate, in many cases, with vessels that are substandard but they get considerable benefits and financial incentives that are not available in this country.

Denmark has removed the pay-as-you-earn tax element from the employer's gross payroll, making it industrially neutral. Denmark did not encourage the employment of foreign nationals and it had the effect of reducing labour costs. What we are about here is Australia introducing measures to counter these imbalances from foreign countries. The Australian Shipowners Association set it out in the Australian Shipowners Journal of June 1995:

SPEECH.PARA: If we are to create the jobs and the wealth the Australian community expects we need to do more. We need to increase our share of world trade. In particular, we need to offer our services to the rest of the world.

This legislation will place Australian ship operators on a more equal footing with their international competitors in respect of crew costs and provide an incentive to the Australian shipping industry to develop new international trading opportunities. The government's principal aim is to ensure that Australian ship operators have continued access to competitive liner services and are able to expand their trade interests. The grant is, as I said earlier, payable to employers who are Australian nationals. It is not payable to Australian seafarers. They pay their taxes and are in exactly the same position as any Australian taxpayer. Under the legislation, to qualify for the benefit a vessel must be engaged in international voyages, with a minimum number of days being half of its operation days.

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 11.32 a.m. to 11.54 a.m.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Snow)—I call on the honourable member for Shortland, in continuation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the committee is graced by your presence. I am very pleased to see you are performing this task.
—He looks very elegant as well.

—He does that. Before the suspension I was about to say that many of our trade partners, especially in Asia, have determined policies to grow their international shipping industries. Yet in Australia our international shipping industry is scorned by senior and powerful departments such as Finance, Treasury, Foreign Affairs and Trade, Prime Minister and Cabinet and Defence, and even the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. This seems to be a cultural thing amongst senior bureaucrats in those departments. It is a policy that this country cannot afford.

PARA.TAB: For decades, as policy advisers to government, they have sold out our national shipping interests, while fostering what were often minuscule land based industries. Why are they doing that, when we can see to the north of us that the Asian nations—Malaysia, Singapore and the Philippines—are all pushing and developing their international shipping industries and their ports as international ports? With the policy advice going forth to successive governments in this country, irrespective of the political complexion of those governments, it is no wonder, on looking back, that the policies have been against Australian shipping and against Australian seafarers.

Vessels are able to visit more than one port under the provisions of the bill, as long as the volume of their domestic or Australian coastal cargo does not exceed the total mass of their international cargo. Provision in the legislation enables shipping operators to broaden their trade base and engage in both domestic and international operations. The basic amount paid for each seafarer berth to the employer is essentially the amount of income tax that would have been paid by the person occupying it.

The bill recognises Australia's exclusive economic zone and extends the provision to an anchorage in the zone or the fishing grounds on the high seas, and this takes account of Australia's vast maritime territory. It enables vessels operating in these areas to meet the competitive challenges that are presented to them when they seek to trade against other international companies. So the government is, in this legislation, honouring its commitment.

The government is in agreement with the Australian Shipowners Association, which stated that tax concessions on the cost of employing Australian seafarers and Australian vessels which spend more than half of their time in international trades would be economically and socially sensible. That is why this provision has been introduced. It will help make Australian shipping a more competitive industry and it will help attract foreign investment.

The opposition is paying lip-service to Australian shipping interests, lip-service which varies from downright opposition to the actual mouthing of words of support which the opposition has no intention of carrying forward in practice. Australian seafarers and Australian seafaring unions do not receive one cent of the payments to be made under this legislation. I made that point on several earlier occasions. The tax that would have been paid by the Australian seafarers is taken by the qualifying Australian shipping companies, and it will help place those employers on a fairer footing when compared with their international competitors. I have outlined the financial assistance that is already available to some of these international competitors.

The opposition goes further in its dishonesty, and claims that tax rebates are now payments to ANL. All Australian ship operators who meet the conditions of the legislation will benefit, the major ones being BHP and the oil companies. I mentioned and listed those ships and the companies that will benefit, and that list includes Howard Smith, Shell, Caltex, Ampol, Mobil and ANI. But I want to see the list grow. I want to see more Australian companies seeking out opportunities in international shipping, and this legislation will go part of the way to creating greater opportunities for Australian based shipping operations.

Australia has a good name in international shipping circles for competence and responsibility. Australia is playing a major role internationally, particularly at the International Maritime Organisation, in ridding our seas of substandard ships and their immoral crew practices. This parliament's Ships of shame report of 1992 has received worldwide acclaim and support, and it has played a major role in much of the reform that is going on internationally. Australian ship officers are in demand overseas. Why? They are in demand because Australian training and Australian skills have worldwide recognition.

Australian maritime credentials are quality credentials, especially where seaboard tasks are comprehensive and complex. Yet those skills and their standing are not given recognition in Australia, especially by major companies in Australia or by senior bureaucrats at the federal level, who seem obsessed with putting down Australian seafarers and Australian shipping interests. Nations much smaller than Australia, especially the traditional shipping nations like Norway, know the benefits to be gained from an effective shipping industry.

We have a solid base to work from, as the fifth largest market in the world on a cargo distance-carry basis, but our problem is that we lack the will from Australian companies to invest. Most are content to be captive customers of foreign shipping lines in the carriage of international trade. Norway, with less than one-quarter of Australia's population, knows the trade benefits to be gained from international shipping. Norway generates less than one per cent of the world's trade, yet Norwegian shipping companies own almost 10 per cent of the world's fleet, and they do this by working hard to carry other nation's trade in their ships.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they more efficient?
—Their crewing levels are greater than ours, but they get greater assistance from government.

PARA.TAB: Shipping is at the foundation of the entire range of Norwegian maritime activities, which go far beyond shipping itself. This is one of the things that drives me with Australian shipping. Shipping is not just about shipping: it is one link in the chain. In Norway, other related activities are shipbuilding, manufacturing of ships' equipment, financing, ship-broking, insurance, legal services, classification, and education and research. It is estimated that in a population of 4 1/4 million people, between 60,000 and 70,000 people are involved in activities related to the shipping industry. We in this country can learn a lot from that.

The World Bank has estimated that the total cost of upgrading and renewal of the world fleet will be approximately $50 billion by the year 2000. The investment in new tonnage that is required over the next decade is an investment that Australia ought to be sharing in—but we are not, because of the attitudes that develop and exist in this country.

In supporting this bill, I want to make it so very clear that this is about helping the Australian shipping industry become more competitive; it is about helping the Australian shipping industry to get out there in the marketplace; it is about encouraging other Australian companies to invest in the shipping industry. It is not about a handout to Australian seafarers at all. They do not get one cent of it. It is not about a handout to ANL, as members of the opposition have tried to put to us earlier.

The legislation, and the proposals that it contains, come from the shipping industry itself. It is similar to many other forms of industry assistance that we have in this country. We have an industry with a solid base from which to work. What that industry needs is recognition; it needs support, and it needs support for the people who work in the industry, so that Australia uses the income that will come from international sea freight to reduce our invisible deficit.

Marine insurance is linked closely to this. Very little of our international cargo is insured with Australian companies, even those companies that are world-competitive. The simplest example is iron ore. It is corporate policy by purchasers in Japan that iron ore must be insured with Japanese insurance companies. There are 16 major insurance companies in Japan. They do not compete with each other. Whichever one you deal with, you get the same rate. But even though Australian marine insurance companies are world-competitive in the rates they can offer on that cargo, they do not get the business.

That is something that has to be addressed at government level, and at the parliamentary level. It is certainly a matter that I have been proposing to put forward in discussions through APEC. Although this is a non-tariff barrier—it is corporate policy—marine insurance is another area industry, linked to shipping, in which Australia is world-competitive. Those non-tariff barriers are preventing us from getting our fair share of the market. I commend the legislation to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity of speaking on the International Shipping (Australian-resident Seafarers) Grants Bill 1995, although I am wondering why a bill which is clearly contested by the opposition is being debated in this place, which is supposed to be dealing with non-controversial legislation. There was a division in the main chamber a short while ago, and we had to close down the Main Committee. That fact indicates that we need to refine the operations of this Committee. Clearly, there is a glitch in the system when this Committee must close down because of a division in the other place. I realise that this problem will be one of the matters looked at by those who will review the operations of the Main Committee as part of the parliamentary process.

PARA.TAB: As indicated by the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp), the coalition does not support the legislation and will be voting against it in a division, presumably in the main chamber, at a later time.

I listened carefully to some of the contributions made by government members and in particular to that by the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Adams). It is sad that he clearly has no idea of the major problems confronting shipping around our coastline. Indeed, it is clear that the government is bereft of ideas. We are a maritime nation. We have a very long coastline with many ports and yet, because of mismanagement in the shipping industry and because of unrealistic wages and conditions, we now have a situation where we have almost no coastal shipping and almost no maritime tourist ships. The old days of the Manunda and the Manoora, when they used to go right around the Australian coastline, are gone. That is tragic. As a maritime nation, we should be encouraging the use of the sea lanes and shipping as a means of tourism, transport and trade around our country.

As we become more concerned about our environment, we ought to recognise that superhighways and railways might well be very good and necessary, but one of the cleanest, most efficient and environmentally sensible ways of conveying goods around our coastline is through use of the shipping industry. It is a tragedy that most of the Australian shipping industry seems to have died this century. It is non-competitive. ANL is essentially on its last legs and the government ought to rethink the whole problem because it is an important area. It is in the national interest. The bill before the House does very little to solve the difficulties that I have outlined.

When one looks at the explanatory memorandum to the bill, one is given a misleading indication of what the bill is supposed to be about. The honourable member for Hume pointed out that the bill is all about a union deal. It is all about the arrangements that were made with the maritime unions on 13 September 1994. It is a bribe on the government's part to bring to an end the national maritime strike over the privatisation of ANL. That strike went for a number of days, tens of millions of dollars were lost, the government capitulated and the result is the bill currently before the chamber.

It is instructive to look at some of the media comment relating to that sordid deal entered into by the government, which is, as we all know, a government of the deals. A couple of days ago in the House we heard about a meeting involving the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), Mr Solomon Lew and Mr Lindsay Fox. Of course, the Prime Minister did not come clean and tell us what that deal was about. We do not really know. Ultimately, we will find out.

The deal entered into by the government was closed on 13 September 1994. In an article by Steve Burrell in the Financial Review of 14 September 1994 headed `Union gun to its head, Govt sinks back under flag,' a few home truths were pointed out. I would like to quote from that article:

SPEECH.PARA: The Keating government would like to pass off its agreement to end the maritime dispute as a wide-ranging package of micro-economic reforms.

PARA.TAB: It has, in fact, passed up a great opportunity to achieve genuine and long overdue reforms in Australian shipping.
It could have used this damaging confrontation as a catalyst to bring the long-standing problems in the industry to a head.
Undoubtedly this would have meant toughing out a long and damaging strike.
Instead, faced with the equivalent of a gun held to the economy's head by the maritime unions, it decided that it had no option but to compromise.
For the unions (and the local shipping owners) this exercise in brinkmanship has netted a pretty sweet deal.

SPEECH.PARA: The `pretty sweet deal' means that there will be taxpayers' money paid in the first year of an amount of approximately $19 million and the net impact over the next five years to 30 June 2000 could be $59 million after tax. So we have a situation where the taxpayer is, yet again, funding and propping up the shipping industry which, in many respects, has only itself to blame for the difficulties in which it finds itself.

PARA.TAB: Sadly, the government has rejected a number of recommendations in the Taylor report on reform of the industry. One of those rejected recommendations related to the establishment of a second register of Australian-owned vessels which will be permitted to use foreign crews. In other words, the future of shipping is not very different from its uncompetitive past, slowly sinking under an Australian flag with Australian crews and Australian award conditions. The government will effectively increase the subsidy for international shipping by providing new tax breaks on crew wages and depreciation.

The International Shipping (Australian-resident Seafarers) Grants Bill 1995 is the legislative instrument through which the government's deal will be implemented. Also, on 14 September 1994 the Financial Review had another article under the headline `Canberra goes ANL retentive,' which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: THE Federal government has bowed to Maritime Union demands offering tax breaks for Australian shipping and ruling out full deregulation of the industry in return for an end to the five-day national waterfront strike.

PARA.TAB: The Government has also guaranteed that cheaper foreign vessels and foreign crews will continue to be kept out of the coastal trade.
As well, the Government acceded to union demands to give its financially troubled shipping line, ANL Ltd, another chance to prove its commercial viability.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know the sad and sorry history of the proposed sale of ANL. We all know about the infamous comments made by the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton). I think it was in August 1994 when he said, basically, that we could not give away ANL. Yet again this minister is indicating his total, complete and utter incompetence.

PARA.TAB: The bill currently before the House commits the government to certain steps which are being implemented in the legislation, but the unions only committed themselves to consider negotiating an industrial reform package including further reducing crew size and the crewing factor, changing employment arrangements so that costs matched those under company employment and a long-term wage agreement and reduced training costs. Basically, what they said was, `We will think about these matters' while the government said it would implement this bill. Clearly, the unions have got the better end of the bargain.
There was a very interesting diagram in the Financial Review of 14 September 1994 under the heading `Unions win in shipping deal' where it says:

SPEECH.PARA: Government agrees to:
Keep foreign vessels and foreign crews off Australian coastal services.
Keep ANL commercially viable with Australian crews and award conditions.
Give a union consortium a chance to buy a majority shareholding in ANL—
that clearly is not going to happen—
Consider tax breaks worth—
they estimated then—
about $18 million to the shipping industry and $5 million to ANL each year.
Unions agreed to consider:
More reductions in ship crew sizes and crew holidays.
Guarantee industrial peace.
Other efficiency measures as part of a new industrial package.

As we stand today, the other changes the unions agreed to consider have not been implemented. Australian shipping remains uncompetitive. More money continues to be lost and when one looks at some of the employment conditions which used to exist—two crews per ship and so on, and everyone agrees now that these were unsustainable—it is no wonder that Australian shipping has been reduced to its current sad and sorry state which is resulting in the industry putting out its hand for more taxpayer funds.

PARA.TAB: The government has made a lot of air play of reduction in crewing levels. I concede that there have been some reductions in crewing levels. The honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) mentioned before that some Australian ships have fewer members of the crew than some overseas ships. He cited the Norwegian example. No-one could deny that Norway is a very efficient shipping nation. Part of the problem is not the number of crew members on a particular ship but rather what they do when they are there. At the present time I am told that crew levels and costs could be tolerated if the crews would perform the same tasks as crews on rival lines. I would like to quote from the Bulletin of 6 June 1995 which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, Australian crews do not carry out maintenance, such as overhauling engines and scraping off rust while the ship is operating. This means that an ANL ship will spend more time in dry dock than one from a rival line.

Of course you do not need to be a mental genius to appreciate that, when we have that kind of hiccup in the system, ANL is simply not going to be as competitive as overseas shipping lines. The article continues:

The cost—both directly and in lost business—could run to an extra $1 million . . . for each ANL ship, putting the line at a heavy disadvantage even without considering the customers it loses because services are curtailed. The lack of . . . ongoing maintenance also means that the life of an ANL ship is about 15 years, whereas rivals can stretch theirs to 25 or 30 years.

When one looks at the capital cost of shipping in Australia, it is clearly a major commercial benefit if an overseas shipping line is able to extend the life of its vessels from 15 years to 25 or 30 years. It is interesting to note the next point:

The actual crew wages only amount to about 3% of ANL's total operating costs, but these other factors blow out to about 9% and really start to wound the line. The cost of the crews is less important than the fact that they don't do enough.

Japan provides another instance. Some of their manning levels are actually more than the manning levels on Australian ships but those extra people are used to keep the ship shipshape, they are used for ongoing maintenance, they are used in many other ways, whereas I do not know what some of our people on ships do. I do not know whether they play volleyball or whatever. The simple fact of the matter is that we might have fewer people but they do less than overseas seafarers would do, and the result is that Australian shipping is yet again uncompetitive.

PARA.TAB: It is unfortunate that the government is coming into the parliament again to seek up to $59 million of taxpayers' money to be given to the shipping industry over the next five years. It has been pointed out that the seafarers will not receive any of this money, and I concede that, but the bottom line is that the taxpayer is funding this. It is another prop-up to an industry which has allowed itself, through varying causes—partly its own and partly other factors—to be uncompetitive.

The coalition is opposed for a range of reasons to what the government is seeking to do. We stress that it is wrong for the parliament to give effect to a deal which everyone concedes to be shonky. It is a deal which the government entered into with the unions as the price for the unions abandoning a very costly strike, and the government is asking us, the members of the Commonwealth parliament, in effect to rubber-stamp this deal to give benefits to the shipping industry—in effect, the government's pay-off to the unions.

The government, with an election just a few months away, if that, is clearly trying to build bridges with the unions. We know what an important role the unions played in the election of the government during the 1993 election. The government will be talking to unions; the government will be seeking to trade off deals because this government is the government of the shonky deal. The government, through this legislation, is clearly seeking to get a major sector of the trade union movement on side so that the trade union movement, when advertising takes place prior to the election, will give full support to the programs of the government.

The explanatory memorandum portrays the government as trying to put Australian operators on a more equal footing with their overseas competitors in respect of crew costs and providing an incentive for the Australian shipping industry to develop new international trading opportunities.

I want to see the Australian shipping industry compete, but really we need to go back to basics. We need to look very much more closely at the major structural problems which prevent the Australian industry from being anywhere near as competitive as it should be. These handouts which the government keeps asking the parliament to approve are no long-term answer to the major difficulties confronting the Australian shipping industry.

The incentive which the government is seeking to have implemented through this legislation is a taxable grant payable to the employers of Australian seafarers on Australian operated ships engaged in international trade. The amount of the grant would be equal to the notional tax payable on the earnings of seafarers serving on that ship. To qualify, a ship must be Australian operated, its crews must be employed by an Australian employer and the ship must spend not less than half its operational service during the year on international voyages. It is interesting to note that some shipping lines are already changing their schedules to try to take advantage of the particular benefits for them included in this legislation.

At present, we have about 30 Australian operated ships engaged in international trade and the grant in the first year will be approximately $19 million. The grants are taxable, so that about one-third can be expected to be recouped in 1997-98 because corporation tax payments are lagged by a year. The after-tax impact for each additional ship entering the international trade would be about $400,000 per year. If one ship enters the trade each year, the net impact after tax would be $59 million over the five years to 30 June 2000. I mentioned that if it was possible—and I believe it is possible—to have crews on Australian ships doing the variety of work that crews do on ships operating in other countries, we would achieve a benefit of $1 million per ship. Clearly, if that could be attained, it would not be necessary to bring in this legislation which hands a benefit of about $400,000 with respect to each ship involved in international trade.

The coalition is totally opposed to this legislation. We will be voting strongly in the main chamber when this bill is voted on after its return there. We simply will not be a party to this union deal. We will not go along with what the government has sought to do. We do not believe that this is an appropriate response to the very major problems confronting the Australian shipping industry, and the minister stands condemned. In fact, it is a wonder that the government allows this minister to remain as the minister for transport because he has a sad and sorry history of mistakes and being quite inept in so many areas of his portfolio. We do not even see him here in the Main Committee; it is, perhaps, beneath him to come here. But the government has come in here and asked us to approve the allocation of up to $59 million over five years.

What the government should be doing is looking at the major and ongoing problems which have reduced our shipping industry to the sad and sorry chaos that it is—a sad and sorry chaos that saw the government knuckle down and saw it run up the white flag when we had the strike last year. We will not accept what the government is seeking to do. We hope that the government reconsiders this matter, because an Australian shipping industry is important.

Shipping around this continent is absolutely vital and what we need are policies which will encourage and foster the growth of shipping, whether it be Australian or overseas shipping. We need to encourage shipping as a means of tourism, to bring tourists here and bring them around the Australian coastline. We need to encourage it as a means of transport, and as a means of communication.

But, unfortunately, there is absolutely nothing in this bill before the Main Committee which is going to improve the long-term future of the industry. There is absolutely nothing that is going to make it viable. I think this bill speaks for itself. It is a bill to implement a shonky deal and the coalition will have absolutely no part of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the previous speaker, the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper). It is interesting that this bill, the International Shipping (Australian-resident Seafarers) Grants Bill, is being dealt with in the Main Committee. As has been outlined today, the coalition proposes to vote against this bill, so at the conclusion of the debate it will end up back in the main chamber.

PARA.TAB: If nothing else, the way that the government, and particularly the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton), has dealt with the whole issue of ANL has been an interesting saga—and a sad and sorry one. The government is in the grips of a massive asset sale program and has been in that position for a number of years. It has not achieved a great deal of success as far as asset reduction is concerned. This bill we are dealing with has a very clear and definite impact on the government's asset sale campaign, particularly with regard to the sale of ANL. It was announced by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) on 9 May 1995 when the government was in the process of attempting to negotiate the sale of ANL after the Minister for Transport had made his infamous announcement that `you couldn't give it away'. Subsequently, the government flogged off the most profitable part of the ANL group, which was the stevedoring section.

The whole sorry saga, interestingly enough, caused Laura Tingle to write an article in the Australian earlier this year. In that article she refers to exactly what we are debating here today in relation to this bill. In that article, headed `Labor's behaviour in flogging our shipping line has been disgraceful', Laura Tingle stated:

SPEECH.PARA: And a small technicality of the "sale" for "$19.5 million" is that, whatever P&O is buying in terms of assets, taxpayers get to keep $183 million in liabilities which the British-owned shipping line doesn't want.
She went on to say:

Last year, facing a likely rebuff on the sale, already delayed for four years, by the ALP national conference, Brereton selectively released details of a valuation of ANL which showed it had a negative value—and which he used to justify his decision to withdraw it from sale.
Of course, we all know that behind the scenes of withdrawing it from sale was the Maritime Union of Australia, which was exerting a bit of pressure, as it always does, on the Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: One of the Labor members—I think it was the member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell)—stated here a few weeks ago, in the main chamber of the House of Representatives of this parliament, that she was `proud' to be a member of the political wing of the ACTU. That is on the Hansard record. She is a member of the government of Australia—disgraceful. I go back to Laura Tingle's article. She went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Soon after this, he rammed through the sale of the shipping line's only decent asset, a 25 per cent interest in Australian Stevedores . . .
As I said before, they sold off the most profitable part of ANL. Interestingly enough, at the end of the article, Ms Tingle noted:
Brereton was in such a hurry to do this that he agreed via mobile phone from a funeral to a deal letting the supposedly financially wrecked ANL lend the money to the buyer without firm security.
In terms of this debate, the important part of this article that Laura Tingle wrote was at the end of article. It said:
The deal had another price: an ongoing $20 million a year support bill for local mariners.

That is what this bill that we are debating today is all about: an ongoing $20 million a year support bill for mariners. Who foots that bill? Who covers the cost that the government is asking us all to commit to today? It is the taxpayers of Australia. The taxpayers of Australia have absolutely been bled dry by the mismanagement of ANL.

PARA.TAB: At the same time, and in the same article, we saw that the minister spent almost $1 million of taxpayers' funds on the you-beaut pair of whiz-kids—the mates—that are supposedly getting ANL out of the mire. They have achieved nothing. The value has gone down. We have not seen a sale. They—that is, one Mr Turnbull and one Mr Wran—have been paid their almost $1 million retainer. They have been paid almost $1 million of taxpayers' money to try and salvage ANL, to get it up and running so that we can sell it and get some profit for Australia for the Australian taxpayers. We have seen nothing.

Now we are asked to sign off on a bill that is going to spend almost $20 million a year of taxpayers' money. We must ask the question: on what? It is interesting. What is the purpose of the bill? The purpose of the bill, according to the Bills Digest from the library, is to provide for a system of grants—`grants' is an interesting word to use—to Australian shipowners who undertake international voyages. According to the explanatory memorandum, the grants will:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . place Australian shipowners on a more equal footing with their overseas competitors in respect of crew costs and provide an incentive for the Australian shipping industry to develop new international trading opportunities.

PARA.TAB: When you dig into it a little deeper, what is the money really being spent on? The money is really being spent on the arrangement that was made with the unions earlier this year. In September 1994, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), senior cabinet ministers, the ACTU and the Maritime Union met to negotiate an industry reform package. As a result of those negotiations, Treasurer Willis announced via a press release on 9 May 1995 that the government had agreed to the introduction of a taxable outlays grant—taxable in the hands of the companies, so that there is company tax payable on it—to be paid to owners and operators of Australian-registered ships predominantly engaged in international trade, to offset the impact on owners and operators of personal income tax on the earnings of seafarers on Australia's eligible international trading ships. The grant is to be administered by the Department of Transport. Subsidising the PAYE tax that is paid by members of the Maritime Union of Australia is what it is all about.

The bill goes on to talk about eligibility but, interestingly enough, Australian flag shipping carries only four per cent of Australia's foreign trade, and ANL is not the major carrier of this portion. We are supposedly providing a subsidy, and it is interesting to look at this in terms of the overall public policy direction in which the government is going, as far as subsidies and tariff protection for Australian industry are concerned. Everybody else in this country has had the barriers in front of them torn down by this government. There is no protection. `Get out there on the world stage and become world competitive: no protection for you!' Australia, as a nation in the international marketplace, has led the way in tariff and subsidy reduction, ahead of any signing of the Uruguay Round.

I noted in some of the information I researched to speak on this bill that the Uruguay Round on free trade and `detariffication' did not get to international transport or international shipping. That was left out. That is all well and good, but this Labor government of Australia has hurtled down the path of `detariffication', pulling down those barriers which are protective walls for a lot of Australian industry. Australian industry has been told, `You get out there and compete and become world competitive!' Here today, we are heading back in the other direction by providing assistance and a subsidy, in a roundabout fashion.

All the commentary on the bill says that it is supposed to make our shipping lines more world competitive. But does not that beg the question of why our shipping lines are not world competitive? Everywhere else, we are expected to be world competitive without any assistance, subsidy or tariffs. Why are they not world competitive? The taxpayers of Australia need to ask that question. The bill is born out of a deal with the Maritime Union of Australia, whereby Minister Brereton wanted things to go along quietly while he was trying to sort out his unbelievable mess with the Australian National Line.

As a buy-off as far as that union was concerned, the minister said he was going to provide a subsidy, supposedly to international shipping. But it is all about keeping the union happy, because that is where it is ending up. It is going to the companies, but it is ending up back with the unions. Fair enough! But let us be fair about the whole thing. We say to our primary producers and manufacturing industries, `Get out there and compete on the world stage, without any assistance from this government.' This is one of the reasons that our primary industries cannot compete: they have had their hands tied by the lack of true micro-economic reform as far as the transport industry is concerned.

We have seen the decisions that this government has made as far as tearing down those tariff barriers and subsidy mechanisms is concerned. In its haste to be one of the gang and one of the big players on the world market as far as free trade is concerned, Australia has led the way. We have pulled down our tariff levels and then we have gone off and signed up in the Uruguay Round of the GATT to reduce them by a percentage each year, starting from a lower base than everybody else is on. I am yet to be convinced that, in that area, we are ever going to end up on a footing level with some of our competitors around the world, because we are starting low and coming down, while they are starting up high.

The most salient point is that we are telling all our other industries in Australia to go out and become more efficient, to become more effective, to become better producers and to compete on the world stage, yet we are not asking this industry to compete. We are not asking this industry to have a close look at itself and ask itself why it cannot compete. What are we doing? We are providing the industry with a subsidy which is going to end up back at the level that I spoke of earlier, on the premise that it is going to make this industry more world competitive. Do you know what? It will not. It will not work. It never has. And it never will work, for the same reasons that we have had to make all our primary industries, all our manufacturing industries, cut the fat, get rid of the fat, have a close look at their process and work out why they really are not competitive.

It did not work there and now those industries are competing, not because of anything the government has done but because they have had a long, hard look at their process and they have found ways and means to become more world competitive. There is a long way to go in that area, where a future government might be able to help them. But this measure by this government will not go anywhere near helping the shipping lines become more world competitive. Of course some of the industry organisations are going to agree. They are getting a handout. That has never helped anybody get off their butt and go and compete and make themselves productive and efficient. It just will not work. History will prove this government wrong in putting this bill before the parliament today and asking us to sign off on it.

On that basis, the opposition is not going to sign off on it. We are going to oppose this bill because it is not right. It is heading in the opposite direction from what this government is expecting of most other industries in this country. On that basis we are going to oppose it. As I say, history will record that this government is heading in the wrong direction and that this sort of measure will not achieve what it is designed to do in helping the shipping industry to be more competitive. The government knows where it has to head to to make Australian shipping more competitive and this is not that direction. I think that it is important that these comments be recorded and that the government be made aware that, as I said before, it is not fooling the people in the press gallery, it is not fooling the people that are informing the people of Australia on what is going on.

I will just repeat the comments of Laura Tingle, because I think they are just a classic. I used this in a speech when we were debating the ANL Sale Bill a couple of weeks ago. I do not know that Laura Tingle is really a great fan of the coalition either, but her headline was, `Labor's behaviour in flogging our shipping line has been disgraceful.' In part of that article she said, `The deal had another price: an ongoing $20 million a year support bill for local mariners.' That puts it in a nutshell. It is nothing to do with making Australian shipping more competitive. It is a $20 million a year support bill for local mariners, and it is a disgrace. As she said, the behaviour of the Labor Party in flogging the Australian shipping line has been disgraceful. The coalition will oppose this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my happy duty to sum up on this debate. I was parliamentary secretary to the minister for transport some years ago and I think the member for Hume (Mr Sharp) was then the shadow minister. He is still the shadow minister and I do not think he has learnt a great deal over that time. What I am astounded by is his absolute lack of regard for the reforms that have already taken place in the Australian shipping industry, which seem to be ignored totally by the opposition, and the rather gratuitous advice they seem to be giving the Australian community about the way in which the shipping industry is performing.

PARA.TAB: It is worth contemplating, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Dr Theophanous) outlined in the second reading speech, just one aspect of the reform process which has taken place. In 1983 a typical Australian trading ship had a crew of 33. The opposition would have us believe that nothing has changed since 1983. Has something changed? Has it or has it not? Have we improved the crew rates on Australian flag vessels? Simple answer, yes or no. Answer—yes.

We will not hear of opposition members saying to the community that the reform measures activated by this government—not by a coalition government—have not had a dramatic impact on crew rates. When the coalition was in government before 1983 and when we came into government in that year the figure was 33. What is it today? Do you know the answer? Eighteen. Do you think that is some improvement? Do you think it might be just a marginal improvement, or do you think it is a dramatic improvement?

TALK.START.PARA: —Are we any more competitive than we were?
—In fact, it is interesting you say that because in 1983 average crew sizes were well in excess of OECD levels; today our crew levels are lower.
—What about your crew to berth ratios?

—No, our crew rates are lower. These are by anyone's measure remarkable achievements. I presume that the three opposition members who are in the chamber at the moment have read the bill and the second reading speech. Of the three major components to this bill, the one which seems to have incurred the ire of the opposition concerns the grants that are payable, based on the tax liabilities of seafarers in Australia's international trading ships.

PARA.TAB: The opposition would have us believe that somehow this benefit was going to the employees, that a direct financial benefit would accrue to the employees—the seafarers. Opposition members know that is not true. If there is a benefit, it goes to the shipowners. Listening to opposition members, one would think it was going just to ANL. In fact, they know it is not and that other shipping companies such as BHP Transport will also benefit.

I am not going to canvass all of the issues in this debate but, to have some integrity in public life, you could surely accept that, even though you may not agree with everything the government does—and I do not expect you ever will—you might at some stage accept that there has been dramatic improvement, dramatic micro-economic reform, in the shipping industry in Australia and that this bill is part of that reform process. If you were genuinely interested in competitive shipping for Australia, you would acknowledge that. But we do not hear any acknowledgment of it; all we hear are disparaging comments about these shipping industry reforms and disparaging comments about the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton). Both views are out of order because the shipping industry supports these reforms. As shadow minister you do not support them but the shipping industry does, and if you were in touch with your shadow portfolio—

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! I remind the parliamentary secretary, as I had to remind the honourable member for Hume earlier in the debate, to be judicious and careful with his use of the word `you'—

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't have any ewes in here, but I am referring to him, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—And to refer his remarks through the chair.

—I am happy to refer them through you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The shadow minister—who actually lives very close to Canberra, I might say, and not very close to the sea—needs to be aware that these reforms are supported by the shipping industry. If it is not the waterfront, it is the shipping industry we continue to hear about, which amazes me. We hear opposition members saying there have not been adequate reforms on the waterfront, that we have not improved our competitiveness, that this is not a legitimate process in micro-economic reform. This Labor government—not a conservative government—has implemented reforms which are being supported and will be supported in the future by the industry. It seems to me very important that we acknowledge that, even though our opponents seem very reluctant to do so.

PARA.TAB: The final point I want to make refers to comments by the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), about the failure of the—

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 12.46 p.m. to 12.55 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the division in the House, I was about to comment on the member for Fisher who was making some rather gratuitous remarks about the absence from this chamber of the Minister for Transport. You will have noticed I am sure, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the reason the minister is not here is that he is in the House debating a bill which has been the cause of some divisions. So I would suggest to the member for Fisher that, before he goes off like a firecracker, he might just deliberate about what he is saying and consider, when he attacks a member of the parliament for not being in a particular place at a particular time, that it is very difficult to be in two places at once. And while I recognise that the opposition intend to vote against this legislation, I would suggest to them that is not a wise course and I would urge them to reconsider their position.

PARA.TAB: Question unresolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —As it is necessary to resolve this question to enable further questions to be considered in relation to this bill, in accordance with standing order 277 the bill will be returned to the House for further consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 8 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: Is he aware of any case in the history of civil aviation in which passengers have survived a plane having been ditched; if so, will he provide details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Australian Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) does not and is not required to keep records of overseas air safety occurrences. Therefore, my response to the honourable member's question is based on reported occurrences involving civil aircraft in Australia.
A search of the BASI's air safety occurrence data recording system has revealed 32 occurrences involving ditching where passengers have survived the accident or incident.
Details of these occurrences are:
(1) On 28 March 1969, a De Havilland DH-82A aircraft ditched near King Island, Tas and the only passenger on board survived.
(2) On 30 September 1970, a Cessna 177 aircraft ditched in Randalls Bay, Tas and all three passengers on board survived.
(3) On 25 March 1972, a Sikorsky S-58B aircraft ditched in Darwin Harbour, NT and all nine passengers on board survived.
(4) On 22 April 1973, a Piper PA-23-250 aircraft ditched near Karumba, Qld and all five passengers on board survived.
(5) On 12 November 1976, a Mooney M20E aircraft ditched near Newcastle,NSW and all three passengers on board survived.
(6) On 31 May 1977, a Hughes 369HS aircraft ditched in King George Sound Gulf, WA and the two passengers on board survived.
(7) On 26 October 1977, a Piper PA-28-140 aircraft ditched in a river near Bankstown, NSW and the only passenger on board survived.
(8) On 27 April 1981, an Aero Commander 500S aircraft ditched near Hobart, Tas and all five passengers on board survived.
(9) On 15 August 1981, a Bell 47G-5A aircraft ditched in a lagoon near Van Rook Station, Qld and the only passenger on board survived.
(10) On 26 October 1981, an American AA-1C aircraft ditched in Bateau Bay, NSW and the only passenger on board survived.
(11) On 18 September 1983, a Piper PA-32R-300 aircraft ditched near Kieta, PNG and all three passengers on board survived.
(12) On 26 October 1984, a Bell 206B aircraft ditched near Bond Island, Qld and all three passengers on board survived.
(13) On 29 December 1986, an Aerospatiale SA.330J aircraft ditched near Karratha, WA and thirteen of the fifteen passengers on board survived.
(14) On 25 April 1987, a Cessna 182G aircraft ditched near Groote Eylandt, NT and all four passengers on board survived.
(15) On 15 January 1988, a Kawasaki BK117-A4 aircraft ditched at Balmoral Beach, NSW and the two passengers on board survived.
(16) On 13 March 1988, a Cessna P210N aircraft ditched near Outer Harbour, SA and three of the four passengers on board survived.
(17) On 28 March 1988, a Bell 214ST aircraft ditched near Troughton Island, WA and all thirteen passengers on board survived.
(18) On 24 June 1989, a Bell 206B aircraft ditched near Ingham,

ANSWER.PARA: Qld and all four passengers on board survived.

PARA.TAB: (19) On 3 July 1989, a Bell 206B(III) aircraft ditched near Sydney, NSW and the two passengers on board survived.
(20) On 6 October 1989, an Aero Commander 500-S aircraft ditched near Port Hedland, WA and all three passengers on board survived.
(21) On 16 January 1991, a Bell 206B(III) aircraft ditched near Heron Island, Qld and all four passengers on board survived.
(22) On 12 May 1991, an Aerospatiale SA.330J aircraft ditched near Karratha, WA and the only passenger on board survived.
(23) On 5 July 1991, a Chrislea CH-3 Series 4 aircraft ditched near Moruya, NSW and the only passenger on board survived.
(24) On 21 November 1991, a Bell 214ST aircraft ditched in the Timor Sea, WA and all fifteen passengers on board survived.
(25) On 8 January 1992, a Cessna 210 aircraft ditched near Hamilton Island, Qld and all five passengers on board survived.
(26) On 28 July 1993, a Bell 206B(III) aircraft ditched near Gladstone, Qld and one of the three passengers on board survived.
(27) On 23 October 1993, a Bell 47J-2A aircraft ditched near Whyalla, SA and the only passenger on board survived.
(28) On 29 November 1993, a Cessna 152 aircraft ditched near Port Stephens, NSW and the only passenger on board survived.
(29) On 15 February 1994, a Bell 206B aircraft ditched near Dalywoi Bay, NT and all five passengers on board survived.
(30) On 24 April 1994, a Douglas DC3C-S1C3G aircraft ditched in Botany Bay, NSW and all twenty-one passengers on board survived.
(31) On 6 July 1994, a Cessna U206G aircraft ditched near Whyalla, SA and the only passenger on board survived.
