ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aboriginal Legal Service : Principles and Practices

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 1 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What principles and practices does the Aboriginal Legal Service (ALS) apply to means testing Aboriginal persons applying for assistance.

(2) Does the ALS provide free legal service to persons who have adequate financial means to fund their legal actions; if so, what is the effect on the provision of services to disadvantaged Aboriginal persons and does the ALS have sufficient funds to assist persons without regard to their financial means.
(3) Does the ALS attempt to charge fees of persons able to fund their legal actions who choose to be represented by the ALS.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) has provided the following information in response to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Legal Services generally do not apply a specific means test to applications for assistance primarily because they believe the application of such a means test would not be cost effective.

(2) Legal Services consider each case on its merits and will generally consider factors such as the financial position of the client, the importance of the case to the client and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people more generally, the budget available to the Legal Service, the prospects for success in the case and alternate financial assistance available, in determining whether to take on a specific case.
(3) Not generally, but will seek to have an award in relation to costs for cases in which they are successful.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 27 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a letter from Mr Rob Elder, Government Relations, Civil Aviation Authority, to Ms Judith Rintoul, Northside Residents Against Helicopter Noise, dated 10 May 1995, indicating that the Minister had asked the CAA to undertake an urgent review of helicopter operations over Sydney Harbour and surrounding areas.
(2) Has he asked the CAA to undertake the review referred to in part (1); if not, (a) what is the status of Mr Elder's letter and (b) why was it written.

(3) If he has asked for a review to be undertaken, (a) when did he ask for the review, (b) has the review commenced, (c) what stage has the review reached, (d) what conclusions has it reached or recommendations has it made, (e) who within the CAA is responsible for the review, (f) will (i) noise, (ii) safety, (iii) heights, (iv) regulations, (v) monitoring and (vi) other aspects of helicopter operations be considered in the review, (g) what are the guidelines or terms of reference for the review, (h) what indications or announcements have been made to (i) the general public and (ii) local councils regarding the review and its conduct, (i) what provision is there for (i) the general public or (ii) local councils to make submissions to the review, (j) what are the details concerning making submissions to the review, (k) on what dates will the (i) review conclude, (ii) conclusions or recommendations be released to the public and (iii) the report be handed to him and (l) how and when will changes recommended by the review by implemented.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(2) and (3) I am aware that in May 1995 an officer of the former Civil Aviation Authority replied to a letter from Ms Judith Rintoul, Northside Residents Against Helicopter Noise, confirming that I had asked the Authority to undertake a review of helicopter operations over residential areas of Sydney with a particular focus on helicopter flights over the harbour.

The initial phase of this review resulted in a decision by the newly established Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) to increase the height at which helicopters are required to fly in the prescribed access lanes east of the Sydney Harbour Bridge from 152 metres to 305 metres.
I announced that change in a media release on 10 August 1995 and it was implemented on 14 September 1995.

I also confirmed that this is the first in a range of measures being undertaken by CASA and Airservices Australia in response to concerns by residents about the environmental impact of low flying and hovering helicopters around Sydney Harbour and in the vicinity of sporting and entertainment venues.

CASA is reviewing all approvals given for low level helicopter operations in the Sydney area, particularly banner towing. I am advised that the Authority recently issued a policy paper to its Regional offices in relation to the requirements for banner/flag towing operations in Australia and, in particular over Sydney Harbour.
I have also called for compulsory limits for hovering times over residential areas. This activity poses a particular noise nuisance for residents.

For operations other than police and essential services, CASA will have to be satisfied that any approvals are justified on both environmental and safety grounds. Approvals should be granted only in exceptional circumstances.
The legislation establishing CASA specifically requires the Authority to take into account the environmental effect of aircraft operations while maintaining the highest possible safety standards.

The issue of the noise nuisance associated with low level helicopter operations is not confined to Sydney, and I have asked the authorities to ensure that the new arrangements apply to built-up residential areas across Australia's major cities.
I understand that the Authority recently met with Airservices Australia, the Federal Airports Corporation and the NSW Environmental Protection Agency to discuss these issues.

I expect that the second phase of the review will be completed by the end of the year. Any changes to the regulation of aircraft operations would require consultation with interested parties including community groups.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 28 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) How long does his Department take to process pension applications.
(2) Does his Department keep statistics on waiting times for pension approval.
(3) What is the longest delay between application for and granting of a pension.
(4) Is it a fact that (a) all claims for pensions are processed within four months and (b) telephone inquiries have quick access to Departmental officers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) There are three major types of pensions paid by the Department: service pensions, disability pensions and war widows' pensions. Based on the first six months' statistics of 1995, it is estimated that the mean time taken to process a claim for service pension was 34 days, and 128 days for disability and war widow's pension claims.
(2) Yes.

(3) The longest delay between application and granting of a service pension claim in the first six months of 1995 was up to one year. However, there were only five of a total of 2 230 claims received that took 250 days or more to process during the period.

The longest delay between application and granting of a disability pension claim is over two years. However, these claims were approximately 0.1 per cent of the total intake. About 1.6 per cent of such cases took over a year.
(4)(a) Yes, in respect of service pension claims. The first six months' statistics of 1995 indicate that nearly 98 per cent of service pension claims were processed within 120 days.
No, in respect of compensation claims. However, the Department has set a target of 120 days for processing all compensation claims with 80 per cent to be finalised within 80 days.

Statistics for the first six months of 1995 of compensation claims processing are not a reliable reflection of current processing because of the recent introduction of a new Compensation Claims Processing System in all States and the use of the new Repatriation Medical Authority Statements of Principles in the determination of compensation claims. These Statements of Principles are binding on all determining authorities.

Statistics for the last two months show that about 55 per cent of disability pension claims and 59 per cent of war widow's pension claims were processed within 120 days. For this period the mean time taken to process compensation claims has reduced to 119 days and is expected to continue to fall as more efficiencies in the new system are realised.

(4)(b) Yes, in respect of compensation claims. Since the introduction of the new Compensation Claims Processing System, claims are processed by officers who handle all aspects of the investigation and decision, including direct telephone contact with claimants concerning their claims.
Where appropriate, the Department also makes telephone contact with claimants to minimise delays in the processing of their claims for service pension.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 30 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: Further to the answer to question No. 2079 (Hansard, 22 August 1995, page 112), is it a fact that no statistics are readily available that indicate the relative size and productivity of the timber industry in each State and Territory, with indications of variation in practice among States and Territories; if so, on what basis is it possible for the Commonwealth to make an informed evaluation of the total number of coupes which may be logged for woodchip exports in any given year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Statistics are available which indicate the relative size and productivity of the timber industry in each State. In addition, forest management processes in each State are determined by specific Codes of Practice, developed, implemented and overseen by relevant State Authorities.

As you would be aware, under the Export Control (Unprocessed Wood) Regulations, I have responsibility for refusing or granting licences for the export of woodchips. Under the regulations, I am required to give consideration to the possible effects of logging on the environment. I also have obligations to fulfil under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals), the Australian Heritage Commission and the Endangered Species Protection Acts when considering licence applications. Major exporters have been subject to Commonwealth Environmental Impact Statements and long term approvals are based on these assessments.

In fulfilling these obligations, consultation is required with other Commonwealth Departments and Agencies such as the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories and the Australian Heritage Commission. In making decisions on export licences for woodchips, I take into account their expert advice.

However, the process is also dependent on the co-operation of the relevant States and, to this end, the Commonwealth and the States have signed the National Forest Policy Statement (NFPS) which commits both levels of government to the sustainable management and use of Australia's forests resources. Consistent with the NFPS, the Commonwealth has committed significant resources to the accelerated development of regional forest agreements (RFAs) to be signed by the Commonwealth and each State, identifying areas to be managed for conservation reserves, and areas for timber harvesting.

Regional Forest Agreements will require a comprehensive assessment of the environmental, heritage, social and economic values of the forests in each region. The Commonwealth allocated $53 million over 4 years in the May Budget, for these assessments. As part of these studies, sustainable yield will be assessed.

By 2000, no woodchip exports will be permitted except from areas covered by RFAs and substantial effort is being applied to their development which will obviate the need for coupe by coupe assessments in future.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, upon notice, on 21 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What level of excise per litre of fuel was payable in March 1983.
(2) When was the excise on fuel tied to the CPI.
(3) When did application of the 2 cents per litre excise impost for the Bicentenary Road Fund (a) commence and (b) cease.
(4) At the time it ceased, what was the effective rate of the excise referred to in part (3) as a result of the automatic CPI adjustment.
(5) What revenue sum was collected from the (a) 2 cents per litre impost and (b) CPI compounded excise on that impost.
(6) To what extent was the 2 cents per litre impost and compounded excise used for roads.

(7) Was the additional excise resulting from CPI adjustment removed with the 2 cents per litre impost when the latter ceased; if not, what sum has been collected from the excise component comprising the CPI adjustment of the impost.
(8) What sum did the Commonwealth (a) collect from fuel excise and (b) spend on road works in each year since 1982.
(9) What method is used to apply parity pricing of fuel in Australia.
(10) How is the excise on fuel adjusted when the world parity price falls.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lee The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The excise rate for automotive gasoline and diesel oil in March 1983 was $0.06155 per litre.
(2) Indexation of Excise Tariff rates on refined petroleum products was introduced on 23 August 1983.
(3) The Department of Transport has advised:
(a) 1 July 1983; and
(b) 31 December 1988.

(4) The Department of Transport has advised that the Australian Bicentennial Road Development (ABRD) Trust Fund Act established the rates of surcharge at 1 cent per litre for the period 17 August 1982 to 30 June 1983 and 2 cents per litre for the period 1 July 1983 to 31 December 1988. There was no provision in the Act to adjust the rate of surcharge to movements in the CPI.
(5) The Department of Transport has advised:
(b) Not applicable
(6) The Department of Transport has advised that total receipts from the 2 cents per litre surcharge and interest on the ABRD Trust Fund was $2.407b. All of this was spent on roads.
(7) Refer to answer for question 4.
(8) The Department of Transport has provided the attached table.
(9) The Department of the Treasury has advised:

The four major oil companies—Shell, Mobil, BP and Australian Petroleum—are currently subject to prices surveillance by the Government's independent pricing body, the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA), in relation to the supply of petrol and automotive distillate. Surveillance is applied by means of wholesale price caps for sales of petrol and distillate direct to resellers and distributors set by reference to import parity prices. Under what is known as the intervention pricing system, a `landed' cost for fuel is calculated based on import parity prices of bulk ex-refinery petrol and distillate from Singapore. Prices there closely reflect those in other major world petroleum product markets and it is the main source of imports into Australia. The Singapore product prices are adjusted to become import parity or landed prices by the addition of freight from Singapore, wharfage costs in Australia and insurance. As product and freight costs are quoted in US dollars, the value of the Australian dollar vis-a-vis the US dollar has an effect in the calculations. Intervention prices for petrol and automotive distillate are calculated daily, based on a seven day rolling average of the latest available Singapore prices.

In the absence of the existing prices surveillance arrangements, the extent to which local petrol and distillate prices reflected international prices would be more fully determined by market forces. It appears that imports of petrol and distillate are a close substitute for local production, hence the domestic price of these products would be unlikely to move significantly out of line with international (import) prices provided effective competition exists at the wholesale level. Under the PSA's system, local consumers are protected as they need pay no more than international refinery prices plus

ANSWER.PARA: shipping costs, local taxes, marketing and distribution costs. In addition, overseas refinery efficiency gains are reflected in domestic wholesale price caps and local refiners are given incentive to invest and employ. In the domestic LPG market, which is not subject to price regulation, major producers mostly set their prices for domestic sales on an import parity basis using the marker price established by the largest international supplier of LPG, Saudi Arabia.

PARA.TAB: (10) The Department of the Treasury has advised that the excise rate on fuel is set by the Commonwealth Government independently of movements in international oil or petroleum product prices.
